{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/wanted-a-new-education-paradigm/article_73e8a4c2-8e60-5b7d-b4d4-df4c3de5ebb8.html", "TITLE": " Wanted: a new education paradigm ", "DATE": "Jul 16, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Part I In his very informative articles on education in the June and July issues of the Trinidad and Tobago Review, Kevin Baldeosingh makes reference, in the June issue, to policy changes being instituted by Minister of Education Dr Tim Gopeesingh, to compari- sons to educational policies in other countries and to the 2010 McKinsey and Company report. In the July issue, he again takes Dr Gopeesingh to task, notably asking for justification and validation of changes he is making, makes further other country comparisons and conducts analyses of aspects of the T&T system, plus an interesting reference to Vivian Stewart's book, A World-Class Education, and highlighting her four traits of high-performing education systems. Anent Dr Gopeesingh, as another clinical professional, I find that Dr Gopeesingh is treating the T&T educational system like a patient, ie, he has diagnosed certain pathologies (problems) in the system and, like the good doctor he is, and according to his training in dealing with pathology (problems), he is prescribing certain treatments (solutions). However, I suggest his approach is homeopathic, treating the symptoms, rather than holistic or going after the root causes of the problems (more on this in a bit), and looking at the problem from a public health perspective. Getting back to my point, what am I alluding to by my assertion I mean that the T&T education system is basically a failure, an anachronism, and no amount of plasters or Band-Aids is going to rescue it. And my condemnation includes the teacher training system (how they are trained), the lack of value placed on teachers and the total inadequacy in the way and amount teachers are paid. Modern educational systems in the Western world were initially designed for the transition from an agrarian to an industrial production-based needs societyin the 19th and 20th centuries. We are now, however, in the 21st century; a century with a new needs basis and a new paradigm. For example, in the US, in 1960, almost zero per cent of the US workforce was employed in information technology, while currently that figure is over 60 per cent. From about zero per cent to over 60 per cent in 50 years! A new educational paradigm is slowly and, with much resistance, working its way into fruition in the US. Of particular note in this new paradigm, most of the higher level positions, well-paying jobs, better placements and professional places are being taken by women. Males are becoming (actually, have become) an endangered species and don't think this does not constitute a threat to society What do hordes of testosterone-loaded young men with no prospects do The old jobs are largely gone, many left taken over by robots and the better and emerging jobs being taken by women. Here in T&T, do you wonder that crime (drugs and gangs) is a career default mode Do you have to wonder much for causes of increased violence against women Do you think it is going to get better before it gets worse As the old expression goes, \"you ain't seen nuthin' yet\". Let us take a look at some of the comparisons that Mr Baldeosingh made about the systems in other countries, especially, to make our points about revamping the total education system, in the way teachers are chosen and trained, and, most importantly, paid. Singapore is often compared to T&T with T&T usually cast in the negative light. Once you look into the differences in the make-up and complexities of the two societies, however, the comparison is not entirely fair. Anent the education system, in Singapore, teacher candidates are chosen from the upper one third of university graduates with even further screening of certain qualities amongst those. In Singapore, teachers are very highly valued and respected, they are very highly paid and they stay in their jobs. Is this true of T&T I think not. Consider the comparison with the US where teaching candidates come from the lower one third of university graduating classes, are not valued and respected, are poorly paid and do not stay in their jobs. One does not have to conjecture much to understand why the US now ranks so poorly on so many education parameters. Even though Singapore is considered to have one of the world's most successful educational systems, critics have pointed to shortcomings which the Singaporean government is starting to recognise and address. For all its shortcomings, America is able to produce world-class achievers as many (unfortunately far from all) US students are in a system where they are encouraged to develop the ability to reason, to think critically, to problem-solve ; basically to think, question, reject and synthesise. This is a far cry from the Singaporean emphasis on rote and strictly book learning. You receive what you are willing to pay for and what educational parameters you put into the system. Where do you place T&T in all this China is another country that in a relatively few years has produced an amazingly successful educational system which incorporates many attributes of the Singaporean system, However, like the Singaporeans, the Chinese are staring to recognise the same deficiencies. China is able to turn out thousands of engineers but not enough of the type with the ability to think to the next level, to make the innovations necessary to respond to the needs of a complex society. However, it is beyond the scope here to discuss the issues involved but suffice it to say that qualities found in many, but far from all, of the US systems, such as critical thinking, problem solving, and entrepreneurship, leave many advantages to these US systems which the Singaporeans, Chinese, Koreans and the Finns are now recognising and looking to address. Mr Baldeosingh discusses the Finnish system in particular, a system that has been widely recognised as highly successful. However, lessons from the Finland experience are not at all easy to reconcile with the historical experience and demographic diversity of T&T. The Finns start off with a dramatically different zeitgeist: they are a very old, settled, stable and most importantly, homogeneous society with a stable economy based upon agriculture (forestry products) and high tech (a company called Nokia). They also have a long (often negative) history with their neighbours to the East that yields a strong sense of solidarity in the Finnish population. Against this demographic and psychological background, re-creating an education system in a 30-year period as discussed by Mr Baldeosingh is impressive, but not totally remarkable. The Finns are, however, like everyone else, being challenged by the forces of modernity: immigration, changes in economic markets, an aging population. And the educational system is being challenged also! One significant educational issue that they now share with many other societies is what they call \"the lost boys\". The lost boys are those who aren't making it in the school system and are dropping out. The question in Finland as elsewhere is: \"Are dropouts failing in their studies, or is the system failing to support these individuals\" To be continued. Leonard Bernstein worked as a professor of orthodontics at the Boston University School of Dental Medicine, an environmental consultant, a medical education consultant, a small business owner and has developed an interest in education in general and early childhood education in particular. Jane Holmes Bernstein is associate professor at Harvard Medical School and a neuropsychologist at Boston Children's Hospital. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/diabetes-scare-among-children/article_aa6f3cad-8e82-5913-8e04-f06c24b0965e.html", "TITLE": " Diabetes scare among children ", "DATE": "Jan 17, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The booming soft drink trade is leaving top level health and education workers worried about the health of young consumers, Minister of Education Tim Gopeesingh said yesterday. He made the comment as he said over one million soft drinks are \"devoured\" in this country on a daily basis. He spoke after the release of the Helen Bhagwansingh Diabetes Education, Research and Prevention Institute's (DERPi) findings at the Daaga Auditorium at the University of the West Indies, St Augustine. Gopeesingh said the results of the initiative will affect the way the primary school system and Secondary Entrance Examinations (SEA) operated. Gopeesingh, who commended the private sector involvement in the initiative, promised Government's support in continuing the study, saying he will consider any research work within the school system. \"We welcome this type of initiative because diseases like diabetes, which result from obesity, stems from a lack of physical activity in schools.This means that it must be an important component toward the final marks of the SEA,\" he said. \"Sports, debate and drama would be included in the curriculum and form a measurable part of the exams.\" Prof Surujpal Teelucksingh, a member of the DERPi board, said the \"worrying\" results showed that childhood diabetes in the country had tripled in the last ten years. \"That gives Trinidad and Tobago the gold medal in these statistics,\" he said. The investigation, which began in 2008, tested 67,000 children between the ages of five and 15 and found 13 children with adult level diabetes. \"We tested them according to adult figures. If we reduced it to suit children, we would have undoubtedly found more. You cannot cure it if you wait for it to reveal itself, but it can be treated if you seek it out,\" Teelucksingh said. Teelucksingh said the levels could lead to a loss of human capital, which will take a toll on the nation's productivity. Diabetes, he said, was costing the country a lot of money in health care. \"Five per cent of all hospital admissions was because of diabetes or other related diseases. One of every ten admissions do not come out of the hospital alive. Twenty-five per cent of all hospital beds are filled with diabetic patients or people with related illnesses,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/taking-the-drama-out-of-school-life/article_c831c3cb-2351-59be-a60a-9afbb3fb41a0.html", "TITLE": " Taking the drama out of school life ", "DATE": "Jun 30, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "DYNAMIC: Jordan\u0092s Theatre Arts class on stage at J Errol Lewis and Renaissance\u0092s High Alert\u0097State of Emergency. \u0097Photos courtesy Anton Harris Photos Photography DYNAMIC: Jordan\u0092s Theatre Arts class on stage at J Errol Lewis and Renaissance\u0092s High Alert\u0097State of Emergency. \u0097Photos courtesy Anton Harris Photos Photography DYNAMIC: Jordan\u0092s Theatre Arts class on stage at J Errol Lewis and Renaissance\u0092s High Alert\u0097State of Emergency. \u0097Photos courtesy Anton Harris Photos Photography DYNAMIC: Jordan\u0092s Theatre Arts class on stage at J Errol Lewis and Renaissance\u0092s High Alert\u0097State of Emergency. \u0097Photos courtesy Anton Harris Photos Photography Mucurapo West Secondary School (formerly Mucurapo Junior Secondary) has long been associated with \"bad-behaved\" pupils. One might wonder then why Theatre Arts teacher Ayanna Jordan would choose to teach at that school out of all the others in the country. To understand that you have to know Jordan. What might be a deterrent for some is a challenge waiting to be met and overcome by the former St Augustine Girls' High School pupil. \"I always wanted to teach at a school where there was a need for the arts,\" she told the Express. Those quick to focus on pupils she referred to as \"my children\" don't know the full story, Jordan said. \"The stories behind their actions are deep. I won't condone wrongdoing, but people don't understand.\" Jordan got into theatre arts at SAGHS when she played parts in The Odyssey, Pressure does buss pipe and her favourite, A Raisin in the Sun, under the direction of teachers Avril Ramchand and Ann Assing Ahyee. When Jordan left SAGHS, she pursued International Relations and Theatre Arts at The University of the West Indies. At the Centre for Festival Arts, UWI, she was awarded the Beryl McBernie Prize for being an allrounder. \"(Theatre practitioner) Rawle Gibbons used to say of my directing style that I have an attention for details and that I approach directing in a photographic way,\" Jordan said. Dani Lyndersay, senior lecturer and coordinator, Theatre Arts at the Centre for Festival Arts, recognised her love for community work.\" Jordan taught financial literacy at schools before moving to Mucurapo West Secondary four years ago. Starting up a theatre arts class at the school initially proved to be a challenge. Since there was no class allocated to Jordan, she first used the Physical Education room, which she had to share. She spent one year there before moving to her own classroom, which she furnished with platforms and mats using funds she raised at the school. Jordan sees her Second and Third Form pupils once every cycle (six days), her Fourth Form students three times a cyle and her Form Fives twice a cycle. Theatre Arts is a legitimate subject in the school cirriculum and students are tested on what they learn at the end of the term and at the CXC level. The petite teacher has observed that Theatre Arts has made a huge difference in the way youngsters relate to one another and how they deal with stress in their lives. \"One of the things that I have them do is to journal. This allows them to express their feelings,\" Jordan said. \"I stress to them that we are all family and that families pick up for one another, rather than pick on one another.\" Jordan also encourages her students to critique each other's performance so they all learn from each other. Without warning, and due to their rapport in the classroom, she has also become more than a teacher to her students; she's also their friend. \"They all have me on BBM (BlackBerry Messenger) and What's App\u2014two cellphone chat programmes.\" Some of Jordan's pupils are also her Facebook friends. \"On Mother's Day I get a lot of greeting cards, which I welcome because I don't have children of my own.\" Last week Saturday, the Murcurapo West Secondary made its performance debut at J Errol Lewis and Renaissance Production's High Alert\u2014State of Emergency at Queen's Hall, St Ann's. Jordan was a director of a piece on reformed prisioner and mentor Ashton Blandin, who at 17, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for fatally stabbling a school friend. After serving six years in jail, his case was called and he was sentenced to three years in prison after pleading gulty to a lesser count of manslaughter. This, on the grounds that he served six years prior to his sentencing and on the account that--through his mentorship--he helped his fellow Youth Training Centre inmates to change their lives. The experience at State of Emergency proved not just to be an entertaining evening out for the Mucurapo Theatre Arts students but one that allowed them to see in action what they learned in class. As expected, Jordan's drama team Otis Nisbit, Shane Jackson, Omari Mitchell (who played Ashton), Isha Khan, Sherkell Phillip, Andrea Williams, Afiya Thomas, Kyia Samaroo, Akillah Bengochea and Nicholas Derrick were all nervous, but the positive response from the audience proved to be a welcome reward for their hard work. \"Ashton's story really had a big impact on my students,\" Jordan said. \"I could tell that most of them identified with his story. \"When the production was over, they took turns talking about what they learned.\" Jordan believes that a teacher she has the responsibility to be a change agent. \"I take my job as a teacher seriously. I know I can't transform every student, but I think that when you love and respect children they would gravitate towards you and open up.\" A lot of breakthrough stories have come out of Jordan's Theatre Arts classes. Some of her teens have completely turned their lives around; her past students have also gone on to good jobs and often keep in touch with their \"miss\" to update her on post-school activities. Like a protective mother, Jordan takes personally the rebuke of her \"children\" and the pupils of Mucurapo West. \"To the people who talk bad about them I say if you didn't make an investment in these children, don't look for the returns. Leave that for those who are actually investing time and energy into them.\" TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/think-of-the-children-and-revisit-concordat/article_3d3275ed-eb0e-555e-a76c-5d6a4b34d3fb.html", "TITLE": " Think of the children and revisit Concordat ", "DATE": "Mar 12, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " It is hardly a credit to the cherished Concordat, which from 1960 has regulated co-operation in education between the State and religious boards, that 48 Anglican schools are short of teachers. This situation has stirred a placard protest by parents and pupils at the Sixth Company Anglican Primary School, with the secretary of the Anglican Education Board of Management bluntly telling the Express, \"We do not have teachers.\" At the Sixth Company school, one parent complained that a single teacher was obliged to teach two classes. The parents made clear their preference for one teacher to a class and, indeed, logistics alone makes this arrangement far from satisfactory. At other Anglican schools, principals, appointed to manage their institutions, were themselves having to teach classes. With the Anglican board looking to the Education Ministry to supply teachers, both sides appear to be blaming each other for bureaucratic foot-dragging. The ministry, claiming to provide \"qualified and competent applicants\", argues the board insists on having Anglican teachers, who may not be in adequate supply. If this is so, then the Anglican school board is being somewhat disingenuous. Additionally, the Anglican Church can hardly complain about a shortage of professionally qualified Anglicans to teach in its schools when, over the past 30 years, the proportion of the population identifying themselves as Anglican has fallen from 14 per cent to a mere five per cent. Even the Roman Catholic Church, which has the largest percentage of the population by religion, does not insist all the teachers in its schools be of the Catholic faith. If, however, the Education Ministry wanted to appoint qualified teachers on the basis of merit only, it would run afoul of the Concordat, which states: \"A teacher shall not be appointed to a school if the denominational board objects to such an appointment on moral or religious grounds.\" This means a qualified teacher can be rejected not only on the basis of being the wrong religion, but also because he or she is a divorcee, a non-believer, a homosexual, or whatever the denominational board classifies as morally or theologically objectionable. In this particular contretemps with the Anglican schools, if teachers satisfactory to the board and to the ministry cannot be found, the Concordat-based collaboration is clearly failing. If only for this reason, operation of the agreement needs to be revisited. This, however, will be no easy task. Even the suggestion of a revised Concordat, whether bruited by People's National Movement or United National Congress administrations, has always met with vehement opposition from all the religious bodies involved. That attitude must change if the nation's children, Anglican and others, are to have their universal right to an education. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/education-and-rights-of-the-child/article_0a761fe8-edef-50c0-bd79-8b0e52b39f47.html", "TITLE": " Education and rights of the child ", "DATE": "Aug 12, 2009 ", "CONTENT": " Part I In my last two articles I wrote on the rights of the child. I shall now address education in relation to those rights. In my article of July 23, I pointed out that in our present constitution and in the Working Document reference to education under human rights referred only to parents' rights. The Principles of Fairness draft constitution, however, proposed rights of the child and rights to education which could be linked. An important issue for education in this country is the legal age up to which education is compulsory (12 years). It should also be noted that the legal age for entry into the workforce is 16! Many persons, including myself, have pointed out this absurdity which can be corrected by a minor amendment to the Education Act. This law is to undergo major review but as with many important issues this will take many years. I have previously suggested that the legal age to which education should be compulsory should be raised to 18 to capture those youths who are now involved in gang activity. In any event the population is aging and the retirement age may have to be raised with the consequent raising of the age for entry into the work force. Already the revision of the Education Act is shrouded in mystery. Last year the Education Discussion Group (EDG) was invited by the Ministry of Education to submit proposals for revision of the Act. We were invited on two occasions to appear before the committee set up to review the Act to discuss our submissions. This year to our astonishment when we expected to receive a revised draft for comment we were sent a draft Education Act of the Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS)! What this means I can only speculate. Does the Prime Minister's thrust for integration with the OECS mean that in future we will be following the lead of those countries While the Constitution can enshrine the right to education this cannot guarantee good quality in the education system or the essential social environment that will allow children to be given and benefit from an education system that allows them to express the potential for creativity that they all possess. Let us therefore examine the present circumstances in which children are placed to be educated. I shall start at primary school since the comprehensive system on early childhood centres is only now being installed and all praise to the Government for this effort. I shall first make general statements which are largely derived from discussion with teachers and persons concerned with the education system and then I shall attempt to back these up with such data as are available. There can be little doubt that the performance at the Secondary Entrance Assessment Examination (SEA) of students from different schools varies greatly. Since there will be random variation in the inherent abilities of any school population this variation in performance must be due to the social environment of the children, the environment of the school or the quality of the teaching. Let us first consider the physical environment of the school since this would be the easiest to verify. Primary schools vary from well designed and constructed and well maintained, to poorly designed, constructed and maintained. The frequent scenes on the television news of parents protesting on the poor condition of one school or another can leave no doubt as to the perilous state of many schools. But even where the schools are in relatively good repair the design may be unsuitable for learning. But this is just the tip of the iceberg. Many situations are far from ideal but are accepted by many parents who have come to accept them once they can afford the extra lessons and their children can be crammed to get a relatively high mark in the SEA. Whether they are well educated or not becomes a secondary issue. At the recent symposium held by the EDG (in collaboration with the University of the West Indies and the University of Trinidad and Tobago) David Subran presented a comprehensive paper on \"Impact of school facilities on teaching and learning\". It is intended that this paper will be posted shortly on the EDG website (educationdiscussiongroup.com). A common feature of primary schools is a large space divided into classrooms by blackboards so that the teaching in one class can be heard in the adjacent class. It would be informative to correlate this feature with performance in the SEA. There have been two newspaper editorials recently that discuss the problems in the education system: \"Drastic overhaul of the education system needed\"Guardian, July 24 and \"Our classrooms need to be havens\" Express, July 24. Of particular importance are two articles in the Catholic news by Fr Martin Sirju (August 2 2\"Catholic primary education needs overhaul\" and August 9\"Education issues: part two: Lessons and elitist education\"). Fr Martin's second article also discusses the ethnic implications of the deficiencies in the system. I shall discuss these four articles in Part II of this series. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/st-judes-school-made-it-possible/article_53d55ef9-82e6-56fd-8b00-51b0324244e0.html", "TITLE": " St Judes School made it possible ", "DATE": "Feb 16, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "OVERCAME OBSTACLES: Gender Youth and Child Development Minister Clifton De Coteau speaks to sisters Patrice, centre, and Adasha Norton at St Dominic\u0092s Children\u0092s Home yesterday in Belmont. \u0097Photo: ISHMAEL SALANDY OVERCAME OBSTACLES: Gender Youth and Child Development Minister Clifton De Coteau speaks to sisters Patrice, centre, and Adasha Norton at St Dominic\u0092s Children\u0092s Home yesterday in Belmont. \u0097Photo: ISHMAEL SALANDY Two young women were yesterday able to tell their stories of success in spite of having grown up in children's homes. Their testimonials came during the visit of Gender, Youth and Child Development Minister Clifton de Coteau and other officials to the St Dominic's Children's Home and St Jude's School for Girls in Belmont. De Coteau outlined a number of plans by Government including the establishment of the National Children's Registry and the establishment of Transition Houses. Those measures are intended to improve the lives of about 972 children from five to 19, living in institutions. Originally from Point Fortin, Patrice Norton spoke to her audience of children and officials about her struggles to become an auditor. Her younger sister Adasha Norton has excelled in sports and wants to make the senior national netball team. Both young women were able to relate their success stories because of their stay at St Jude's School for Girls. They were born to a mother hooked on cocaine. Norton said: \"It (our mother's addiction) affected the quality of life. We lived in a shack. No toilet. No water. We were about five to six-years-old. Our mother would disappear for days. We would have to drink water for days to survive. Then she moved in with an old man. He taught us a thing or two about church. Our mother would visit us. She would be drugged out. She would act weird. She would say weird things.\" At one point, an elder sister and the police intervened. \"They would give us toys. But around September 1997, they decided they had to remove us from the depressing situation. We spent two days at a halfway house. I was 11. It was the first time I had a birthday party. I knew the situation was going to change,\" said Norton. Although their mother struggled with her cocaine addiction, Norton said she never forgot her mother would regretfully say: \"If I could, I would have listened to my mother. If I could have gotten an education, I would have had a better life.\" When they moved to St Jude's, and she started attending St Martin's High School, Diego Martin, she decided to pursue an education. Later, she pursued her A-Levels at Malick Secondary and then attended university. Norton said: \"Without St Jude's, it would not have been possible. The transition was difficult. There was no one to talk to me or understand my struggles. I tried to focus on my studies.\" Adasha Norton said: \"At seven, I made a wish on my birthday. I wanted to live in Port of Spain. Two years after, we made the transition. I was nine. But I could not count. I did not know the alphabet. At St Jude's I found out I could play tennis and netball. I went to St Vincent and Grenada. I even picked up hairdressing. Today I am an ambassador for St Jude's.\" Norton said: \"I don't know my father. We still care for our mother. She is still on cocaine. We do not look down upon her. We try to let her know how strong her children are.\" Evans Thomas, from St Dominic's Children's Home, did not know his father. His motivation came from his caregivers. \"When there is someone who can say I believe in you, when there is someone to hold on to, that was what kept me.\" Thomas urged the children to take advantage of all opportunities available. \"There are few people who understand the psychology of growing up in a home. Don't let anybody say to you \"You are from a home.\" Don't ever stop believing in yourself. Photo by Roberto Codallo Hazel Browne. Photo by Roberto Codallo Carnival, we've long been told, is woman. But this year Carnival Tuesday crossed threads with the International Women's Day (IWD) commemoration. Coordinator of the Network of NGOs for the Advancement of Women, Hazel Brown, had no illusions about which March 8 celebration held the trump card. This year they've chosen to focus on the Commonwealth Day which is celebrated tomorrow (March 14). With the theme \"Women as agents for change\", the Network will honour women from various spheres. \"Some of these women work all day to ensure that there is food on their family's table. Others are campaigning for political, social & economic rights. Many are setting examples to others, pushing through vital reforms in the public service,\" Brown explained. Beyond our shores, however, women's organisations used IWD2011 as an advocacy platform in the area of education, training and decent work. Roberta Clarke, Regional Programme Director of the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment explained that there must be a distinct interpretation of the theme in our region. \"There are countries where girls have very little access to primary education. That is not our norm so it does not have quite the same resonance. Post-independence our governments have made commitments to universal primary education. In most territories there is universal access to secondary education and there is tertiary access in three countries. Over the last 40 to 50 years Caribbean girls and women have taken this seriously. Sometimes the stats are quite stunning,\" Clarke acknowledges. \"Upwards of 70 percent of UWI entrants and graduates are women.\" But while many focus on girls' achievement, it remains true that too many girls and boys continue to under-achieve at the primary and secondary level. \"One of the issues we must address is the quality of the education we receive,\" Clarke pointed out. \"Many girls and boys leave school without certification or without adequate certification. The education sector generally is not achieving the kind of outputs we'd expect from the investments we're making. That's an agenda for women as well as men. In the Caribbean there are some countries where the majority of the workforce is unskilled. The global economy is geared toward skilled jobs and a value-added labour market.\" Clarke stressed that we must also address the role of education in socialising children, enhancing access to employment opportunities and fostering leadership among girls. \"We comprise most of the teachers and girls outstrip boys in academic performance, yet they do not hold down many top positions in the corporate world or in politics,\" Prime Minister Kamla Persad Bissessar acknowledged just over a year ago. There remains a gulf between women's academic attainment and their leadership in the world of work. \"The education sector is important for a number of reasons. Educators are the primary socialisers of children. They can dispense the value systems we want to promote or limit the stereotypes about how men and women and boys should behave. Very often those stereotypes are channeled through schools, family, and the popular media. Restrictive gender norms continue to be perpetuated by the education sector. It is important to change the culture,\" she said. Clarke stressed that the over-arching agenda should be creating innovative, reflective and critical individuals who can participate meaningfully in democracies. And that's an agenda that lasts year-round. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/addressing-deficiencies-in-education-system/article_6eed31bd-4a1b-50e1-abd3-9553d501cf1b.html", "TITLE": " Addressing deficiencies in education system ", "DATE": "Nov 27, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " Part 2 I shall correct an error in my last article. Teachers are entitled to 14 days casual leave (which may be taken during term time) and not 28 as I had stated. I apologise for the misstatement. I had in mind that the 14 days may be taken half day at a time and to take a half day from school is disruptive of the whole day's work especially if it is taken in the morning! I still maintain that the Government should negotiate with the Trinidad and Tobago Unified Teachers' Association (TTUTA) to increase salaries and remove the casual leave. If a teacher has an urgent problem then arrangements should be made by the principal for the class to be supervised in some other way. It should be made illegal for a class in any school at any time to be without the supervision of a teacher since to do otherwise is to short change our children's learning and to place them in physical danger. I shall now discuss the other important issues raised in my last article: school and classroom design and numeracy and literacy. Announcements by the Minister of Education indicate that a number of new schools are to be built particularly to replace existing buildings that can no longer be repaired. Thus there is an opportunity to build schools that allow for modern teaching methods; have facilities for new subjects on the curriculum such as the performing arts; and which have lunchrooms. Some of the structures now used as Primary schools have to be seen to be believed. There are still some schools that consist of one long rectangular room with the \"class rooms\" separated only by chalkboards. The pupils at the end of one class hear the teacher from the adjacent class as well as the teacher from their own class. The Principal of a secondary school on seeing one such arrangement said to me: If you had attended that school you would not have achieved the educational level that you are at today. Even assuming that such schools are the exception how many schools are designed to further modern concepts of education Recently the Education Discussion Group (EDG), in collaboration with the University of the West Indies and the University of Trinidad and Tobago, held a symposium on school and classroom design. A summary report on this symposium is available from the EDG. The symposium was well attended by architects and educators, including officials from the Ministry of Education. A presentation by Mr Gary Turton of the Trinidad and Tobago Institute of Architects on \"Stimulating Learning Environments\" recommended for introductory reading an article in the journal Scientific American entitled: \"How room design affects your work and mood\". I retrieved this article through \"Google\" and again found this interesting reading. Not only the design but the colours in which the room is painted affects work performance. I wonder if such factors are considered in the building of our schools. The external environment (open spaces around the school) and the flow of student traffic into and within the school are also of importance. For example I understand that the Woodbrook Secondary school is to be rebuilt on the same site which is greatly congested. Another aspect of school design to which I call attention at every opportunity is the provision of lunchrooms. Very few of our schools have such facilities and arrangements for \"sit at table\" lunches. All the schools that I have visited in developed countries (or that I have seen in movies or documentaries) have such facilities and eating of lunches in lunch rooms is compulsory. Such arrangements help to teach discipline and etiquette which is now on the curriculum. Modern teaching methods demand suitable architectural arrangements. Government should arrange competitions with million dollar prizes (if we do this for our culture why can we not do it for the most important aspect of our social arrangements-education of our children) for school designs for pre-school, primary and secondary schools. I am convinced that one of the most important issues in our high crime rate is the fact that a significant number of our young males are leaving school being functionary illiterate. This situation leads to gang membership to achieve self-esteem since with such membership the ability to use a firearm is more important than being able to read and deal with any complexity of numbers. I was heartened recently to hear the Commissioner of Police stressing the importance of social factors in crime-fighting. Regrettably I did not hear him discuss schooling. I blame the present state of numeracy and literacy on a well intentioned decision in 2000 to place all children in secondary schools despite poor grades in what was then referred to as the 11-plus examination. Prior to that time such children went into post-primary classes in the primary schools where there was remedial teaching. When the decision was taken to place all children into secondary schools the post- primary classes should have been replaced by remedial classes in the secondary schools. This was not done and so a number of children go through secondary school not being able to read, write or deal with numbers. They are sent to the back of the class so as not to keep back the other pupils. So I place some of the blame for our present high crime rate on that decision. This problem will continue to exist until all primary schools attain high standards. Why do not our universities (we now have four operating at postgraduate level) research the social factors, including education, affecting crime to point the way to an effective long term solution to the crime problem There are many deficiencies in our education system and I have discussed only a few in these two articles. I selected these because they are not usually discussed in spite of the important role they play in our education system. John Spence is professor emeritus, UWI. He also served as an independent senator. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/features/prize-for-woman-who-ran-secret-schools/article_c69f3838-c01c-5257-8fe5-c97727263a7b.html", "TITLE": " Prize for woman who ran secret schools ", "DATE": "Nov 15, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "An Afghan woman who supported underground schools at a time when the Taliban banned education for girls, was awarded the fifth annual WISE prize on Wednesday for taking education to marginalised communities. Sakeena Yacoobi founded the Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) in 1995, providing schooling and healthcare in Afghan refugee camps in Pakistan as well as setting up the secret home schools, which closed down when Taliban rule ended in 2001. Since then the charity has expanded its work, helping 12 million people, many of them girls, in rural and marginalised parts of Afghanistan, according to the World Innovation Summit for Education (WISE). \u201cIt is particularly meaningful because this is such a crucial time in Afghanistan,\u201d said Yacoobi, accepting the prize in Doha, Qatar. \u201cI dedicate the prize to the AIL and all of the women, men and children we are educating.\u201d The Taliban have launched sustained attacks since the withdrawal of most foreign troops late last year, straining the limited resources of Afghan forces. Many districts across the country are now fully or partly under Taliban control. The US$500,000 education prize awarded by WISE, set up by the Qatar Foundation, recognises individuals or teams who successfully address global educational challenges that can bring real change to communities. US First Lady Michelle Obama also spoke at the conference. \u201cWith this prize, we know that we can continue to educate more and more Afghans, giving them hope and encouraging them to go forward no matter what they are facing,\u201d said Yacoobi. She has also opened private schools under her own name, set up a radio station, and plans to establish a university for women as well as a television network. Last year the prize was won by Ann Cotton, a British entrepreneur who set up Camfed, the Campaign for Female Education, which has helped educate more than one million girls in Africa. Other past winners include Vicky Colbert, a Colombian, Madhav Chavan, an Indian, and Fazle Hasan Abed, from Bangladesh. (Reporting By Joseph D'Urso, editing by Tim Pearce. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/school-mourns-twins-killed-in-crash/article_d819a349-b944-5c7d-bbf5-0e8914fef694.html", "TITLE": " ...School mourns twins killed in crash ", "DATE": "Jun 9, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "ANNOUNCED PLANS: Finance Minister Larry Howai ANNOUNCED PLANS: Finance Minister Larry Howai Twin sisters Khadijah and Khertima Taylor were remembered yesterday by their teachers and friends during a prayer service held at St Joseph's Convent, San Fernando. Their friend, Kafiya Gill, was also remembered as a past pupil at the school. She was a student at the University of the West Indies south campus. The three teenagers were killed in a crash along San Fernando bypass on Sunday morning. Another St Joseph's Convent pupil, Teenisha Garcia, who was in the wrecked vehicle, remains in critical condition at hospital. The four girls were among six persons returning from a birthday party at a nightclub in San Fernando. The driver, Anthony Balkissoon, 20, and passenger Akinton Derrick, 22, were also admitted to hospital. The Taylor sisters, aged 18, were sixth form pupils at the school. St Joseph's Convent principal Dinna Bainey said teachers and pupils held a candlelight vigil in memory of the teens on Sunday night. \"And promptly at 8 a.m. (yesterday) everyone came out and went to the auditorium and we had an assembly. We said Psalms, we had worship, we sang and gave thanks for their lives,\" she said. Bainey said Ministry of Education officials visited the school. \"The school supervisor addressed the school and we also had people from the Ministry of Education support services who provided counselling for the girls.\" Bainey said a trauma specialist also visited the school to speak with pupils writing Caribbean Secondary Examination Certificate (CSEC) and Caribbean Advanced Proficiency Examination (CAPE) examinations. Khertima Taylor studied Economics, Accounts and Sociology, while her sister, Khadijah, pursued Spanish, Sociology and English. Bainey said, \"I am trying to handle it from all corners, making sure that everybody's needs are attended to. This is not a one-off situation, it is not ending today and so the ministry has offered the EAP (employee assistance programme).\" Bainey described the sisters as two beautiful young women who had great plans for their future. \"They were always jovial, very close to their mother and to members of staff, they were excellent leaders and they were active in the house system, so this didn't only affect sixth formers. It affected the lower school and all the children who look up to sixth formers for leadership.\" Bainey said Garcia, 19, is also a sixth form pupil studying Biology, Chemistry and Environmental Science. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/experimental-sex-education/article_abcb6039-7c3a-52ff-8070-4864e0aa8c3a.html", "TITLE": " Experimental sex education ", "DATE": "Apr 8, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "The people who have been criticising the single-sex pilot project don't seem to know what an experiment is. My main worry, however, is that the technocrats at the Ministry of Education might not know, either. In considering single-sex schools as a policy which might help improve learning, the Ministry has adopted the right approach: a pilot project. But all the critics have been speaking as though this project is already a policy that will, eventually, be implemented in all schools. On the basis of mistrust of Government, such a reaction is understandable. Too frequently in this regime's tenure, policies have been foisted on the country without consultation and even, as the Prime Minister boasted about his tall buildings, without planning. But, rather than criticising the project itself, which is already underway, it might be more productive if the stakeholders, such as TTUTA and the National Parents Teachers Association and others, ensured that the project is done as a proper experiment. Single-sex initiatives in other countries haven't been conducted with enough rigour so we can state, with reasonable certainty, that this policy improves educational outcomes for boys and girls. Nonetheless, it is a scientific fact that male and female brains function differently, and that these differences are innate rather than, as humanities scholars like to suggest, socialised. This would logically mean that boys and girls require different teaching methods in order to learn effectively. However, human behaviour is too complex for even logical assumptions, so an experiment is the best way to reach a conclusion. Thus we have 20 schools converted from co-educational to single-sex, starting with the incoming cohort. The idea, presumably, is to benchmark the Forms Four and Five, which are still mixed, and then compare their academic performance and socialisation to the Form Ones, who are now single-sex. So the experiment is a five-year one. If this is so, it would mean that baseline data have already been collected on students in all 20 schools. If that is the case, this data should be provided to researchers at UWI, since it must be useful for analyses beyond single-sex schooling. And, if journalists request the baseline overview academic performance, socioeconomic profile, ethnic breakdown, behavioural indicators, and so on it will be readily available. And if the Ministry has measured staff ratios, equipment supplies, infrastructural quality, and so on, these will be kept constant over the five-year period, since any change in these variables would confound the factor they're trying to test: single-sex classes. And, yes, I wrote this paragraph on the basis that \"if\" is the biggest small word in the English language. Anyway, these are the criteria which are needed for a proper pilot project, although it would still be a more effective experiment if a single-sex high performing government school, such as St Francois Girls College, was converted to co-education, so as to provide a control. But I won't quibble too much, because experiments of any sort are very rare in education, and not just in Trinidad and Tobago. You would think, given the importance everyone places on education, it would be the leading area for research in the social sciences. In fact, the opposite is true. The Express used to carry a regular column by various lecturers from UWI's School of Education, and I guarantee that 99 per cent of the pedagogy in those articles was not based on any scientific research. Instead, there are whole bodies of \"theory\" dreamed up by various academics, which has never been subject to any testing to see if they actually work in the classroom. Thus, in the teaching courses at UWI and the University of Trinidad and Tobago, the ideas of Jean Piaget, John Dewey, Lawrence Kohlberg, Jerome Bruner, and even BF Skinner are promulgated as if they are correct. These scholars offered certain theories about how children's minds work, which have led to pedagogical practices such as look-say reading and socialisation through authority. However, research by cognitive and child psychologists has proven that the intellectual and moral developmental stages identified by Piaget and Kohlberg, as well as the models of learning created by Dewey and Bruner, are flawed. This means that teaching techniques built on these ideas start from wrong premises. Siegfried Engelmann, inventor of the Direct Instruction teaching method, in his book War Against the Schools' Academic Child Abuse describes education research as follows: \"They conduct a study in which nothing is taught. Instead, they 'study' something about the kids' behaviour. They then suggest teaching techniques based on what the kids do. This kind of 'study' gives no indication of what caused the kids' behaviour in the first place.\" Yet it is these theories which are more accurately described as philosophies or even ideologies which inform education policy in many countries. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/an-education-lesson-from-england/article_36d6f463-10dc-5ea0-8540-ed6462a4b2f4.html", "TITLE": " An education lesson from England ", "DATE": "Jan 3, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "LEADER OF THE DARK HORSES: Windwards skipper Darren Sammy LEADER OF THE DARK HORSES: Windwards skipper Darren Sammy There are many legacies we have inherited from England, not least of which is our state subsidised education system. It may therefore be appropriate to pay attention to educational issues in the United Kingdom as these may contain important lessons for us. Over the recent past the UK has expanded university education by the creation of a large number of new universities. At the same time there seems to have been very significant grade inflation among A-level students. In last year's exams, 27 per cent of all A-levels taken resulted in a grade A and 95 per cent of students passed at least two A-Levels. Thirty two per cent of those from private schools receive three grade A passes which was higher than the 11 per cent from state schools who received three A grades. There is much debate as to whether the high percentage of passes and \"A'' grades has resulted from a reduction in the difficulty of exams or simply because children are better prepared. Whatever the reason the number of students attending university has increased (now 45 per cent of all school leavers go to university) and it is becoming more difficult for the universities to differentiate between the excellent students and the merely average students. One consequence has been the introduction of an A grade to help identify the best students. The most significant development, however, has been the consequence of the unsustainable budget deficit on the financing of tertiary education. For many years UK students have been heavily subsidised in their tertiary education. The maximum charge to local students for fees was approximately TT$32,900 per annum. The state then pays the university directly a further TT$80,000 subsidy for tuition. By contrast, overseas students are charged the full cost which averages approximately TT$140,000 per annum (fees vary according to the course and university). In some respects therefore the overseas students help finance the deficit at the universities by paying more than local students even after consideration of the government subsidy. The UK government recently announced that the subsidies would be cut very significantly. Students will now be expected to pay TT$90,000, almost triple what they paid in prior periods. There is also a further debate about alternative funding through scholarships and student loans. As a direct result of this revised policy there were large student demonstrations in London, some of which became violent. Readers may recall that Prince Charles and Duchess Camilla were subjected to an attack in which a window of their car was broken. This very un-British behaviour has resulted from the strong feelings arising from some significant hardship for existing students. Clearly the tertiary education system is now under pressure because its cost has become unsustainable. Not only can the UK no longer afford the existing subsidies but there also appears to be a shortage of jobs for the new graduates. It is possible the massive increase in fees will result in a declining demand for university places among local students. The universities may turn to overseas students to expand their intake to survive the revenue cuts. The important lesson, I believe, is to understand the importance of planned sustainable development in tertiary education that will not require any sudden cutbacks and is supported by effective demand rather than government subsidy. Most would agree that education is the fundamental building block for the development of society and should avoid any unexpected contraction. In recent years in Trinidad and Tobago we also have engaged in a very significant expansion of tertiary education through UWI, the new University of Trinidad and Tobago, expanded scholarships, COSTAATT and GATE funded private colleges. It is very important that this expansion maintains the existing standards of education. There are risks that some university entrants may not be fully prepared for tertiary education and the standards fall as a result. There is also the risk of \"grade inflation'' if the quality is not maintained. There is the further risk that the education provided may not match the employment needs of society, which means there will be no suitable jobs for the new graduates. And there is the further risk that if we expand subsidies too swiftly the costs will become unsustainable and lead to unplanned cutbacks. Subsidies should be carefully aimed towards the focused needs of society and balanced with the ability of those graduating from secondary schools. There is little point providing university places that cannot be filled with the appropriate quality of student, nor is there any point offering scholarships for PhDs in obscure subjects where we do not have a demand for these PhDs. It is also important that primary and secondary education provide students of appropriate quality to fill the expanded tertiary education places. In a developing country the sustainability and quality of education are of paramount importance. It is to be hoped that this development will be part of a well balanced plan and we can learn to avoid the mistakes which have become apparent in the UK. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/how-children-define-race-and-identity/article_49bcc0c4-6a1e-50ea-b3cc-cbc0552d4f3b.html", "TITLE": " How children define race and identity ", "DATE": "Jul 14, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " Put on your old school uniform and your \"washikongs\" and re-enter primary school. There is a brown girl in the ring, tra la la la laDoes skin colour affect how you view yourself and your peers Come back now to the present day and ask yourself how do your children see themselves in a multiracial and cosmopolitan society As parents do we discuss racial identities and attitudes with our children Kerry-Ann Escayg, a PhD candidate in the Department of Sociology and Equity Studies at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, University of Toronto, asks and answers this question and more through her research topic: The role of parents and teachers in pre-school -Trinidadian childrens racial identities and attitudes. Salient findings from pioneering studies on race and young children, such as those by Clark and Clark (1939), suggest that between the ages of three and five, children become increasingly aware of their racial identities and develop both positive and negative attitudes toward racial groups, including their own. Contemporary research (2001; Gopaul-McNichol, 1995) also confirms that black children continue to display racial preferences toward white/light skin tones, states Escayg who is also an Ontario certified Kindergarten-Grade 6, teacher. She further argues- Very little attention has been paid to the process of racialisation of Caribbean children; more specifically, how parents and teachers influence childrens construction and application of racial knowledge. My study addresses these gaps using an anti-colonial and anti-racism lens to deconstruct the nuanced understandings of race in the Trinidadian context, and its transmission to pre-school children. Escayg, a graduate of St Francois Girls' College, Belmont, has published scholarly articles in peer-reviewed journals on the topics of equity, race and teacher diversity. Her most recent contribution is a co-authored chapter on Afrocentric teaching in the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education-\"Inquiry into Practice: Reaching Every Student Through Inclusive Curriculum. Formerly a resident of Chaguanas, she also has an extensive list of presentations at peer-reviewed scholarly meetings, including this year's presentation on \"Children and Race in the Caribbean Diaspora\" at the annual Caribbean Studies Association Conference. Concomitant to her active involvement in and commitment to anti-racism scholarship and practice, she was recently invited to serve as a guest panelist at York Universitys Race Seminar Speaker Series, and to participate in the Centre for Integrative Anti-Racism Studies at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, University of Toronto, Speaker Series, on race and racism beyond the Canadian social context. Her repertoire of elite qualifications and major strides in the academic world at age 28 may be mind-boggling to many, but a peek into the findings of her research is even more amazing. Her preliminary findings suggest that not only are pre-school Trinidadian children aware of racial differences, such as skin colour and hair texture, they also accord positive characteristics to two racial groups-East Indian and mixed. \"The former is considered as being smart, and the latter as being more physically attractive, Escayg said While it is quite evident that children at this age have not fully developed an understanding of racial group membership/categories (for example, Indian, negro, mixed, white), they did demonstrate an ability to isolate phenetoypical characteristics, such as skin colour, as a prominent signifier of difference, says Escayg. According to Escayg, the participants in her study were Indo-Trinidadian, Afro-Trinidadian, and children of mixed race. A compelling phenomenon which was revealed in the racial identity interview session was that the mixed children and Afro-Trinidadian children, accurately identified with their racial background, whereas the Indian children (female participants) identified with white and mixed children. Equally relevant was the fact that the majority of parents in the study indicated that while they believe it was important to discuss race with their child, they were unsure as to whether this discussion should begin at the pre-school age. Some participants also mentioned that if they were to discuss race with their child, it may solidify, and not challenge, their misconceptions. When asked how they will cultivate a positive racial identity in their child, only a few parents felt confident in their ability to do so. In fact, one parent (Afro-Trinidadian) responded to this question by proudly declaring: I will tell her,..you see this traffic light, a black man created it, the elevatorwe made that too, declared Esacgy who incidently is also a recipient of the Gordon Cressy Student Leadership Award. Another interesting revelation from interviews conducted was that teachers confessed to experiences with children using racial slurs, and displaying preference for children of lighter skin tones, and softer hair texture but due to limited exposure to anti-racism training, which engenders more inclusive and anti-racism classroom spaces, they couldnt effectively manage the situation. I believe that in order to move towards an early childhood education that is empowering and inclusive, we must first acknowledge how young children are affected by the social structure, particularly in relation to the construction and application of their racial knowledge; and subvert these with teaching practices that do not reinforce or reproduce a hierarchy of identities, knowledges and lived experiences, suggests Escayg. Another caveat pertinent to the discourse is the difference in which racial groups perceive race relations in Trinidad. When quizzed, Afro-Trinidadian and mixed parents affirmed that there is still a race issue in Trinidad, and even provided personal examples to illustrate. The views of East Indian participants however, were varied, and somewhat less personal, she explained.. Escayg said that on closer analysis, the microscope was placed on the local education system- Why is the process of racialisation different for African-Trinidadian, mixed and Indian children Why is there such a reticence to discuss race with children, even though parents are aware that there are still racial divisions and spurious racial ideologies that marginalise children from particular racial groups And finally, how is the education system responding to promoting positive racial identities in children across the various age levels Much of the findings are consistent with previous literature on young children and race, particularly in relation to preference of lighter skin tones and (softer) hair texture. A point of departure in my work however, is the centrality of both environmental (parents and teachers) and systemic factors. I contend that if we are to disabuse our childrens minds of such inimical racial ideologies, then the pre-school period is indeed the incipient stage of this revolutionary process. It is a stage where we can begin to unravel the multiple layers of false consciousness, which is too often reproduced and reworked to their own detriment, avows the anti-colonial scholar. A born-again Christian, she believes her firm faith in God has inspired her work and that her findings will contribute to the fabric of a more stable society. To conclude, Escayg makes it clear that her mission is sincere as she cites her goals Once sponsors for a venue and time permit, I would like to offer free seminars for parents, teachers and the general public on the topic of children and race. It is time we work to decolonise our minds, and our children's minds, if we are to transgress the current social order. We owe it to our nations children. They are all worth the effort. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-life-in-education/article_00562c29-dc8d-5a08-96d5-70bbeb91a71f.html", "TITLE": " A Life in Education ", "DATE": "Apr 25, 2013 ", "CONTENT": " Teacher and author, Edlin Rochford, is one of a kind. A woman with a strong will, and a zest for education that was developed during her childhood. It is the combination of these two qualities that have enabled Rochford to rise above her humble beginnings and attain her present status of educator and author. But what is most striking about Rochford is the fact that, in spite of her now many major accomplishments, she has not forgotten where she has come from and does her best to impart her strong determination and fervour for education unto others, mainly her students. Rochford was born in a place called Caigual, a place all the way behind Gods back as the common parlance goes here. And that is not just my perspective on her home village. I was born in a little village outside of Sangre Grande called Caigual. The only one who might know that village is the local writer, Anthony Michael, quipped Rochford. But while her early childhood was spent in Caigual, the balance of her youth was lived out in Diego Martin, where her parents moved there with her, and her six siblings. So when Diego Martin Junior Secondary was established in 1972, Rochford became a pupil there. I am a junior secondary product, a good product, she noted. But it is questionable that Rochford would have been a good product without the encouragement and support of both her parents. My parents didnt go to secondary school. They had seven kids, all of them, save for one, went to university. There is even one doctor in the family. My parents were sticklers for education. My mother would be cooking and shed have us around the table doing work. We got our books as soon as school went on break. Shed have us reading until school re-opened. Rochford, therefore, learned very early the value and importance of education. It is no surprise, therefore, that Rochford has found herself smack dab in the academic arena doing her best to impart the value of learning onto her pupils, in the same way that her parents have imparted the value of learning onto her. She had started off as an ECCE teacher and from there, moved on to preparatory school and then on to primary school. Maraval Primary School was my only primary school, she stated. Jehue Gordon is my claim to fame at the primary school level. Moreover, that Rochford was doing a good job imparting her love of learning onto her students became evident at Maraval Primary, where she had nine pupils, including Jehue, pass for Belmont Secondary School and a few others for St Francois Girls College. She taught the SEA class. In 2006, after teaching for sometime at St Anthonys College, she ended up at Bishops Anstey High School, Port-of-Spain, as a Communication Studies teacher. And in 2012, she made waves in the academic world when, in her class of 28 pupils, all 28 received one's with 21 distinctions in the CAPE May/June 2012 exam in Communication Studies. I kept telling them that I am going to be there for you. We are a class with a vision on a mission to succeed. I love to motivate my studentsOn the day of the exam, I meet my girls and I tell them, hear my voice telling you what a medium is I love to put things on my walls to motivate them. I give them love notes, Rochford stated as she explained the techniques she utilises in her classrooms to help her pupils succeed. Love notes are little letters containing positive and edifying statements to help her pupils stay on track. I should add here that the aforementioned class was considered an underperforming class given that they were the C classes (classes are divided alphabetically at Bishops Anstey High: A, B and C, with C being the least advanced students) and was comprised of mainly science students (at least when they had moved into Lower 6; also, those in the academic world, English and Literature teachers to be exact, know that Science and Math students tend not to write very well and so pose a challenge to their language teachers). But Rochford is a good motivator. Her 2012 class would have also benefitted from the fact that Rochford is a table leader at CXC. Such a position allows her to talk to other teachers in the field and see what students are writing. She is also able to see what CXC and CAPE expect from students. Her present classes also enjoy that benefit. Rochford is now at Holy Faith Convent where she teaches both Communication Studies and Caribbean Studies. However Because of a recent move to Couva, she has transferred there. She confessed that her pupils at Bishop Anstey High miss her. Nonetheless, she maintains contact with them. I have no childrenAll my students are my children, she told me. Indeed, she treats them as such. Rochford is the author of Communication Studies: Preparing Students for Cape. She is married to Phillip Rochford, whom she describes as her motivational coach. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/expert-school-bullying-leading-to-serious-crimes/article_e24e0422-e109-53ca-9053-24d6fac74982.html", "TITLE": " Expert: School bullying leading to serious crimes ", "DATE": "Apr 18, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "BULLYING in Trinidad and Tobago is deteriorating fast and furious and is morphing into serious offences, warns Dr Diane Williams of the Criminology Unit of the Department of Behavioural Sciences at the University of the West Indies. In a study conducted in 2007 among 32 primary and secondary schools, Williams noted that 26.6 per cent of males reported being bullied while more than seven per cent of females said they were victims of physical bullying. Although there are no current statistics to indicate the prevalence of bullying in schools today, Williams told the Express that news reports and anecdotal evidence suggest that the issue of bullying has rapidly worsened. At a workshop held last Thursday afternoon at the Department of Social Sciences addressing the issue of bullying, domestic violence and rape, Williams spoke at length about bullying in the workplace and at school. Victims of bullying suffer with negative feelings, low self esteem and may resort to suicide or murder. Williams noted that there are not enough safeguards in schools to protect children against bullies and emphasised the role the Ministry of Education plays in curbing the problem. \"Educators need to recognise the potential for bullyingas soon as it is identified the next step is dealing with it. All educators must also be sensitised and each school must have specialised counselors to deal with this issue. There also must be ramifications if teachers knowingly turn a blind eye to bullying,\" said Williams. Legislation to fight bullying must be put in place, noted Williams. Standard policies and procedures to deal with the problem, stringent punishment for those engaging in bullying and mandatory training for teachers along with specialised counsellors in schools is necessary to combat the growing problem. Guest speaker Diana Mahabir-Wyatt later told the media that legislation to deal with bullying is needed. \"You have to be very clear to define what bullying is and not only bullying of children with other children, but bullying of teachers to children and bullying of people within the school system to children because it's an extremely complex subject and once you have defined what bullying is and say it's against the law, then you've got to develop appropriate measures to deal with it,\" said Mahabir-Wyatt. She added, \"It's going to be very, very difficult, but if we are going to deal with the violence in society, we've got to start with schools.\" TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/issues-in-primary-and-tertiary-education/article_349f6a28-93f3-568b-abbe-3cd90522ce2d.html", "TITLE": " Issues in primary and tertiary education ", "DATE": "Jul 6, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " The new Minister of Education seems to be starting out on the right track to have highlighted the problem at the lower end of the SEA passes. He states that some 2,000 pupils obtained below 30 per cent in that examination. The news media continue to rave over the performance at the top end (pupils obtaining over 95 per cent); as a society our concern must be for the 2,000 pupils whom the system has failed. I would be interested to know how many pupils would be expected to get below 30 per cent if they all had the environment (parenting, schooling, level of income and so on) that those above 95 per cent had. In order to judge just how well or badly our pupils are performing at both ends of the scale one would need to know a lot more about the system of examination. For example, I am surprised that over 150 candidates would get over 95 per cent in an examination (other than one in mathematics alone). In the United Kingdom there is concern of the standards in the Advanced Level examination and there is talk of \"dumbing down\"lowering of the standards. What does scoring over 95 per cent or below 30 per cent in the SEA mean How many of the pupils who score below 30 per cent can neither read nor write What percentage of those pupils writing the examination obtained between 50 per cent and 40 per cent, 40 per cent and 30 per cent and so on down to between 10 per cent and 0 per cent It would be interesting to compare the SEA results with those of the National Test since I believe these latter carry international standards. The fact is that to be able to pinpoint the problem one may need to undertake a great deal of research; the Ministry of Education does not have the resources or the environment to conduct such research and so the universities must be funded to undertake this vital task. As an aside, the appointment of Ms St Rose-Greaves in the Prime Minister's office as Advocate for children is of extreme importance. It is my hope that she will be able to lobby successfully to have some of these problems researched. I must express my surprise and disappointment that a commentator in last Sunday's Express newspaper criticised the appointment of Ms St Rose-Greaves, apparently on the grounds that contract appointments in general were open to abuse. In my article in the Express of June 3, I had suggested the appointment of Ms St Rose-Greaves in the Prime Minister's office where she would be in a position to hasten the establishment of a permanent Advocate for Children and the Children's Authority which I am confident she will do. I shall now discuss some issues with tertiary education. In my article in the Express of July 1, I had suggested that consideration should be given for tertiary education to be reunited with the Ministry of Education as is the case in many countries and had been the case in this country until the creation of a Ministry of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education. Does the present arrangement imply that tertiary education is only about science and technology However, perhaps the problems with primary and secondary education should be dealt with successfully before tertiary education is rejoined with them. In my Express article of June 11 I wrote: \"What is urgently needed is a body to oversee UWI and UTT and a university council should be created such as exists in Jamaica.\" I have since discovered that the University Council of Jamaica is in reality an accreditation council similar to the Accreditation Council that already exists in this country. I have also discovered that in this country there is a Green Paper on the website of the Ministry of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education dated October 2009 but with a foreword signed by the new Minister, Senator Fazal Karim. This Green Paper is entitled: \"Policy on Tertiary Education, Technical-Vocational Education and Training, and Lifelong Learning in Trinidad and Tobago\". There are some curious aspects to this development. Evidently this Green Paper has been adopted wholesale by the new Government, including the 2020 vision which the Paper uses as its starting point. In view of this I must register my disagreement, as I have done on many occasions during the time of the last PNM government, to the people of this country having as an objective that they shall be \"fun loving\". While pleasure and happiness are important aspects of our well being to have \"fun loving\" as an objective in an important statement on our aims and objectives for development in my view sends the wrong message to our young people. This Green Paper also proposes some developments that I have not seen in the People's Partnership Manifesto. The Green Paper states: \"It is envisioned that the governance of the system will be facilitated by a single National Education Commission comprising separate but interlinked Councils to deal with all levels of education including TVET (Technical and Vocational Education and Training)\". The Councils to be created are: Council for Tertiary Education and Training; Technical-Vocational Education and Training Council; and a National Council of Science, Technology and Innovation. The People's Partnership Manifesto proposes under Tertiary Education that: \"A National Commission for Higher Education will guide the sector and we will work with Caricom and other governments of the region, as well as the Association of Tertiary Institutions to establish a Regional Qualifications Framework and to strengthen quality in a diverse system across the world.\" This is quite a different concept from that proposed in the Green Paper and if all of these proposals were to be adopted there would be \"overload\" in the system! The Green Paper was prepared apparently for the previous government by technocrats who no doubt did an excellent job. However, when will political parties develop their own policies based on their political philosophy which could be discussed subsequently by technocrats It might have been wiser for the People's Partnership Government to tread more slowly and to develop and articulate its own philosophy and programme for the governance of the education system. I have been invited to a consultation on the Green Paper and so shall reserve further comment until after those discussions. Prof John Spence is a retired UWI lecturer. Leela Ramdeen On Thursday January 24, the world will observe the first UN International Day of Education. The right to education is enshrined in a number of documents, particularly in article 26 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and in The Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Sustainable Development Goal 4 aims, by 2030, to \u201censure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all\u2026about 265 million children and adolescents around the world do not have the opportunity to enter or complete school. More than a fifth of them are of primary school age. They are thwarted by poverty, discrimination, armed conflict, emergencies and the effects of climate change. Migration and forcible displacement also affect the achievement of the education goals\u201d (UN). IN yet another incident which has had the effect of piling \u00adembarrassment upon embarrassment for the authorities, a convict walked out of the Golden Grove facility in Arouca on Thursday, and was on the run up to last night. THE West Indies has had a phenomenal number of exceptional cricketers in its history. The captains have been mostly \u00admiddling. I restricted the playbooks to those of Frank Worrell, Richie Benaud and Mike Brearley simply because they were known as thinking men; able in both the technical and \u201cman-management\u201d aspects of the game.
