{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/seeking-education-sea-change/article_6a0ec7df-a862-53a3-a7bb-ff739589a985.html", "TITLE": " Seeking education SEA change ", "DATE": "Jul 24, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "The results of the 2015 Secondary Entrance Assessment (SEA) examination once again have produced as much dissatisfaction, distress and disappointment as celebration. For while we celebrate those who have \u201cdone well\u201d there are many who receive the outcome as anything but a cause clbre. And we can expect the same when the CXC results are released. Universal education should mean that students no longer have to compete for school places since there is adequate provision for all children at all levels. It is now possible to have seamless transitions from ECCE through to secondary level. Why then do we persist with the unnecessary anxiety-producing SEA exam Universal access to schooling is based on the principles of equity and social justice. Thus we are challenged to revisit policies and practices to ensure that they are equitable and just. It means therefore, that those policies and practices that have entrenched inequality and sustained inequity in our education system must go. The SEA exam is one such practice. Why the SEA continues to be part of the educational landscape Perhaps it is the easier option for the principal stakeholders, namely the Government, the schools and the parents! They know that it is not just a matter of waving a magic wand. Doing away with the exam means that we have to find new ways to manage the transition to secondary school. Removal of the SEA should involve deliberations on the broader issues of the effectiveness of schooling and of the inefficiencies and wastage in the system. This is not beyond our capability; neither do we need another multi-million dollar World Bank or IDB project. The removal of the SEA exam presents us with a unique opportunity to engage in a comprehensive re-culturing of the education system. This must include rethinking and restructuring some of the organisational aspects of the school system. It also requires that we anticipate changes in policies and practices. The aim should be to remove inefficiencies and improve the quality of schooling so as to graduate confident persons who are socially and intellectually competent. The re-culturing process should require all schools to improve the quality of their programmes and the quality of their graduates. Schools however, must be provided with the required support and resources for achieving these goals. Several aspects of schooling directly affect the quality of student outcomes: teachers and the quality of their teaching; school leadership; the level of funding and resourcing to support teaching and learning; and the collaborative support of the home and community. In restructuring the system, we should seek to eliminate differences among schools. Schools at all levels should be well resourced and staffed with high quality teachers and administrators. All schools should be standardised on key factors. Standards are needed for the following: staffing of schools and related administrative functions; funding, equipment, resource materials, and support facilities; buildings and infrastructure; leadership and administration; and teacher, student, and school, performance. Policies should also incorporate accountability measures. Once teacher performance standards are defined and teachers are given adequate support for meeting those standards, teachers should be held accountable for their students' achievements, but within reason, since many factors that affect learning are beyond teacher or school control. Individual schools must be held accountable for the quality of their graduates. Schools should establish proper outreach programmes to build partnerships with parents and communities. The Ministry of Education and its agents should be held accountable for the general outcomes of schools, their quality, physical infrastructure, and resourcing. Most crucial is the need to bring teaching in Trinidad and Tobago into the 21st century. The Ministry of education, because of its public service identity, is increasingly incapable of managing the teaching profession, particularly with regard to the issue of quality assurance. It is unreasonable to expect principals and teachers to behave like professionals while teaching is administered like a public service occupation. The teaching profession must be placed in the hands of the professionals, as is done in other professions; in highly successful education systems; and as directed by the Caricom education ministers. The money that is spent on the SEA examination would be better spent on establishing and monitoring standards, resourcing schools adequately, providing teachers with adequate compensation and working conditions; and timely maintenance and repair of equipment and buildings. Most prudent, however, would be channelling this money into a programme for teachers' and administrators' continuing professional development so as to motivate and encourage them to strive for and maintain excellence. This is the ultimate challenge of Universal Education: to have high quality teachers in all classrooms and high quality administrators in all schools so that all children can benefit optimally from their schooling. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/church-schools-must-do-more/article_b89fe98b-451c-5490-8fde-542b6b9a1789.html", "TITLE": " Church schools must do more ", "DATE": "Dec 13, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Revisiting the Concordat on Education Part II I ended my last article with a reference to Clause Five of the Concordat the main points of which are summarised below: The then (1960) existing relationship between the government and the governing bodies and teachers in assisted secondary schools was to remain, but a system of inspection of these schools by persons authorised to do so by the Ministry of Education would be put in place. The governing bodies of these schools would continue to be responsible for the administration, maintenance, repair and furnishing of the schools. These schools will continue to qualify for government aid and the principals would make available a minimum of 80 per cent of places for government allocation. The principals would be free to allocate 20 per cent of the remaining places, as they see fit, all these students to be taken from those \"passing the test\". Thus the Government is responsible for selecting only 80 per cent of pupils allocated to individual schools. There is reference in this Clause to students \"passing the test\" but this is no longer relevant as secondary school places are now provided for all. The Concordat does not prevent government from using any method for allocating students to schools. The system of admission now used is by order of merit in the \"test\" (Secondary Education Assessment SEA) modified by parents' choice. I have written a series of five articles in the Express (December 2005 to January 2006 ) entitled \"Education and social equity\" in which I suggested that this system is unfair to persons of low income, perpetuates class divisions and mitigates against social mobility of children of lower income groups. Some of our primary schools are substandard, badly designed and are in a state of disrepair. Many teachers at primary school level will continue to have inadequate qualifications until the policy of recruiting only teachers with university qualifications has been in effect for many years and all under-qualified teachers have retired. Parents who have the financial and other resources are able either to use private (fee-paying) primary schools or are able to make up for deficiencies in the school system by the home environment, paying for extra lessons and so on. I now discuss the remaining clauses. Clause Six deals with removal of pupils from school (for disciplinary reasons or unsatisfactory progress); the principal may suspend a pupil pending an investigation but the authority to expel a pupil is vested solely in the Cabinet. It is not stated who shall carry out the investigation but presumably this is to be conducted by the Ministry of Education. Clause 7 states \"All new Central schools may be established only by Government for the simple reason that these schools are to be fed from the primary schools of all denominations, as well as Government Schools which may be in the area served by the central school. Where, however, the need arises for converting an existing denominational school into a secondary school, the denominational character of the school will be allowed to remain.\" This clause has been used by the Government to prohibit denominations from building any new schools except with State permission. Clause 8 states: \"The selection of teachers for training at the Teachers' College is to remain solely with the Ministry of Education and Culture. Selection of teachers for training in the existing denominational training colleges (as far as I am aware these no longer exist) may be made by the denominational boards: but such selection must be approved by the Ministry of Education and Culture.\" Such training was often carried out after the teacher had joined the teaching service (in-service training). The Teachers' colleges are now a part of the University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT) which offers a degree in Education. The policy now to be pursued by the Government (which I fully support) is for all teachers to undergo pre-service training. UWI at St Augustine, after many years of offering only an in-service training post-graduate diploma in Education is now launching a pre-service programme. Clause 9 states that training of teachers should be at the Teachers' College under government supervision. The denominational training colleges existing at that time were to continue in existence but not to be expanded. Government-operated teacher training colleges are being transferred to UTT. Teacher education will thus now be offered at three universities UWI, UTT and the University of the Southern Caribbean. In the 51 years since the Concordat was agreed to, there have been major changes in the education system and some of the provisions are no longer relevant. Further the way in which the system has developed has resulted in a streaming of better performing primary school students into so-called prestige schools, mainly denominational, based on an academic examination (SEA) in which pupils from low income families are at a distinct disadvantage. The result is that instead of the religious denominations helping the disadvantaged in society they are catering in the main for the pupils of families who can afford a better primary school preparation for the SEA. The main basis of our judgment that denominational schools perform better is the number of scholarships won by the school which may not reflect the \"value added\" (the performance of pupils at \"O\" level or CXC in relation to their performance at SEA) to the majority of students in the school. We must ensure that Government schools are brought up to the best level. In the meanwhile to move towards greater social equity, the denominational schools should be allocated at least 50 per cent of candidates from the lower end of the SEA pass list and such students must be given special attention. I am basing this proposal on the fact that religious denominations are concerned with the good of society as a whole and in particular with helping the disadvantaged and so I would expect this proposal to have full support of the denominations. To be continued John Spence is professor emeritus, UWI. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/in-education-oh-the-shame-of-it/article_78c03cd1-978c-561f-9fc1-eda5f6c53fb5.html", "TITLE": " In education Oh, the shame of it! ", "DATE": "Jan 1, 2013 ", "CONTENT": " I am ashamed that after 50 years of independence and 60 years of the existence of the University of the West Indies (UWI), this country is going to a little known Canadian university for \"Developing, Revising and Implementing Primary Curriculum\" and to conduct a \"Baseline Survey of Teacher Performance, Parent and Student Attitude and Achievement\". Oh, the shame of it. The University is Mount St Vincent (UMSV). This is the second contract given to this university and I shall quote from an article I wrote in the Express, April 10, 2003: \"The contract to develop the curriculum for technology studies has been given to an obscure Canadian university (Mount St Vincent University). This university is listed as number 40 in an assessment of 60 Canadian universities and its web-site indicates that it does not have any faculties dealing with technology. There are no faculties of engineering or agriculture and the science programme does not appear to offer degrees in chemistry or physics. Yet Mount St Vincent was favoured over UWI for the award of the contract to develop the curriculum for technology education in this country! Surely such a syllabus needs to be developed indigenously rather than by foreigners from an alien environment. Using a foreign university will ensure that the materials needed by the schools to teach the subject will have to be imported.'' \"Mt St Vincent University has also been given the contract for the training of the teachers in technology education. This should be closely monitored.\" \"The recommendations of the Ministry of Education to the Central Tenders Board for the award of this contract comparing UWI and Mt St Vincent need to be fully exposed.\" \"Ironically UWI has done important work in the Caribbean in technology education and has produced extensive curriculum material in this subject that is being adopted by Caricom countries-except Trinidad and Tobago! In any event we should take every opportunity to build up our tertiary-level institutions by involving them in activities of this kind (even if this means foregoing loans from multinational agencies)\". I shall give two examples taken from the technology syllabus document which is the revised draft of the Secondary School curriculumForm 2technology education. The document states that \"Dr Robert Sargeant, international consultant, guided the curriculum design and development process. The examples given below are extracted from the biotechnology section of the technology syllabus. Example 1: Sensitisation of students to genetic engineering in plants and small livestock. Year II Term II 2. Design a procedure for gene manipulation e.g., budding in roses, mating in rabbits. I am certain that my readers will know that budding in plants does not in any way involve manipulation of genes or any form of genetic engineering. Example 2: Course outline Biotechnology Year I Term ISuggested activity-micro organisms- 2. Perform technological process (fermentation) to convert raw material (fruit, sugar, flour, yeast) or (other) resources into useful products: wine, bread, vaccines and antibiotics. Production of vaccines in schools By fermentation Dr Robert Sargeant is the lead consultant in the two new contracts to be undertaken by UMSV. At the time of the publication of this draft a colleague and I were interviewed by the then minister of education and we brought the errors in the syllabus to her attention. The minister, I believe, referred the document to the University of the West Indies but I never heard if any corrections were made. Since the present loan, I am informed, is from the Inter-American Development Bank the item must be advertised internationally. Was it advertised locally If we can build a $7 billion highway without borrowing from IADB why can we not do the same for the few millions needed for the education contract It is vital that a school syllabus be developed in relation to local mores. This is particularly important at the primary school level. Otherwise we could go wrong in the education of our children for generations to come. Last year (2012) UMSV was ranked by Macleans in the category of universities that are mainly undergraduate, as number 17 out of 19 Canadian universities. There are two important reports available on the secondary school curricula produced by the previous studies. One was prepared by Prof D Poonwassie of Manitoba University (now retired) a Trinidadian with a distinguished career in Canada, and W Anderson. Prof Poonwassie has recently been honoured by this Government by being one of five Trinidadians who were awarded the Distinguished National of Trinidad and Tobago Canada Award. In a report on these awards (Express October 15, 2012 by Carolyn Kissoon) it stated: \"Poonwassie, professor emeritus, University of Manitoba, is the founding director of two groundbreaking programmes focusing on Aboriginal students. Both projects received National Awards from the Canadian Association for Continuing Education\". The second report was prepared by Dr Edrick Gift who has had a distinguished career in education in T&T having served on the staff of the School of Education at UWI St Augustine and a lecturer at a teachers' training college. Both of these reports are of extreme importance but seem to have been down played. I shall quote from one of the conclusions of the Gift report (on the Secondary Education Modernisation Programme (SEMP), Curricula in Technology Education, Science and Social Studies) which goes to the heart of the issue: \"The three curricula did not draw sufficiently from the culture, environment, and realities of Trinidad and Tobago.\" How do we correct this situation Presumably we cannot get out of the contract with UMSV. Government will have to commission UWI to conduct a parallel study to produce the Primary Education curricula. Is this a waste of money I think not in view of the importance of getting our education on the right footing. I wish all citizens a peaceful and successful New Year. John Spence is professor emeritus, UWI. He also served as an independent senator. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/crime-cure-try-education/article_21207ae4-3bee-5657-a2f1-2c84389d08e3.html", "TITLE": " Crime cure Try education ", "DATE": "Dec 30, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "In a recent article about President Anthony Carmona by Express Political Editor Ria Taitt, it was noted that President Carmona addressed the issue of crime in his inaugural address on March 18. He suggested that \"laws dealing with parental responsibility must be considered to ensure that the child does not become a criminal because of the recalcitrant parent\". An excellent suggestion indeed, except for the details in identifying the \"recalcitrant parent\" and as to what exactly constitutes any such parent. As I point out when I write and lecture about early childhood education (ECE), from age three to five, and what I choose to call early, early childhood education (EECE), from birth to age three, Parents cannot give to children what they themselves lack. How can anyone expect a parent or, if a child is fortunate, two parents, who have never themselves been properly parented to raise and parent a child Can society really label such parent(s) as \"recalcitrant We have many instances of what can only be considered children having children; do they have the parenting skills not to be labelled \"recalcitrant\" Also consider that according to the study done by ALTA that found that only about 45 per cent of adults can read this newspaper with some depth of understanding and that approximately 23 per cent of T&T citizens are illiterate. Can we logically categorise such parents as \"recalcitrant\" If a child has not learned behavioural skills, self-control skills as well as others such as language skills by the age of five, it is most often too late. Consider also that in a well-documented New Zealand study, 24 per cent of the study cohort that had not acquired self-control by age three had, by age 30, acquired criminal records. So, by the time such a child enters the school system, he is too often unreachable and so too late for the semblance of an educational process to give him any chance of being a successful adult. What chance does this child have of himself not becoming a \"recalcitrant parent\" By age five, formal schooling starts and all children are thrown together; low socioeconomic children rapidly learn they can't compete. Resentment sets in, behavioural problems arise, fights are common and the drop-out problem arises. For children like this, are you not surprised that without the development of any skills that crime is too often the default career choice As has been proven in numerous studies of early childhood programmes, the path to these children and their parents is well-proven. It has been shown that the way to reach these children and parents is by sending teams of education specialists, psychologists, social workers, language specialists etc. into the Homes of such children to teach the child and the parent(s) what is necessary for the child to thrive and succeed. Only then will society be able to produce parents who have a chance to give children the tools to not become \"recalcitrant parent(s)\" themselves. The Government has over the past few years spent large sums of money and instituted many programmes to better educate children in an attempt to produce better citizens. We had a few years ago the spending of large sums of money to build early childhood learning centres throughout the country. The problem was soon discovered that there was no trained cadre of teachers and specialists to staff these buildings. So the Ministry of Education established an Early Childhood Care and Education (ECCE) programme at UTT to train such a cadre. But the teachers placed in the positions created are grossly underpaid. These are the most demanding of all teaching jobs and in order to attract quality student applicants, adequate pay scales have to be established. Teaching algebra is a worthy skill but nothing like the many skills needed to teach small children. For another example, the Government funded the hiring of 500 guidance officers and counsellors to combat school dysfunctional behaviour problems and planned a facility in Tobago to house a counselling clinic which would have educational, behavioural and clinical psychologists available on a daily basis. Both these programmes would have been unnecessary if these funds were put into ECE and EECE programmes. The private sector, with its specialised NGOs, has a role to play in helping to alleviate the problem. For example, the Cotton Tree Foundation (CTF) has a wonderful pre-school programme for low income disadvantaged children in St. Ann's. While they are very successful in helping these children they unfortunately do not have enough funding to form the necessary specialty teams to go into their homes. The CTF deserves more private personal and corporate contributions and also Government funding. Are such ECE and EECE programmes expensive Of course they are. However, it has also been demonstrated that there is a return on investment (ROI) many years later, many times more than the original cost along with the demonstrable added value societal benefit of reduced crime. So what is the problem here Why are these programmes not universal Do we not know what is necessary to produce results Of course we do. Then who should we then pin the label of \"recalcitrant parent\" on; pin it you yourselves. Instead of having yet again listen to the Minister of National Security tell you his plan to reduce crime, instead of spending billions of dollars on the forces and toys needed by these plans, instead of putting bars on your windows and building high walls around your homes thus creating your own prisons, you should individually and collectively pressure your elected representatives to fund and institute the programmes we know will be successful to produce socially responsible citizens. Since politicians cannot see beyond the next election, unless a bottom-up demand and democratic-style push is placed upon them, your elected representatives will not act. It is all too easy and self-satisfying to blame the Government all the time; the Government is you and as such, you are responsible for it. If you do not act you will have to place yourselves in the dock for prosecution as you are then the \"recalcitrant parent\". Therefore, as the truly guilty party, instead of building your real and virtual prisons around yourselves, perhaps you yourselves should be sentenced to a real prison instead. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-tragedy-of-blind-faith-norms-and-education/article_8d09f40a-1c0d-5a1c-80ff-28ab10d4450c.html", "TITLE": " The tragedy of blind faith, norms and education ", "DATE": "Jun 13, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "T&T TALENT: Florida State's James Harris, left, Oregon's Mike Berry and Texas A&M's Deon Lendore, right, battle down the stretch in the NCAA Outdoor Track & Field Championship men's 400 metres final, on Friday, at Hayward Field in Eugene, Oregon, USA. Trinidad and Tobago's Lendore place first and Berry second. Photo: AP T&T TALENT: Florida State's James Harris, left, Oregon's Mike Berry and Texas A&M's Deon Lendore, right, battle down the stretch in the NCAA Outdoor Track & Field Championship men's 400 metres final, on Friday, at Hayward Field in Eugene, Oregon, USA. Trinidad and Tobago's Lendore place first and Berry second. Photo: AP Last week I wrote about the tragedy of blind faith in relation to religion and politics. This week I will continue on this topic but in relation to education and norms. It is my belief that the unwillingness of our citizens to question and address norms, values and education is one of the foundational flaws of our country. It is one of the root causes of the many ills we are experiencing today. It is necessary to acknowledge that there are many positive and uplifting aspects of our norm set and education. We are a people who transcended slavery, indentureship and all manners of oppressive horrors to build our nation. In education we continue to produce brilliant people who rise above their peers and go on to become leaders and elites in their respective fields. However, there are foundational problems with our norms and education. It is not my intention to criticise and highlight only the bad. Rather, I am seeking to point out the flaws and shortcomings of these institutions so that we can begin to rectify them. On norms, I cannot stress how much of our problems and issues can be attributed to this point. We as a nation have become accustomed to following norms without question. We have a tendency to follow a set of norms that were appropriate to a certain time and context and are unwilling to reshape and restructure our norms to reflect our present. For example, the patriarchal structure of our society and many of our national institutions date back to the times of colonialism. The favouring of men over women, the hyper-masculinisation of men and the de-sexing and de-humanising of women can be traced back to the slave fields, to white colonial controls and cultural prejudices. Women were expected to be subservient to their male relatives and the men were not to be questioned or opposed. Despite the very few public women in positions of power, the subjugation of women continues. To take the norms of gender relations even further the role of men as masculine, the \"village ram\" or \"badjohn\" has morphed into the stark criminal behaviour we see today. Young men in seeking to prove their masculinity are violent toward others, just as violence was meted out to them. Furthermore, they seek to impregnate as many women as possible to prove their virility but cannot take care of their offspring, leading to fatherless children and an entire cycle of violence. In a society where we expect boys to be hardy, rough, violent and promiscuous, is it not surprising that we are plagued by so much violence We set the stage and the structures of violence and the drug and arms trade provide the tools for them to perform their expected roles. Blind acceptance of norms goes far beyond gender and violence. We still operate under a colonial mentality that white is right. We refuse to place science and logic, facts and knowledge into our values systems and instead rely on false or outdated sources of conduct. We as a nation turn a blind eye to child abuse, animal abuse, domestic violence etc because \"dat is none ah we business\". We continue to sexualise all of our cultural arts and yet are shocked at sex scandals in schools. Sex has been going on in schools since there were schools, the only difference is now there are cameras and phones to record. Norms in relation to sexual orientation, in relation to child rearing and medication, healthy living and community are all very much flawed, yet we refuse to change; \"dat is de way it is\" is the usual rebuttal of those who are set in their ways. This is not to say that we should do away with all the old. Rather we should endeavour to adjust our norms and values to create the equitable, just and peaceful society that we crave. The blind acceptance of education is also another fundamental issue with our nation. I will need to traverse carefully along this explanation if I am to get my point across. Education is supposed to be much more than the knowing of facts and the memorising of \"knowledge\". Rather it is supposed to be an enquiry project where basic understanding is used to challenge and push the boundaries of what is called \"education\". From primary school all the way to Form Five the general pupil needs to be imparted with basic knowledge, facts, figures and skills. From A-Levels however, pupils are supposed to be prepared to question the question and push the limits of their minds. At university this is supposed to bloom. Sadly, the pushing of boundaries and the expanding of frontiers is not something that is taking place in our system. We are not equipping students to question and think critically. In this point it is not the student who is at fault, rather it is the cumbersome, detached and uninformed bureaucracy who design education curriculum who accept the old style of learning without question. They refuse to see that a student in 2012 cannot be expected to learn like a student in the 1950s. Time and technology has fundamentally altered the pedagogy of teaching and learning and we need to catch up. It is not too late for us to try and push the boundaries of what we accept even at the foundational level. We should as a nation realise that we are not perfect and that there is much work that needs to be done. The best way to grow and to learn is to open our minds and reject blind faith in any and all things. Rajiv Gopie won the President's Medal in 2006 for business/modern studies. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/is-religion-education-good/article_2db67fd5-51f2-5b96-b9a8-1668e0f53257.html", "TITLE": " Is Religion Education good ", "DATE": "Apr 15, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The Religious Education that the Government will be making compulsory in all schools is supposed to foster tolerance among young people. But, according to psychological studies, this will be achieved only if the students become less religious. And, if RE makes more people more religious, crime and corruption in Trinidad and Tobago may get worse. This is not the view of the country's present Prime Minister, however. When she was Minister of Education in the UNC administration 15 years ago, Kamla Persad-Bissessar told the audience at an ASJA fund-raising function: \"There is a fair amount of empirical evidence that points to the contribution that religion makes to healthy human development, especially in the development of the young.\" But in their book Atheists, North American psychologists Bruce Hunsberger and Bob Altemeyer cite their research which found that, the more religious people were, the more narrow-minded they became. \"As religiosity ranges from 0 to 100, so will dogmatism, zealotry, authoritarianism, and prejudice generally increase,\" they write. Their studies encompassed Canadians and Americans who went to church regularly and those who went only occasionally. Non-believers scored lowest on this list of undesirable traits. However, psychologist David G Myers, whose psychology textbooks are widely used in American universities, says the opposite in his book A Friendly Letter to Skeptics and Atheists. \"In nearly every one of more than two dozen studies, faithful church attenders exhibited less prejudice than irregular attenders,\" Myers writes. \"...it seems that, among the churched, the devout exhibit less prejudice and deeper feelings of human kinship that the nominally religious, who are somewhat more likely to rationalise prejudice with the aid of religion.\" In Trinidad and Tobago, religion is also seen as a key to academic success. Religious leaders continually claim that it is the religious character of the denominational schools which account for them producing most of the top 100 SEA students and taking the lion's share of CSEC scholarships. Maha Sabha head Sat Maharaj, for example, in a 2007 article in the Trinidad Guardian wrote: \"A successful education system must, therefore, provide for the cultural and religious needs of the children. Lack of State subventions for priests, pundits, and imams to teach religious values must impact negatively, especially at the state schools.\" However, at the formal opening of a national consultation on the primary school curriculum on April 5, Education Minister Tim Gopeesingh noted, \"The denomination boards cream the top and put them into their so-called prestige schools, so they must get better results at CSEC, CXC. So you only get good results at CXC and CSEC because you have the best students coming to your school.\" Other factors may be more pertinent to the academic performance of these schools. Criminologist Ramesh Deosaran has done research showing that the majority of students in the \"prestige schools\" come from two-parent families which are mostly upper- and middle-class. (See Table 1.) Studies show that these factors are more relevant than a religious upbringing to doing well in school and avoiding serious juvenile delinquency. Moreover, studies in other countries have consistently shown a negative correlation between IQ or education and religiosityi.e. the higher people's IQ or educational attainments, the less likely they are to be religious. For example, a 1996 study by psychologists EJ Larson and L Witham showed that over two-thirds of the most eminent American scientists do not believe in God or an afterlife, as compared to a mere ten per cent of the general American populace who also rejected such beliefs. Table 2 shows the religious affiliations of UWI students at the St Augustine campus, compared to their respective proportions in the wider population. The percentage of students who did not state their religion is twice that of the general populace (or seven times that of the national census who put \"None\"). All denominations are under-represented, except Presbyterians and Pentecostals. Professor Theodore Lewis We may begin the discussion of education between Emancipation (1834) and Independence (1962) with the report of Joseph Latrobe, who in 1837 was sent by the British parliament to see how money from the Negro Education Grant was being spent. Latrobe wrote in his report that \u201cThe colony has laboured under greater disadvantages than many of the West India Islands, from the prevalence of the French and Spanish languages, and of the Roman Catholic faith, and also from the manner in which its motley population is found scattered\u201d. It must be remembered that the Church of England (Anglicans) is led by the English monarch, while Catholics are led from Rome (Italy) by the Pope. Latrobe said, \u201cIt appears evident that before emancipation the education of the negro was carried forward in all these colonies, \u201cmore or less, under every dis-advantage.\u201c The colonial legislatures were openly hostile to it; and so were the majority of proprietors and administrators of estates. Thus, he wrote, \u201cThe schools to which the negro had access were, for the most part, of but poor pretensions.\u201d Governor Lord Harris came in 1849, shortly after the first set of Indian indentures arrived. He introduced primary schools in each ward of the country, insisting that the schools must not have a religious flavour. It should be clear by now that after emancipation there was a missing voice in the discussions about the education of the ex-slave\u2014the voice of African forebears. There is no record in Caribbean history of anyone asking Africans, now freed from slavery, for their views on what form their education should take. Africans were no longer slaves, but they were not citizens either. They had no say in their education. Carl Campbell sheds important light on the formative years of secondary education in the country, with the main actors engaging in conversation about the curriculum and its proximity to the requirements of Oxford and Cambridge. Classical education was the order of the day. As with primary education, the main tension with secondary was whether the orientation of the curriculum should be religious or secular. Two significant secondary schools for boys emerged in Trinidad in the 1850s, the Queen\u2019s Collegiate School (later Queen\u2019s Royal College) supposedly secular but really an anglicised institution, established by the colonial government, and St Mary\u2019s College established by the Roman Catholics, and championed by the French Creole population who had appealed to Rome to establish a counterpart to QRC. Convents for girls had been established before emancipation. These secondary schools were for the children of the ruling classes, white and coloured, who were admitted to the schools based solely on their colour. They did not have to take exams. For the children of Africans, a different logic of admission obtained, particularised to academic giftedness. A handful of black children, three or four, could be admitted periodically if they topped the island in a special exam. The Presbyterians entered the fray late in the 19th century, taking special interest solely in the education of the children of indentures. They were blind to the African child, and never ventured to Tobago. Following the establishment of QRC in the 1860s, the colonial state did not establish another secondary school on the island, until 1953, when St George\u2019s College was founded. These were the only two State run schools here when Eric Williams and the PNM came to power in 1956. How do you run a country, with education so crucial to state formation, if the secondary schools are not under the control of the state? The PNM government and the denominations agreed to a compromise in the Concordat of 1960. The denominations could prescribe 20 per cent of the intake. Since whites and coloureds constituted less than 20 per cent of the population, all their children could attend the prestige schools. Some still want the Concordat to prevail, even though we no longer have conditions of scarcity in education. We have gone from two government schools in 1953 to the 37 pages of schools filled with the SEA results this year. No other country in the Caribbean allows churches to come in and take their share first. Not Barbados, not Jamaica. The country has been held with its head over a barrel based on the Concordat compromise, made in 1960, at a time when we did not have any of the highways we now have, when people bought butter by the ounce, and all of the houses on streets where I lived had a pit latrine. Our current SEA examination process is premised on a status quo of unequal schools that children and their parents understand in terms of first, second and third choices. Each choice reflects a different order of quality. Why do we not have first, second and third choice water, hospitals and electricity in this country? Secondary schools, like primary schools in this country, are of unequal quality, therefore children of every creed and race do not find an equal school place. Here at Emancipation 2019, 185 years on from Emancipation 1834, the black child remains at the margins of the education system, more likely to graduate to the remand yard than to the university. Professor Theodore Lewis WE are now 185 years on from emancipation. Recently deceased historian Colin Palmer made the fact of an African diaspora in the Americas a pillar of his scholarship. In 1863 as the American civil war raged, President Lincoln issued the emancipation proclamation declaring the slaves free. Slavery was the reason why slave owning confederate southern states had broken away from the Union, and hence the basis of the war. Emancipation was a death blow to them, because it meant they had no slave empire to which they could return. The proclamation changed the status of blacks from slave to free. The news spread among them that they were no longer slaves. Black men joined the Union army in droves. Come 1865 and the Civil war was over. Immediately after the war, concessions were made to blacks including the establishment of the Freedman\u2019s Bureau to begin an assault on illiteracy by the creation of educational institutions. That led to the establishment of Howard University, among others. Blacks themselves on a clandestine basis, throughout slavery, had built a network of schools. When the civil war ended those from the Northern states who had been free all along, migrated in droves to the south and quickly established a vast network of elementary and secondary schools along with teachers\u2019 colleges, for their brethren. This effort of self-help is well documented by WEB Dubois in Black Reconstruction, and by James Anderson in The Education of Blacks in the South, 1860-1935. It has no counterpart in Caribbean slavery. Fast forward to 1954, and American blacks found themselves before the Supreme Court fighting for the right to quality education for their children. Official school segregation had forced them into separate schools that were poorly funded and equipped. Violence against them kept black children out of white schools. The Supreme court agreed in Brown v the Board of Education, that indeed separate schools were inherently unequal. Here at home the slave trade was abolished in 1806, one year earlier than elsewhere in the British empire, Trinidad being set aside as the model for crown colony rule, as James Millette has espoused. A key feature of the model was amelioration, intended not to abolish slavery but to reform it. In an address to the British parliament in 1824 on the question of amelioration, Colonial Secretary Canning said the following: \u201cWith respect to Trinidad, I cannot omit to observe that about twenty years ago I in this House called the attention of government to that colony, the possession of which was then recently confirmed to us by the peace; and submitted a motion to the effect that Trinidad should not be placed on the same footing as our other colonies by the grant of a legislative constitution; but should be reserved under the unfettered dominion of the Crown, for the purpose of experiments for the amelioration of the condition of the slaves.\u201d In a 1932 article in the Journal of Negro Education, titled \u201cThe Neglected Period of Emancipation in Great Britain 1807-1823,\u201d Charles Wesley wrote that the logic of leading abolitionists was that Africans would be unable to deal with complete freedom, and hence a period of gradualism was needed by them. In \u201cSlavery and Freedom in the British West Indies, 1823-33: The Role of Education\u201d Olwyn Blouet writes that: \u201cThe imperial commitment to amelioration in 1823 had a marked impact on the development of education in the British West Indies. First, nonconformist missionaries stepped up their activities to prepare slaves for freedom. They opened schools when and where they could. Some missionaries were independent of planter patrons. The missionaries became unofficial agents of imperial policy with a claim to imperial protection.\u201d Blouet writes further that \u201cThe British government hoped that the Established Church of England (the Anglican church) would be the religious and educational arm of amelioration. Education was intended for moral regeneration, to lift slaves out of degradation and barbarism.\u201d The archbishop of Canterbury has recently apologised for the fact that the Anglican church had inherited and owned slaves at Codrington Estate in Barbados. Amelioration failed for a host of contested reasons. With its failure, the abolishment of slavery and the emancipation of slaves became plan B. In Capitalism and Slavery, still the most persuasive explanation of why Caribbean slavery collapsed, Eric Williams illustrated the economic decline of sugar. At the point of emancipation, the parliament passed the Negro Education Grant, which set aside \u00a3235,000 to be spent on education across the region. Religious denominations were to compete for the funds available to establish schools. A first-hand account of schooling in the early dawn of emancipation was provided by Joseph Latrobe, who in the service of the parliament was sent in 1837, to make observations on the status of the school systems and disbursements in Jamaica, Trinidad and British Guiana. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/education-the-way-forward/article_da512244-faf9-5553-ab2c-a6fc0cd22e14.html", "TITLE": " Education \u2014 the way forward ", "DATE": "Sep 1, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "On Wednesday, Trinidad and Tobago celebrated its 54th anniversary of Independence with the usual pomp and ceremony. Interestingly, the debate on education once again surfaced as retired principal Justin Paul, who received a Chaconia Medal (Gold), said that the shift system in secondary schools is responsible for the escalating crime in the country. The strengths and weaknesses of our education system have been the source of ongoing discourse. Some have lauded the system, recognising that this country has produced some of the finest minds in the world. Students from Trinidad and Tobago excel wherever they go, particularly in universities in North America and Europe. Foreign faculty and students alike are impressed by the quality of our students, particularly those who have earned scholarships and opt to study abroad. The significance of education has been recognised by our leaders over time, with several administrations experimenting with various policies in an effort at improvement. It was Dr Eric Williams who, on the eve of this country's independence from Britain on 30 August, 1962, said that \u201cto educate is to emancipate\u201d. His famous message has never been forgotten as he stated that \u201cYou, the children, yours is the great responsibility to educate your parents, teach them to live together in harmony\u2026To your tender and loving hands, the future of the nation is entrusted. \u201cIn your innocent hearts, the pride of the nation is enshrined. On your scholastic development, the salvation of the nation is dependent\u2026you carry the future of Trinidad and Tobago in your school bags.\u201d Dr Williams meant well but there is some truth in Paul's assertion about the deficiencies of the junior secondary school system. Pupils enjoyed considerable free time during the hours when they were not at school and some would have used that time to indulge in negative activities which contributed to the high crime rate in this country. However, there are other factors which contribute to crime including culture, poor parenting, politics, lavishing children with material things, deficient curricula, the drug trade and the lack of a comprehensive youth development policy, amongst others. Even without the shift system, discipline problems are quite high in the secondary schools, including the so-called prestige denominational institutions. Some of the most notorious trouble-makers are privileged children from affluent homes. In short, there are many factors accounting for criminal activities which can be attributed to a web of historical and social problems that have festered over time. The result is a high number of hungry, alienated, hopeless, rich and poor youths who find it difficult to cope with the demands of academia. There are those who are spoilt rotten with all the material comforts in life and who do not appreciate the value of hard work and sacrifice. Some of them make it to university but struggle to complete their programmes as they get distracted with drugs, including alcohol. The lack of meaningful employment opportunities is also contributing to the crime crisis. The hard-working, diligent student who struggled financially to secure an education but cannot find a suitable job after graduation is left frustrated. Quality education continues to be a challenge as the heavy emphasis on academics leaves many students unprepared for the needs of this society, particularly the increasing demand for skilled workers. Even so, a high number of tertiary students have difficulty writing proper English. Spelling, style and grammar leave a lot to be desired, making them ill-prepared for the world of work. Yet, today's youths have an amazing grasp of technology and are quite tech savvy when it comes to mobile phones and computers. But the language of the chat line is unacceptable in the classroom and for examinations where some students' inability to communicate in good standard English really comes to the fore. Some students are only pursuing education at the tertiary level because their parents insist that they get certified. But this certification may not even get them a job in their field as the rate of underemployment escalates as thousands of students graduate with each passing year. Nevertheless, education remains the only way forward for the majority of our youths and certainly the best route out of poverty. Youths must understand that it has more than economic value as it moulds their personality, intellect and overall development and impacts their capacity to think, analyse and make rational decisions. Neither should we forget the many educators who have laboured in the classrooms over the decades. For a long time, teachers and principals have endured low salaries, poor working conditions and inadequate resources in their valiant efforts to uphold a noble profession which is not given the recognition it deserves. So, as the country prepares for the rat-race with the reopening of classrooms on Monday and the concomitant mad rush, traffic and possible torrential September showers, it would be useful to remember the watchwords \u2014 live, love and learn. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/developing-teachers-and-children-too/article_44ba109e-49d1-5411-8c78-f220716c367f.html", "TITLE": " Developing teachers, and children too ", "DATE": "Apr 17, 2017 ", "CONTENT": "There is an absence of professional teachers' associations in the country. I am making a distinction here between a professional association and a union. This is not an academic difference. The aim of a union is to present a united front for workers that strengthens their bargaining position on matters relating to conditions of work, pay, promotion and so on. The aim of a professional association of teachers is to improve the practice of teachers, and to establish codes of ethics or behaviour that can help guide their work. These are not necessarily mutually exclusive aims, but the impetus of associations can serve as a limit on what a teacher is prepared to do where service to children or obligations to them are concerned. I am provoked to write this column by the weekly, and sometimes daily, e-mails I continue to receive from the Minnesota Technology Education Association, though it is almost a decade since I worked in the state and was a member of that association. The same is the case regarding frequent e-mails I receive from the American Education Research Association asking me to renew membership, something I gave up when I retired from university teaching in the United States. In the US, university level professional associations are parallel to those that serve elementary and secondary teachers and aim to improve practice in subject fields. An exemplary association that can be drawn upon here to help the point is the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA). This association has all the classic features of a professional association of teachers. In the first instance membership comes with paying annual dues, with the option to subscribe to the array of professional journals and other publications put out by the association. NSTA produces journals for science teaching at all levels of schooling, from elementary to secondary. These journals bring to teachers the latest in science practice that can inform their teaching. There was a time in T&T when science teachers were organised, not as a union, but as a professional body, with an important journal, ASSETT, that kept teachers up to date. Technical and vocational teachers, too, were professionally organised in T&T. We held regular meetings, and an annual conference. We had the ear of the Ministry of Education. One may argue that locally we have a union in the Trinidad and Tobago Unified Association, and that the professional needs of teachers can be served through it. I don't think so. Unions and professional associations are diametrically opposed when it comes to service to children. For one thing, unions require group-think, or collective response. For example, you may be called upon to stand outside of your school and picket the principal. What if your instinct is not to do that, but instead to stay with your form four class that is having difficulty with technical drawing or mathematics Union thinking could make that dangerous, even for teachers. Here a teacher becomes no different from an oil worker, and with respect, that really ought not to be the case. Professional associations foster individualistic thinking. It might impel the teacher to say that children must not be punished in the service of some union aim. There are a host of issues in our schools that seem to me to require a new wave of professionalism, as opposed to unionism. For example, many children in schools in depressed areas are not performing well academically. Many children are struggling with mathematics, or with standard English. These are not union concerns typically; but they would be the concerns of professional associations. What do we know about the urban child here What strategies are there that can be adopted in urban schools to help the many lost children within them The education landscape in the country is virtually devoid of professional organisations related to teaching. There are no active teacher professional associations in art, music, mathematics, science, geography, or language. There are no local journals produced and circulated by teachers aimed at improving teaching. I have some familiarity with the SEA mathematics syllabus and know that many teachers and parents would have difficulty with it. If there were elementary education associations, there could be sharing of strategies on how to teach aspects of the mathematics curriculum. Professional associations require a different mindset from unions. A teacher is not a construction worker, or a boiler mechanic. You can't just take a day off for rest and reflection, or whatever, when children are the bargaining chip. Associations require teachers to think individualistically, against the backdrop of codes of ethics. Teachers must draw upon professional conscience sometimes, and to find ways of bargaining that do not require holding children and their parents hostage. There is a great need for groupings of teachers in this country to get together professionally in the service of the advancement of school subjects they teach. Our professional landscape in teaching here is a desert. It is one of the reasons why failure abounds in many schools. Teachers are not taking failure personally, and they should. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/new-education-system/article_0873dd74-7333-5f01-b8f9-b1309efc40b4.html", "TITLE": " New education system ", "DATE": "Jul 21, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Part 1 of this article was published on July 18 Both Singaporean and Finnish students excel at knowledge acquisition and book learning; they lead the world when the outcome is success on standard tests. They are less sure when facing the expectations of the modern world for entrepreneurship, thinking outside the box, seeing as-yet-unimagined social, civic, economic, ecological possibilities. The need is for students and citizens who can reason, think critically, problem-solvethink, question, reject and synthesise. These are not capacities that are easily captured by standardised test formats. Both Singapore and Finland are considering the adjustments they need to make! (We note that we have stellar \"book-learners'' and \"test-takers'' in T&T who can compete with the international beston the SEA, for example. What we do not know is how well they do in the world. Do we have ten-year and 20-year outcome data on these successful examination takers) China is another country that in a relatively few years has produced an amazingly successful educational system which incorporates many attributes of the Singaporean system. They too, like the Singaporeans and the Finns, are starting to recognise the limitations of knowledge and skills acquisition unleavened by the yeast of creativity. China is able to turn out thousands of engineers: they do not all have the ability to think to the next level, to make the innovations necessary to respond to the needs of a complex society. They too are looking elsewhere for the sources of critical thinking, problem-solving, and entrepreneurship. So what do we mean by a \"new educational paradigm'' If he is serious in his goals for T&T's education system, Dr Gopeesingh needs to abandon the application of plasters to the T&T education system as is, and, taking a public health approach, should build from the bottom. What does that mean here It means building a totally new, parallel, education system improving, to the best standards possible, the lower forms while carrying along the current system as best as can be done. Those upper classes remaining will be no worse off than they currently are until all are graduated out of the old system. So what does building a new system involve First, it involves a totally new attitude about and toward teachers. Teaching has to be highly valued as not only an occupation, but as a career. In order for that to even start, the pay scale has to start at salaries commensurate with those found at the mid-executive level. A college degree is to be the minimum standard; Masters level degrees are to be encouraged and even required for some teaching specialties; teachers should be paid accordingly. Bonuses should be offered to those who are interested in, and show an aptitude for, pre-school, kindergarten and primary classroom teaching. Establishing the foundations of learning in the youngest learners is the most important goal of an education system; the most demanding teaching skills are needed at these levels and should be recompensed accordingly. With competitive pay scales, a teaching career will become attractive as a career choice to those graduating in the upper 1/3 of their university classes. Competitive and attractive pay scales will also attract more men into teaching thus helping to alleviate the surplus endangered-species male population problem. Once these become a part of the system, we will be able to expect responsibility and, that key word, accountability, from the teachers. A well-paid, highly respected, greatly valued member of society will not have much issue with a concept of wanting to perform well amongst a peer group and for society. Second on the agenda is setting up an entirely new teacher recruitment and training programme. In this regard T&T can learn from the systems that work well in countries like Singapore, Korea, Finland and the like. There is no need to re-invent the wheel. Included in the new model will also be the lessons learned from the best of the more progressive educational philosophies from countries around the world, those that foster the ability to reason, to think critically, to problem-solve and to be able \"to think outside the box''. Third, a complete sub-training programme to train teachers whose focus will be to provide teaching services for what we call Early, Early Childhood Education (EECE), involving those children from birth to age three, and for Early Childhood Education (ECE), involving those from age three to five. These periods are the most important times in the education timeline of a child. If you do not \"get them'' by age five, you have lost them and trying to play \"catch up'' after that is extremely difficult and very, very expensive. A fourth link in this chain will be maximising the development of all T&T children. For this link it will be necessary to include nutrition and early childcare programmes, to empower paediatricians and social workers at the community level, to establish units of occupational and physical therapists, speech-language therapists, neuropsychologists, behavioural psychologists, medical specialists such as audiologists, ophthalmologists, dentists, plus training specialty teachers and educational therapists. All these will be necessary elements in order to provide the care and resources for children to develop to their full potential and get whatever supports they may need to thrive in the school setting from preschool onwards. The fifth link extends the provision of the fourth. Specialist teams should be developed to provide remediation services to those children with specific learning disabilities (SLD: an estimated 15 per cent of all learners in any society). The teacher training programmes will include coursework and practicum experiences to enable teachers to recognise SLD. No society can afford to waste any potential for learning in any child; the primary obligation of an educational system is to enable every child to ultimately become a self-sufficient, productive member of that society. Now, do we think that this society will embrace and implement the system we have presented Is Trinidad going to implement an education system that will meet the needs of the 21st century Is this going to happen in T&T If not, why not Trinis surely do not lack for brains, creativity or energy. Lenn Bernstein worked as a professor of orthodontics at Boston University School of Dental Medicine, an environmental consultant, a medical education consultant, a small business owner and has an interest in education in general and early childhood education in particular. Jane Holmes- Bernstein is a neuropsychologist at Boston Children's Hospital and is an associate professor at Harvard Medical School. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/one-in-five-children-obese-in-south/article_a695922c-702d-50b9-9c80-b527ef123f2a.html", "TITLE": " One in five children obese in south ", "DATE": "Apr 2, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "A health study conducted by local and foreign researchers has found that one in five children in south Trinidad are overweight or obese. The findings are contained in a report published as a result of work done by the Trinidad and Tobago Health Sciences Initiative, John's Hopkins Medicine, Ministry of Health, and The University of Trinidad and Tobago. The aim of the study which was prompted by the Trinidad and Tobago Olympic Committee, the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Health, was to fight childhood obesity through educating the public. Senior author of the report, Felicia Hill-Briggs, Ph.D. stated: \"These are decidedly sobering findings that highlight a critical need to reverse a trend that, if uncorrected, can have far-reaching consequences for the health of this nation.\" The research shows that some of the conditions faced by adults are in fact as a results from childhood. Obesity and early weight problems are known to be rooted with cardiovascular diseases, respiratory problems, metabolic disorders, type 2 diabetes, and some cancers. These researchers stated that there have been successful treatments in dealing with childhood obesity and overweight issues, through lifestlye and behaviour-modification programmes. The findings are from data collected in 2012 from more than 3,300 children, age ranging from 5 to 12 years old from 14 different primary schools, within the Point Fortin and Mayaro regions. The results of the analysis showed that less than two-thirds of the children had a normal body mass index, more than one-fifth were overweight or obese and 13 per cent were underweight. The number of underweight children from the survey, can be attributed to poor nutrition, the report stated. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/celebrating-three-decades-of-education/article_db8c9519-0253-5a31-9e96-eb67f74fa984.html", "TITLE": " Celebrating three decades of education ", "DATE": "Nov 9, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "On her feet: Principal of Eshe\u0092s Learning Centre Kit Cadette embraces founder Dr Elsa Lynch at the School\u0092s 30th Anniversary Celebration at Tranquillity Methodist Church. On her feet: Principal of Eshe\u0092s Learning Centre Kit Cadette embraces founder Dr Elsa Lynch at the School\u0092s 30th Anniversary Celebration at Tranquillity Methodist Church. All the international statistics indicate that there is a direct link between school difficulties and school failure and juvenile delinquency, Dr Esla Lynch, founder of Eshes Learning Centre, noted, as she addressed that schools 30th Anniversary celebration at the Tranquillity Methodist Church last Wednesday. As a testimony of Eshes success, Lynch reflected, that not many graduates of Eshes, a school which caters for pupils with learning disabilities and other challenges, had followed the path of delinquency. The school had produced many productive pupils, which included priests, university graduates, public servants, teachers, a doctor and other such persons who were contributing constructively to the society. In fact, Lynch pointed out that three former Eshes pupils had received national scholarships. But the path to this accomplishment has been paved with the vision and commitment by Lynch, and coloured by her passion for the disenfranchised. This saw her 30 years ago, starting the Eshes embryo at 7 OConnor Street on November 5, 1984, with just three full-time pupils, whose names she still remembers- Collin, Mark and Kyle. The school then had no name, no uniform, just a lot of boxes and charts and the desire to work with children who were having difficulties in the mainstream school system. In January of 1985 the school moved to Lynchs childhood home on Alfredo Street and the house became home and school. The children worked at the same table at which I had done homework many, many moons ago, often accompanied with licks, recalled Lynch whose dyslexia had been undiagnosed as a schoolchild. This experience of her own difficult school life fed her interest, specialisation, qualification and passion for Special Education, in which she had earned a doctorate. By this time the numbers of students began to grow and Lynch took on two other teachers. By this time January 1985 the school was not only offering academic support, but had begun an enrichment programme which included ceramics, pan, woodwork and sewing, sourcing these skills from the community. By 1986, with a waiting list of over 50 students, the school opened at Maraval. Thanks to the generosity and sacrifice of the Lynch family, who put both money and mouth in the venture, Eshes home is a big building with ample yard space located at 105 Arapita Avenue, Woodbrook. It currently has 31 full-time teachers and approximately 200 students. Recognising that it cannot reach every child with learning challenges, the school has held three national conferences and has gone into public and private schools providing guidance to teachers there on how to work with such children. In the last two years we have begun the process of forging a very important relationship with the Howard School in Atlanta, Georgia and has a result of that we have had seven persons from that school come to Eshes to conduct staff development workshops. And five of our teachers have gone to the Howard School, Lynch reported. Although she retired as principal, Lynch continues be active in the schools development and sits on the board of management, influencing both policy and perspective. The schools current principal, Kit Cadette is from the Howard School. Cadette, whose relationship with Lynch and Eshe predated her appointment as principal, stated in her emotional address: We want her (Dr Lynch) to know that her years of sacrifice have not gone in vain. And unlike so many schools that when the founder has handed over the school, the school loses its essence and in a real sense, its place in society, we commit to you Dr Lynch that your child (Eshes) will continue to bear much fruit. Psychologist Allyson Hamel-Smith, speaking on behalf of the board of management, also stated that goal was to make sure that the work started by Lynch continues hopefully long after we are all gone. She said boards work was based on the pillars underlying the strength of Eshes which included a deep and profound respect and serious commitment to children, consistent staff training and robust staff accountability, measured by the progress and behaviour of the students; and a relationship with the parents and community. Commenting that many people in the country were better off because of Dr Lynchs significant intervention in education, she said the school was committed to continuing her work. Parent of a former Eshes student, Pat Sookdar described Lynch as a mother, who helped to nurture confidence and competence in her (Sookdars) son, Jeremie, whose greatest happiness is now in the world of music. Parent of a current student, Pavia Paymah remarked that she could only genuflect to the teachers at the school for giving her son the necessary life skills, academic background, good manners, the ability to interact with others and the capacity for a wealth of information. Most importantly, Paymah observed, the teachers at Eshes gave love. Rev Harry who delivered the homily picked on the significant of giving love. Time is teaching us how valuable love is, he said, noting that the staff and management of the school were engaged in a labour of love. Today we celebrate a milestone but the love continues, the love for God, the love for wisdom and the love for special children, he asserted. Greetings were given by a representative of the Ministry of Education on behalf of Dr Bharathsingh, manager of Students Support Services, Mrs Grant and Mrs Cupid. The representative noted that Lynch was a pioneer in working with children with hidden disabilities in the days when no one knew what this was and when no one was prepared to work with such children. Over the years your graduates have done us proud as nationals of Trinidad and Tobago, the representative stated. Wednesdays programme of events including performances by Eshes steelband recitation of poems by the students, a dance by teacher Lystra Black and a song performed by teacher Ruth Joyette. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/pm-not-a-good-week-for-children/article_1ff414ac-3215-5d73-8675-d8a3b51403c5.html", "TITLE": " PM: Not a good week for children ", "DATE": "Jun 3, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "CONCERNED: Kamla Persad-Bissessar CONCERNED: Kamla Persad-Bissessar PROTECTION of children is everyones responsibility, said Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar in a press release to mark todays commemoration of International Day of Innocent Children/Victims of Aggression. In a statement from her office yesterday, the Prime Minister admitted that this week had not been a good one for the children of Trinidad and Tobago, with the deaths of two toddlers by drowning, while a nine-year-old was murdered in what police described as a gang-related incident. Persad-Bissessar said there can be no greater terror for a young child than to desperately reach out to the ones they love and trust for help, and be met with aggression and violence. The mental and emotional torture, the anxiety, the sense of hopelessness and fright are unthinkable and we must, all of us, make the commitment that we will all take on the role of keeper of our nations children. The PM added: Over the years, however, even as we have progressed in a number of ways, incidents of aggression and violence against children, a number of them fatal, have been a source of revulsion, horror and a fervent commitment to do more, and do better for our children. Within the past week, we have seen two teenagers and a nine-year-old boy gunned down by criminal elements. We have seen the drowning of two small children who were apparently left unsupervised. Everyone still remembers the gruesome events which took the life of 11-year-old Akiel Chambers in 1998, with no justice to the family. On the side of Government, our vision has been to ensure that our children and young citizens are provided with every opportunity so that they can be supported to develop into grounded, socially-adept and intellectually-strong adults, said Persad-Bissessar. Through universal, free pre-school places for every child; a now fully technology-driven system of secondary education; much greater diversity of technical and vocational training programmes; community-based partnerships; legislative enhancements; full resource and technical support for the Childrens Authority, and direct intervention parenting and family policies, we have been able to expand our reach to protect our childrens lives and future, she added.
