{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/combat-crime-through-education/article_4c9b853f-38ec-5175-88f2-68f67d148558.html", "TITLE": " Combat crime through education ", "DATE": "Jan 6, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Washed away: There was extensive flooding and damage to property in Cane Grove, St Vincent. \u2014Photo courtesy iwnsvg.com Helping hand: ITNAC volunteers during recent preparations to take emergency items to St Lucia. Washed away: There was extensive flooding and damage to property in Cane Grove, St Vincent. \u2014Photo courtesy iwnsvg.com Helping hand: ITNAC volunteers during recent preparations to take emergency items to St Lucia. With authorities in Trinidad and Tobago struggling to contain escalating crime and with our murder rates at record levels, there has been an increase in calls from all sectors of society to focus on strengthening the home as a haven to raise healthier children and combat crime. Camile Swapp, director of Swapp & Associates is advocating a different approach. Her remedy is to combat crime at all levels, raise healthier adults and build stronger societies by focusing on the education system. Swapp, 45, who is a Guidance Counsellor and also serves as the Director of Youth Affairs at Vision on Mission, believes that the 'colonial' education system adopted by many English Caribbean countries is deeply challenged, harming the Caribbean male most of all. She has been advocating for a different approach to child development for the past 11 years. \"We have made mistakes in not checking on the needs of our young people, especially our learners,\" said Swapp during an interview at her home on Tuesday evening. \"There is a lot of research now about child and brain development, but we did not focus on that in the Caribbean. Our focus was on exam-oriented learning and we believed that if we taught the child everything and the child was able to recollect everything, the child was smart and ready to move forward whereas the child who could not recollect as easily was deemed to be stupid. We tended to see everything wrong with the learner and not really anything wrong with the system.\" This is the system within the school that Swapp believes must be changed to allow for healthy growth. A Jamaican by birth, Swapp is the wife of marine pilot, Elgin Swapp and mother of two daughters aged 17 and 11. Mr. Swapp's job has taken the family to different countries around the world and provided the Swapp family with an exposure to different social systems and different approaches to education. \"Eleven years ago our family lived in Sweden for some time,\" she recalled. \"When I was there I saw that the school positioned itself to understanding what is developmentally appropriate for young learners to do well from 8:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. without extra lessons and the additional stress. The State held the school and parents seriously accountable for the way the child should be treated, promoted best practice systems in education and the schools actually provided the best environment for the children when the parents were at work.\" The Swedish education system focused on a nine-year comprehensive school for children between the ages of seven and sixteen so that most children in Sweden remained in the same institution for all of their compulsory education. Children are also offered the opportunity to stay in the school until 18 years, and many take up the offer. \"They taught the child at the level of the child's understanding,\" Swapp said. She also spoke of the education system in France where children were offered extra help during the school day for areas where they were challenged. The family moved to Trinidad five years ago when Mr. Swapp was offered a post in the Maritime Department at the University of Trinidad and Tobago. When his tenure at UTT ended, he joined the Trinidad and Tobago Marine Pilot Association where he is currently employed. While here, Swapp researched developmentally appropriate practices to promote joyful learning in school age children at the Caribbean Nazarene College and prepared an undergraduate thesis on the subject. \"Here in the Caribbean, our passion for education from the cradle to tertiary is mostly about certification and prestige and not enough about building nations so that while we have had people who have succeeded, too many felt less than or insignificant through the experience,\" she said. She encourages the school system to teach the child at an age appropriate level where he or she can understand and relate to their parents rather than hope that all parents are proficient teachers. \"That way we build the nation, we are better able to lift their generation higher than the one before,\" she said. \"Parents don't have the tools and best practices from a teachers' college. The current deviance among youths, sadness and apathy and lower levels of health mentally and physically among children is an indictment on our system.\" She believes that this system has placed the male student at a disadvantage. Research has shown that boys and girls learn differently and many educators have observed that boys learn better by non-verbal cueing and have a harder time than girls listening to a lot of words. While girls have better fine motor skills at an earlier age and are more fluent verbally, boys develop gross motor skills faster and are better at physical activities. \"By the time the boy is ready to wake up and really challenge with fine motor skills, he is out of school at form five at age 16, and what do you do then\" Swapp asked. \"The child needs to stay in the school system until 18 years, those two extra years are frightfully important.\" Swapp also slammed other pressures in the educational system that forced many parents to seek extra lessons to ensure that their children met the required standard. With the view that the school is the single institution that has the most influence in society as it touches the lives of all regardless of race, color, social standing or religious affiliation, Swapp believes that more attention should be focused on child development when developing a curriculum that is conducive to learning. \"It is not about 'dumbing' down the curriculum, but about finding a balance,\" she said. \"We must challenge our children, we must give them information, but it is wrong to use the test to say they are good or no good and use results to get them to certain schools. This is a true sustainable way to limit crime and we can make that change for 2011 and beyond. Having lived in Jamaica and also here in Trinidad, we have tried to change every system to combat crime except our education system. How can we not have done that That is the think tank and that is where the change in thinking must come. We have changed political groups. We have changed police commissioners. We have done everything except renewing the education system for our children in this modern world.\" She is taking her theory about education to the other level. In addition to publicly sharing her views, she formed the company Swapp and Associates together with her husband in 2010 and proposed to serve as the mediator between the home and the school. In April 2010, Swapp and Associates hosted US educator and child psychologist Dr David Elkind. This function was well attended, and to meet the demand for a repeat, Swapp and Associates would be hosting Dr. Jane Healey later this month. This conference is to be hosted at Paria Suites on January 14th. Persons interested in further information can contact Swapp and Associates at 732-4897, 741-4001 or 780-4654 \"I am really heartened by the feedback and the fact that a lot of educators want to know more about brain and child development,\" Swapp said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/columnists/tracks-man-run-this-school/article_5859cf5a-5caa-11e9-953c-fb86198766de.html", "TITLE": " \u2018Tracks man run this school\u2019 ", "DATE": "Apr 11, 2019 ", "CONTENT": "The writer is an international journalist based in Port of Spain {{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. The writer is an international journalist based in Port of Spain Sanjaye Shaw has not had it easy. As a three-month albino baby, he was dumped by a roadside in Red Hills, a tough Kingston, Jamaica, neighbourhood. He was left with a diaper and a pack of powdered milk. The woman who found him took him in and raised him, alongside her eleven other children. Even when lunch money was short, his adoptive mother scraped his bus fare to school. In Jamaica\u2019s colour-conscious society, albinos come bottom of the heap. An adopted albino kid in a hard-bitten neighbourhood could easily go under. Instead, Sanjaye passed for Kingston Technical High School, then for Jamaica\u2019s University of Technology. Gleaner columnist Mark Wignall quotes his words: \u201cI cannot even begin to tell you the number of times I have had to fight for things that most people would take for granted. All I do is fight it and move on. I would be a fool to hold grudges for all this time.\u201d Now 33, he has taught physics at Kingston\u2019s Calabar High School for four years. He is articulate, and controlled. He has pushed up the CAPE pass rate from 37 per cent to 100 per cent. When I spoke to him this week, it was after nine at night. He had just finished teaching. So he\u2019s star of the staffroom, darling of the school administration? Nope. In the December school break, he gave up his free time to run a physics camp for his pupils. Who tell him do that? With 63 pupils staying overnight, he needed some of the beds used by the school sports team. After a verbal set-to with sports coaches who weren\u2019t keen to share equipment, Shaw says up to 60 athletes banged on the windows, then \u201cfly the door open\u201d and invaded the physics lab, two of them in the lead. He reports one saying: \u201cTracks man run this school\u2026 A feel like jus\u2019 boxing you up inna you face!\u201d Shaw told his pupils: \u201cSit where you are. Don\u2019t say anything.\u201d He activated his phone\u2019s video camera \u2014the clip is now up there, online. He says one of the athletes \u201cslap my phone out of my hand\u201d cracking the screen; the boys dispute his account. All this sounds to me like a fairly serious breach of discipline, witnessed by 63 pupils, a parent, a guardian, a teacher and a semi-smashed cellphone. Shaw says he tried 19 times that night to contact the acting principal. The school\u2019s reaction next day? Not much. And later? The weeks ticked past. Shaw says the school\u2019s athletes taunted him in the corridors: \u201cCopper-coloured boy,\u201d \u201cYu don\u2019t finish mek yet,\u201d \u201cTake sleep and mark death\u201d and \u201cCoffin for you.\u201d So what sort of a school is Calabar? It was established in 1912 by the Jamaica Baptist Union for children of ministers and poor blacks, A well-known alumnus is former prime minister PJ Patterson. Another is Adijah \u201cVybz Kartel\u201d Palmer, former \u201cWorld Boss\u201d of Jamaican dance-hall, and now serving a jail term for murder. Like T&T, Jamaica has prestige schools. Calabar is kind of semi-prestige in academics, ranking 39th on its CSEC five-passes results. But the school is super-prestige in athletics. In Usain Bolt\u2019s homeland, athletics counts big. Shaw was told the athletes could not be disciplined: \u201cThese boys are ambassadors of the school.\u201d Well yes, they\u2019ve put Calabar on Jamaica\u2019s front pages these past weeks. After months of dithering, the two apparent ringleaders of the December attack were in March suspended for one week. They were allowed to work on CSEC school-based assessments and continue athletics training. One competed in a national sports event, the Digicel Grand Prix. So, let\u2019s say, a semi-suspension. They were also told \u201cseverely\u201d they should not have gone into the physics lab. Three weeks ago, Shaw went public. He filed a formal police report. He went to a big-time English-origin lawyer, Lord Gifford. He held a press conference. The story hit the media. But he held back from pressing charges. Days after the row surfaced came the Boys\u2019 and Girls\u2019 Athletics Championships\u2014the \u201cChamps.\u201d That event is huge in Jamaica. Held in the national stadium, it pulls mass TV audiences. Calabar\u2019s team had won the big prize seven years in a row. This year they came second, 80 points behind Kingston College. Who was blamed for the loss? Yep, you guessed right. Shaw heard death threats: \u201cHands steady with the \u2018matic,\u201d that sort of thing. In Jamaica, as in T&T, automatic gun threats from street-smart adolescents have to be taken seriously. On Monday last week, the assembled students showed their frustration as they waited for morning devotions. \u201cKC a batty-boy school\u201d went the chant, from sixth formers and juniors alike. Check it: there\u2019s a viral video clip online. A well-established rival school gets a formal apology. Next day, Calabar\u2019s principal, acting principal, head boy and seven other students made their way to Kingston College to express regrets. The school\u2019s Board said the chanting was \u201cabhorrent.\u201d Students were called to a special assembly. Board representatives met education ministers and senior officials. There has still been no apology for Sanjaye Shaw. But he\u2019s just an albino boy from Red Hills Road. IN yet another incident which has had the effect of piling \u00adembarrassment upon embarrassment for the authorities, a convict walked out of the Golden Grove facility in Arouca on Thursday, and was on the run up to last night. THE West Indies has had a phenomenal number of exceptional cricketers in its history. The captains have been mostly \u00admiddling. I restricted the playbooks to those of Frank Worrell, Richie Benaud and Mike Brearley simply because they were known as thinking men; able in both the technical and \u201cman-management\u201d aspects of the game. International Youth Day is approaching. It is time for the youth of this country to stand up and make their voices heard. It is time to become more \u00adinvolved in the political process to put an end to the corruption and mismanagement taking place far too often and for too long. Recently, the press \u00adreported that a mother was in tears after her victim impact statement was read out in court during the trial of the accused for her son\u2019s murder. She cried out for answers as to the reason the accused, having robbed her son of his \u00adcellphone, had killed him. While the horizon must seem unrelievedly grim to many citizens, once in a while a few specks of bright light appear to \u00adrelieve the gloom. And so it was \u00adrecently when it was announced that the country\u2019s first drug treatment court was to be established within three months. Regarding the arrest of Minister Marlene McDonald in the ongoing investigation of corruption charges levelled against her, Dr Rowley bought that wholesale. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/get-history-back-into-schools/article_f158414d-d694-514b-a2f3-c56a3fc83c09.html", "TITLE": " Get history back into schools ", "DATE": "Aug 10, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Dr Verene Shepherd, Professor of Social History, at Mona Campus, Jamaica, has said there was an urgent need to reintroduce history into Caribbean schools since students were leaving schools without any solid knowledge about their respective countries' histories. She also said there was the need to go a step further and examine the historiography (systematic review of written history), rewrite the textbooks and erase the prevailing Eurocentric misconceptions. Shepherd made these comments Saturday after delivering the lecture themed In Their Name: Caribbean Women, Slavery and Reparation, at Andre Kamperveen Hall, Centre of Excellence, Macoya, Tunapuna. During the lecture, she had called upon Caribbean goverenments to honour more women as national heroines since they had fought in Emancipation Wars and to ensure they got reparations\u2014including repatriation and resettlement in their homelands if they so desired. Among those present were Aiyegoro Ome, chairman of the National Action Cultural Committee (NACC) vice president of the National Joint Action Committee (NJAC) and Chairman of the T&T National Committee on Reparations. He was joined by Liseli Daaga, wife of Chief Servant Makandal Daaga and Senator Embau Moheni, Minister of State in the Ministry of National Security. Asked to share her sentiments on history being taught in the Caribbean schools, Shepherd said: \"What we have is the rhetoric that social studies is better than history. But what we are getting is the \"watered down\" version. Social studies has a little bit of economics, geography and history. What you find is the students are leaving school without a grounding in history. Unless they choose to do history as a subject for CXC, then there is no real emphasis on learning and studying history.\" Shepherd added: \"The Ministers of Education in the region would do well to make it a compulsory subject. It's sad they are leaving school without a clear knowledge about their history whether it is African, Indian or Portugese. There is the need for them to develop that sense of self-esteem and appreciation for their backgrounds. It is important for the development of their respective countries. We need to get back history into the schools.\" The Caribbean historiography is entrenched in colonialism, Indentureship and the Emancipation experiences. Shepherd said there was the need to revisit the historiography. She added: \"We have to do the textbook research and look at the Eurocentric view. We must look at the curriculum. We must also look at the selection of our textbooks and what is being taught to our children. We need to let our children know that Timbuktu is not a fictional place. It is a real place in Africa. There was a gold trade in Africa. The progress on the African continent was interrupted with the Trans Atlantic Slave Trade. It is something Caricom needs to address because many times children and young people don't want to associate themselves with anything African.\" She also paid kudos to Trinidad and Tobago for being the first country to celebrate Emancipation Day. Shepherd recommended students of history and adults to read prominent Guyanese historian Walter Rodney's (How Europe Underdeveloped Africa), Frantz Fanon (Black Skins: White Masks), Lucille Mathurin Mair, the late CLR James Black Jacobins and the late Dr Eric Williams' Capitalism and Slavery. She will deliver a lecture on the contribution of Walter Rodney, at the University of Warwick, England, on October 28. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/call-for-health-family-life-education-in-schools/article_8fc6b010-f018-51b3-a385-73d06777051f.html", "TITLE": " Call for health, family life education in schools ", "DATE": "Dec 1, 2008 ", "CONTENT": "A call has been made for the Ministry of Education to implement the Caricom-sanctioned Health and Family Life Education (HFLE) Programme in the nation's schools. The call comes in light of the fact that HIV/AIDS remains prevalent among the 15 to 19 age group, who youth activist Nicole Hendrickson said are many times misinformed on health and family life issues by their peers. Speaking at the North Central Regional Health Authority's (NCRHA) HIV/AIDS commemorative seminar at the Eric Williams Medical Sciences Complex (EWMSC) in Mt Hope last week, she said: \"Caricom Heads came together recognising the situation in terms of the STI and other things that affect young people and came up with a document that is Caricom-sanctioned and is supposed to be implemented, but we have been having some challenges getting it implemented in our school system.\" She added, \"We are asking the persons in authority... Ministry of Education, to implement something that is sound, that does not only include sexual education. It includes physics, it includes consumer health, it includes things on the environment... it's a comprehensive document. \"But we have recognised that because there is a sexual education component in it, we have been having some battles in having it implemented.\" She added that although Family Planning Association (FPA) data pinpoints the age of sexual initiation in Trinidad and Tobago as 14, a couple of years ago the age of sexual initiation had been identified as eight. From the data, she said, it is believed that the curbing of vertical transmission of HIV can be done by giving children age-appropriate sexual information, starting with the correct names of parts of their bodies. Dr Jeffrey Edwards, who also spoke at the seminar, looked at the basics of HIV/AIDS, which included its history and how the numbers of cases increased over the years, as well as the progression in treatment of the virus. (See Page 22) Other speakers included Dr Beni Balkaran, senior lecturer in Child Health at the University of the West Indies, who looked at developments in treatment for paediatric HIV locally. World AIDS Day was commemorated yesterday. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/sex-education-should-be-part-of-school-curriculum/article_18c92051-1cfb-5878-b35d-4a5f623ba0ed.html", "TITLE": " Sex education should be part of school curriculum ", "DATE": "Dec 8, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "\u0091IT IS A BASIC RIGHT\u0092: Dr Babatunde Osotimehin delivers a lecture on Adolescent Pregnancy titled \u0093Motherhood in Childhood\u0094 at the Learning Resource Centre at the University of the West Indies, St Augustine, yesterday. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE \u0091IT IS A BASIC RIGHT\u0092: Dr Babatunde Osotimehin delivers a lecture on Adolescent Pregnancy titled \u0093Motherhood in Childhood\u0094 at the Learning Resource Centre at the University of the West Indies, St Augustine, yesterday. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE COMPREHENSIVE sexual education should be a part of a school curriculum, according to executive director of the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) and under-secretary of the United Nations, Dr Babatunde Osotimehin. As part of the University of the West Indies' distinguished open lecture series, Osotimehin is in Trinidad where he addressed an audience at the Learning Resource Centre at the UWI St Augustine campus yesterday on the topic \"Motherhood in Childhood. Facing the challenge of adolescent pregnancy.'' \"We at the UNFPA believe that comprehensive sexual education must be a part of education. The ability for the girl to understand, the ability for the girl to access correct information and the ability for the girl to access services if she does require it is a basic right she must have,\"stressed Osotimehin. Each day in developing countries 20,000 girls below the age of 18 give birth and each year 7.3 million girls give birth below the age of 18. Out of this number two million are under the age of 14, according to the latest report on the state of the world population compiled by the UNFPA. The rates of adolescent pregnancy in the Caribbean are among the highest in the world. The issue of comprehensive sexual education in schools is a contentious one, says Osotimehin but he contends that girls who are in school should be able to access information about contraceptives. He has seen first hand the benefits of such programmes. He was the director general of the Nigerian National Agency for the Control of AIDS which coordinates all HIV and AIDS work in a country of about 160 million people. In that position, Osotimehin established sexual education programmes throughout Nigeria. The result was that the uptake of information was high. What Osotimehin also observed was that these programmes also empowered girls and many started abstinence clubs in their schools. Osotimehin stated that in developed countries which have comprehensive sexual education that have delivered universal access to information and services with regards to contraception, the number of teen pregnancy cases decreased, whereas countries where this is absent, there are high rates of unsafe abortions and suicides. Osotimehin said the UNFPA is working with Caricom on the issue of adolescent pregnancy and key strategies to address it. Some of these strategies include sexual education programmes in schools, public policies at sub-regional levels to address gender equality and gender-based violence such as rape and incest and policies which ensure that girls go to school and stay in school. \"We know for a fact that when girls go to school and stay in school up to the age of 18 they tend not to have children and when they do, they have fewer children and they are able to make decisions for themselves,\" he said. Osotimehin served as Minister of Health in Nigeria prior to his appointment at the UNFPA in 2011. In recognition of his contributions as a leader of Nigeria's response to HIV and AIDS he was awarded the national honour of Officer of the Order of the Niger (OON) in 2005. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/saving-the-children/article_16e1b798-3d24-5876-957e-70fe8a780e10.html", "TITLE": " Saving the children ", "DATE": "Jun 29, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "A society can be judged not by how many tall towers it has, not by its GDP nor by its wealthbut by how it treats its people and, more so, how it treats the most vulnerable in its midst. Being vulnerable means being highly exposed to risks of death, disease, violence, abuse, torture, discrimination and all the like. It is a state of being at the fringes of society, the last to receive the benefits of the state and the first to bear the brunt of any fallout. At-risk or vulnerable groups are usually thought of as minorities, including the physically or mentally challenged, drug addicts, sexual minorities, etc, and to a large extent this is true. However, children are probably one of the most vulnerable groups in any society and yet they are far from constituting a minority. Children, for all of the rhetoric that is thrown around as being \"the future\", \"the leaders of tomorrow\", \"our joys\", etc, are exposed to levels of violence and are devoid of rights and protections in many societies to the point that they are dehumanised. Across the globe, children die by the thousands every day from starvation, dehydration, diseases, in war as victims or child soldiers, and in numerous other unspeakably horrible ways. Children are abused and tortured sexually and physically, girls and boys as young as three are sold in the sex trade or as house slaves. They are made to work in factories in India and Thailand to make the shirts and scarves we in the West wear; their broken, fragile bodies are the ones that keep the wheels of our consumer society turning. It is their tears, sweat and blood that keep us comfortable and happy. In Trinidad and Tobago, the situation may not be ideal but it is more than a million times better than across the vast majority of the global South. Children here, unlike the millions in the Philippines, do not have to eke out a living from the dumps and the drains. They, unlike the pre-teen girls and boys in the former USSR, have not been sold into the sex trade. They do not have to worry about being kidnapped and chopped into pieces for body parts for rituals and bush magic as in some parts of Africa. We are doing remarkably well as a developing nation. Guaranteeing education, books and nutrition up to secondary school is a monumental achievement and we must be extremely proud of this. The strides we have made toward universal education may seem \"normal\" to us, but across much of the globe education is a luxury afforded to a special few. There are millions of children in the Favelas of Brazil or the slums of India who have never been to school, do not even know what school is and are part of the drug trade or working ten hours a day for one US dollar to feed their families. There is, however, room for much improvement. Though we are part of the UN with its Universal Declaration of the Rights of a Child, we are far from implementing all of them. Children, unlike what some religious books say, are not property. First and foremost this must be understood, there is a tendency for much of the parenting populous to make the assumption; \"that is my child and I can do as I please\". Nothing can be further form the truth; a child belongs to the country, they are first and foremost citizens and, as a nation, we have a collective responsibility to ensure the well-being of every child within our territory and, as global citizens, all the children of the world. As a people we need to begin to understand that children have rights and among these rights are the rights to food and shelter, the right to be safe and the right to be heard. Too often most of us are continuing to believe children are to be spoken at and not with. It is not part of our child-rearing culture to talk with our children and consider their input: \"parents know best\" is an obsolete ethos with which to raise children. Apart from political rights many children in our country are still going to bed hungry due to poor families or other socio-economic factors. In a land of plenty, no child should have to do without the basics. The lack of proper parental planning and reproductive education is a sore point and until it is addressed children will suffer. It is a common refrain from most people that the \"poorest people have the most children\". This may, however, be an inaccurate statement as poverty may not be the element that we need to look at, as many rural families can take care of children quite well despite lacking orthodox measures of wealth. The problem lies with procreation by teenage mothers, abused mothers and sex workers, all of whom are vulnerable themselves and create a new generation of children to continue on the vicious cycle of suffering, poverty and exploitation. Social services for children and these vulnerable parents are one of the best ways to reduce the suffering of children. Thus children may make a great background to take pictures with for elections and they may make good political ploys, but they are not just to be used and left on their own. They are indeed our future, their condition is our condition. Right now the crime plaguing our nation is most times being perpetrated by youths and children, most under the age of 25. Just a few years ago they were young children, the violence and neglect many suffered are now being meted out to us as a country. We need to wake up and care for every single child, to make sure they are happy and well taken care of, protected and loved. We may bring children into the world, but they make our futuresit is high time we realise this. Rajiv Gopie won the President's Medal in 2006 for business/modern studies. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/too-much-schooling-too-little-education/article_257c0027-b3f0-5078-989e-56ca9b70b983.html", "TITLE": " Too much schooling, too little education ", "DATE": "Oct 21, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "I wish to make a rejoinder to the article written by Prof Noel Kallicharan, in the Express of Tuesday, October 18, titled \"A 'papered' society, not an educated one\". The professor has raised an issue which is central to the education system in Trinidad and Tobago and which we need to deal with as a major issue in education reform at all levels of the society from early childhood, straight through to university. I wholly agree with the professor that we have a certification crisis, and people who may have acquired certification have not benefited from the processes of development in skill and intellectual growth that the certification implies. The professor confines his argument to the tertiary level and argues that it is a matter of falling standards and institutional failure. Examinations are being \"dumbed down\" by some tertiary-level institutions, in order to jack up pass rates in the quest for profit. People with false certification are serving as teachers of the young, and the solution is that the authorities must become stricter about management of the system. I would like to add some thoughts to this issue of certification and education. My main concern is that this is not a matter affecting only tertiary level nor is it only about the weaker institutions at the tertiary level. This is a matter central to all arrangements for education in Trinidad and Tobago. It affects strong schools more than weak schools and is perhaps more infectious to those who pass than those who fail. The race for certification and the quest for passing is the main driving force in the school system, and it subverts the education processfrom primary to university. As someone who has been involved in the preparation of teachers for both the primary and secondary school systems in Trinidad and Tobago, I would like, in this article, to simply explain how teaching and learning are compromised by the quest for certification and, consequently, why we do not promote sufficient innovative or critical thinking in our classrooms. Completion of the syllabus, it seems, has become a serious challenge, and perhaps the sole purpose of schooling at all levels of the system, and I include the university level as well, as lecturers and teachers struggle to get in the coursemarks and the lecture sessions. At the primary level, if you show a teacher ways to engage children, get them involved in groups, manipulate materials, shade and draw or observe and experiment, they do it all while in training or under observation. Some honest teachers will actually confide in you that if they taught that way in their school, they would not be able to complete the syllabus. And if they are from a school that has a reputation in SEA (Secondary Entrance Assessment) to upkeep, then notes, practice and drills win out. Early-childhood teachers are now faced with the predicament where they are told that they are not preparing children well for primary school because they have not learned enough about numbers and reading and are unprepared for the long hours of seatwork or the harsh discipline. Primary school and SEA are, therefore, subverting the true nature of early childhood care and education (ECCE). Child development loses out as a result. Of course, at the secondary level, the story is the same. Any talk with teachers about discussion in the classroom, group work, problem-solving and case method is usually met with strong reservations or downright resistance. They explain that this would slow them down and they would not be able to finish the syllabus. They concede that they will do it while they are engaged in the teacher preparation programme but do not see how they can implement those approaches in their job. Exam preparation trumps all else. At the University of the West Indies (UWI), I suspect the story is the same. Do students get the opportunity to develop deep understanding of the subject matter How does the pressure of getting in the 40 per cent coursework affect the delivery of courses How do very large classes impact on teaching and learning Is there time to really explore and excite students So at all levels of the system, product wins out over process, and we end up with the situation that even those who pass are not able to display the creativity and imagination necessary to solve our problems. While it may be an issue all over the world, it is one that is having fatal consequences here at home. We need serious public discussion on this issue. Many educators have spoken and written about it. The title chosen for this article is the title of an article written by Lloyd Best years ago. What we have not been able to do is to agree on a way out. The report provides analysis and recommendations from over 70 experts in more than 50 countries on global trends in corruption in education, understanding the scale of corruption in school education, transparency and integrity in higher education, innovative approaches to tackling corruption in education. The results demonstrate that if we ramp up the fight against corruption in education, more children will stay in school and meet literacy and development goals. It will prepare the next generation to say no to corruption. The report also details numerous practical steps to prevent the abuse of power, bribery and secret dealings from corroding the education-al experience. \"For schools to educate the corruption-fighters of tomorrow, they need to be free from corruption themselves. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/school-psychologist/article_6d4ce291-e8a5-55d1-8931-51a3c62378a4.html", "TITLE": " SCHOOL PSYCHOLOGIST ", "DATE": "Aug 29, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "Raquel Matthews. Photos: Curtis Chase Raquel Matthews. Photos: Curtis Chase Twenty-six-year-old Raquel Matthews is a newbie in the area of school psychology, and how she got there makes for an interesting story. A resident of Goodwood Gardens, Diego Martin, Matthews started off at Savonetta Private School and went on to Holy Faith Convent, Penal where she attained seven 1s and a 2 in her CXC exams; she studied English A, English B, History, Principles of Business, Social Studies, Integrated Science, Geography and Mathematics. From there, she completed a year of cape at the same high school and then went on to Plattsburgh State University of New York where she majored in psychology with a minor in cultural anthropology. She now holds her MA and CAS in school psychology. But school psychology is not what Matthews had in mind, initially; it is not where she had thought she would find herself. In fact, she told me during the interview that, when I was younger, I wanted to be a dentist. But when I started Form 3, I had problems with integrated science. While she attained a 1 in integrated science in her CXC exams and it was a hard-earned 1 the sciences just were not her thing. So she had to find another niche. At school, I was angelic, she began in an effort to explain how she went from wanting to be a dentist to now being a school psychologist, but at home, I threw temper tantrums. I had a lot of problems with my family. I had a lot of therapy as a result; and throughout the course of my therapy, in observing the interaction between my psychologist and my family, and between my psychologist and myself, I grew to admire that interaction and began thinking about getting into that field. Without much ado, Matthews got on the Internet and began researching the field of psychology. She noted that she had googled education and psychology and was displeased with the information that she got back; however, there was a link, in the midst of all the information that she had gotten back that caught her attention. It was a link to school psychology. Her decision was made and in 2005, she flew out to the United States to begin her studies in psychology coupled with a minor in cultural anthropology at Plattsburgh. In her first year as an undergraduate and to fulfill her practicum, she worked as an aid to children in a pre-school. In my second year, I worked in a middle school and it was much more hands-on, counseling and leading social skills group. I remember that my first major test that year was dealing with a bipolar student and it was particularly harrowing because bipolar children can cycle in a day. Adults tend to take longer, she asserted. She completed three years of practical work and each year served to endear her more to her chosen field of study, and so, her chosen career path. Matthews returned to Trinidad and Tobago on June 5, 2012 and took up work at IAG & Associates where she worked closely with Isolde Ali Ghent and two clinical psychologists. I was offered a job at a high-school in Orlando where I did a full internship in my third year of practicum, but saw that there was a great need here for school psychologists; so I chose to return. That is not to say there is not a great need for school psychologists in the United States as well, but I prefer to return to my country and help out, she affirmed. And she has been doing just that. However, she is no longer with IAG & Associates. Driven by ambition, she has now set up her own practice in Palmiste, San Fernando and has her own clinical psychologist, Lydia Moujet-Ramcharam on her team. We work as a team and essentially, our company provides comprehensive psycho-educational evaluations, assist schools in identifying students they are concerned about and provide appropriate interventions. The big hurdle for us is getting out there, she said. I want people to know I am there; I charge the minimum fee $5,000 but I also take payment plans. Also, we do social skills groups for children with Asbergers and ADHD. We also do emotional literacy groups. Anyone interested in contacting Matthews can do so at raqsmatt@gmail.com. Haiti will improve education for as many as 360,000 children from preschool through grade nine with aUS$50 million grantfrom the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB). The grant will fund the building of new schools, tuition-free primary education, student health programmes, and strengthen theMinistry of Education and Professional Training (MENFP) and its executing agencies. Twenty new public schools will be built, benefitting 8,200 children from preschool through grade 9. When completed, these schools will include equipped libraries, sanitary facilities, a school canteen, energy and water systems, and be made accessible to disabled children. The grant will also subsidise education expenses for 35,000 children attending primary non-public schools for two school years. The IDB contribution adds resources to an existing tuition waiver program, which is co-financed by the government of Haiti, theCaribbean Development Bank,CIDA, theGlobal Partnership for Education, and theWorld Bank. The programme is expected to increase retention and contribute to Haiti's goal of providing free and universal education to all six to 12 year olds by 2015. In addition the US$50 million will fund bi-annual deworming campaigns in schools for 300,000 children and support 100 schools which enroll 15,000 children in achieving a \"Hygiene Friendly\" certification.School dewormingis a simple and inexpensive yet highly cost-effective intervention. Hygiene Friendly certified schools will contribute to children's health through prevention of water-borne diseases and promotion of good hygienic practices. Another component is technical assistance to the Ministry of Education to further develop and structure interventions aimed at expanding literacy skills and strengthening the institutional capacity of the MENFP to implement its 2010-2015 Education Plan and regulate non-public schools. This will include reconstruction of MENFP offices, upgrading of information systems, and procedures for school accreditation. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/deadly-impetus-for-school-reform/article_1568f3b3-8e55-5f63-a21e-26359053c2a8.html", "TITLE": " Deadly impetus for school reform ", "DATE": "May 15, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " It has taken the death of an innocent for us at least to talk about the need for reflection on the education system. As the family of Devindra Boodoo mourns, searching for questions, having done all the society told them they should do to get their boy ready for the next stage of his education, out from the woodwork comes the Trinidad and Tobago Unified Teachers Association (TTUTA), the Minister of Education, the principals, all of them just like that, talking about the need for change, as though the issue is new. But when the mourning ends they will all go back to silence. They like it so. For four years this minister has been talking about removing the Secondary Entrance Assessment (SEA) exam. But this is all carray and no bois. This same minister decreed that all extra-curricular aspects of the curriculum are to be delivered after school. He does not have a concept of a holistic curriculum, nor a vision of education for citizenship. As a man who is a medical doctor and who also made a Trinidad and Tobago 11 in cricket, he has a surprisingly conservative view of the curriculum. It is not just the minister. The churches are indicted on the count of actively participating in a system that lacks compassion for the multitude of children who come to school and who must take major exams starting a few feet behind the actual starting line. All of the attention is on the first choice children as though the rest of them are not our children too. It is not pure ability that causes most of the children who get their first choice to do well; it is the luck of the draw. I spent most of the last week at a conference in Bangalore, India, sponsored by Azim Premjie University, where much of the focus was on inequality in the Indian education system. One of the presenters, Prof Heredia, Fellow of the Indian Social Institute, New Delhi, said, eerily, and almost verbatim that \"In India we train children for exams, and when they fail they commit suicide\". He went on to say that people cannot be held responsible for achievements or choices when it comes to education. Nor can they be held responsible for natural gifts or talents they have or don't have. The role of governments, he said, was to strive to improve the condition of the poor. \"We cannot have fair competition in education if we do not neutralise starting conditions. The concept of a meritocracy should not apply in education.\" In India, the concern is that many poor people are forced to expend their scarce resources to remove their children from public schools to private schools, just to try to get them the English-based, high status education that companies prefer. The concerns are compounded by the very recent ruling of the Supreme Court of India that the government cannot impose a language, including the mother tongue, as the medium of instruction for primary education. Scholars are aghast at this ruling. In Singapore, for example, instruction must be bilingual, students being exposed to both English and a native language. Anuraj Behar, vice chancellor of Azim Premjie University, said in opening the conference, that in India some 30 per cent of children are now attending private schools, a percentage he said that is one of the highest in the world, and is shameful because it places the country in the company of failed states. Indian scholars at the conference, for which one of the themes was social justice in education, felt that the state should have as one of its primary goals the levelling of the playing field so that children come to the starting line of schooling without advantages or disadvantages that accrue mainly by the chance of who their parents are. Children do not pick their parents, just as they do not pick their race or gender. They find themselves born, some of them in homes where no one has ever done well at secondary school, some with homes without fathers, or without surplus income that could be spent on educational materials. In colonial times, these differences at birth were mapped onto schooling. When St Mary's College and Queen's Royal College were established in the 1860s, entry to them was on the basis of skin colour or privilege. Local children, like V S Naipaul, Eric Williams, CLR James and others, could attend these schools only by placing at the top in the College Exhibition. The elite got to attend school by virtue of colour, the masses by winning an educational tournament. Even though we have schools for all now, we still keep the tournament, knowing that those with the requisite social capital will win. But the 1860s are long gone. (Concludes on Monday). \u2022 Theodore Lewis is professor emeritus, University of Minnesota. Professor Theodore Lewis In this second part of my series on the global resurgence of investment in pre-schooling, I focus on examples of this in selected developed and developing countries. The origins of this notion of educating small children might be the thought and practice of multiple great educators. Jean Piaget described cognition in children based on stages of development. Froebel noticed that brain growth is at its peak between birth and age three. In every culture, children learn the language by age two. In many countries, including most of Europe and in Singapore, small children are versed in more than one language. Rousseau believed in the idea of freedom in the early education of children. Pestalozzi emphasised activity-learning, involving hand and head. Lev Vygotsky introduced the notion of social learning. Learning takes place when conditions come together at what he called the \u201czone of proximal development\u201d. The child has to be psychologically ready for what is to be taught. Countries are understanding that the superstructure is only as solid as its foundation. Early childhood education influences later ability to learn. In England in 2003 a national system, called the Early Years Foundation Stage Profile, was introduced. It requires the assessment of children at age five in six areas of learning, ranging over social and emotional development, language and communication, problem-solving, knowledge and understanding of the world, physical development, and creative development. This has become the \u201cEarly Years Foundation Profile\u201d. The results are provided to parents. We see the great push to pre-schools in Europe where there is resolve to universalise early childhood care and education (ECCE). This can be seen in the European Union, reflected in the publication, Key Data on Early Childhood Education and Care in Europe. The European Commission, which authored this 2014 document, explained that early childhood was the stage at which education has the greatest effect on children\u2019s learning. It was noted in the report that only eight countries in Europe had thus far made the commitment to provide an early childhood place for all children, by legal entitlement. These were Denmark, Germany, Estonia, Malta, Slovenia, Finland, Sweden and Norway. In the United States, there has been an upsurge in early childhood education, much of it having to do with the passage of the No Child Left Behind Act (NCLB, 2002). The pre-kindergarten (PRE-K) movement is an outgrowth of this focus on early education. The coalition is comprised of organisations including the National Association of State Boards of Education, National Education Association, and American Association of School Administrators. It has set forth as policy that all three- and four-year-old children should have access to high-quality education. In support of the renewed focus on early childhood education in the US, the National Research Council has published the document, Preventing Reading Difficulties in Young Children. This work drew on the contributions of leading researchers and deals extensively with the challenges that could impair a small child\u2019s ability to learn to read. It is made widely available on the internet. The Asian countries that perform so well on international academic tests do not now have a similar reputation where early childhood education is concerned. This is an area of education that policy makers in countries such as Singapore and South Korea have in recent times been according greater focus. These countries have found themselves with a dual system approach (day-care versus pre-school) that they are seeking to resolve. This dual approach can be seen across Asia, not just in Singapore, but in Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam. ECCE efforts are on the rise in Africa. One researcher pointed to challenges as Nigeria tried to meet UNESCO goals. Initially the government left pre-primary education to the private sector, but more recently has moved toward state involvement, consistent with an early childhood policy framework. Peculiarities of the African context for establishing ECCE in Africa can be observed. A 2017 study of ECCE in Ghana examined the perceptions of parents about pre-schooling. One parent explained that the purpose of ECCE for her child was \u201cSo that his mind will open.\u201d We get a sense of ECCE in India through a longitudinal study done by Dr Venita Kaul and her colleagues. They followed a cohort of 14,000 children for four years across three states in India. They noted that there are 1.3 million early childhood centres known as Anganwadis, across the country. The authors explain that the centres offer holistic packages of services for pregnant and lactating women, and children between ages three and six. They serve 82 million out of the 158 million children below age six. Closer home, in the Latin America and Caribbean region, there has been movement in ECCE. In a 1993 article, in the International Journal of Educational Development, Fernando Reimers examined ECCE in the region. Using 1988 as the baseline the percentages of enrolment in pre-school across selected countries was as follows, Cuba 99 per cent, Jamaica, 75 per cent, Guyana 51 per cent, and Trinidad and Tobago, five per cent. In his role as president of the Inter American Bank Luis Moreno in 2016 penned an op-ed in The New York Times making a plea for greater investment in early education in Latin America and the Caribbean, pointing to pre-school home interventions in Jamaica as a demonstrably successful initiative. A 2013 report on Latin America and the Caribbean by UNESCO acknowledged variation in the region but found that net pre-primary enrolment was 11 percentage points higher than the average for other regions in the world. Barbados was striking, showing 90 per cent progress to the goal of universal pre-primary education. THE AUTHOR chaired the cabinet committee on Elementary and pre-school education. Adults underestimate how impressionable young people are. So ask yourself, what lessons the more than 700,000 Jamaican youth are ingesting from the avalanche of suspicions surrounding the dismissal of a minister of education? Who will explain to them what is truth? Who are they to look up to now? What are they to remember after the speeding motorcade of ministerial vehicles, the sirens, the brace of security guards (who are you afraid of anyway?) and the fawning of the ministry officials and incompetent advisers are all stripped away? And even the teachers ... in a profession heavily influenced in tone and trust by a minister, what are they to think? What are they to tell the pickney when his big portrait on every school wall is suddenly and disgracefully removed? A little counsel: Flashiness and show; stush, self-congratulatory bashes at Jewels, on the yacht and elsewhere are not what good governance and effective \u00adservanthood make. Better to deal with the substance than the protocol. Just look at how \u2018braff\u2019 and lavish turn into the smelly stuff. Who paid for all the partisan extravagance anyway? The whole sector is now \u00addemoralised by the circumstances surrounding the departure of its leader and the discrediting \u00adsuspicions around several of the education-related \u00adagencies. I grieve particularly for the Caribbean Maritime University (CMU), up to now a beacon of the kind of disciplined education and training most needed by poorly socialised pupils and most suitable for our global workforce needs. The CMU is too important to have any cloud of nepotism or corruption hanging over its leadership. Full and complete answers to all the questions regarding its connection with the Ruel Reid Foundation, any hiring of relatives, concubines and party hacks; full details of all contracts involving the ministry, are needed this week. They are already late! Next, please do not ignore the unease of individuals and organisations in the diaspora concerned about how monies donated through the National Education Trust are spent. Who decides which schools are favoured? Why could vastly more money be found to advance schools in NW St Ann but not for every other constituency whose schools are equally needy? Check SE Clarendon as one example. The evidence is available, as is the obvious corruption of priorities. Then, new revelations constrain a return to the question of why the cash-rich HEART Trust was removed from the Ministry of Education, but with almost a billion available for the Career Advancement Programme, trickled through to a myriad of institutions, many with little instructional capacity but with impeccable party connections. What about the self-respect of each of the boards of these \u00adagencies? Should they remain? Inevitably, the mess at the Ministry of Education will slow down the vital process of educational transformation. The Government had already decided that major advances in education are not its priority for the next four years. Just look at the budget and the forward projections through to 2022. Who can now say when the Jamaica Teaching Council Bill will be brought into law? And who on the government bench, other than former minister Holness, can understand and then engineer this critical change of teacher accountability? Who is the strong, inspirational leader who will redress the situation Richard Azan, fruitlessly, put to Ruel Reid and solutionless bureaucrats at the Standing Finance Committee two weeks ago? One depopulated school in Azan\u2019s constituency (and there are scores more like this elsewhere) has less than 100 pupils and nine teachers, who are tenured there and cannot be moved. But there is a nearby school bursting with over 1,000 pupils and lacking as many teachers as the other has oversupply. Nothing is being done to correct this. Such anomalies hurt innocent pupils. And this is but one instance, among many, immediately requiring trusted leadership; bold, concensus-building skills and strong powers of persuasion in an indifferent Cabinet and an \u00aduninformed public. At a more than two-hour, \u00adthorough interrogation of the ministry\u2019s budget at the Standing Finance Committee, Michael Stewart and I deliberately never took on issues about the minister\u2019s personal or political activity despite the many questions already in the public sphere. But how could it have been that other members of the governing party knew nothing and had no questions about the \u00adeducation spend? And have we missed the trenchant comments about education and training \u00adpriorities from the teaching \u00adprofession, whose leadership, of late, had become so indistinguishably aligned to the then minister? All this confusion and \u00adcorruption should never happen. Not in education! The author is member of parliament for Kingston Central and opposition spokesman on education and training. Professor Theodore Lewis I intend to characterise the global resurgence of interest and investment in pre-schools, under the general rubric ECCE (Early Childhood Care and Education), and to alert the populace, especially people of humble circumstances to seize every opportunity to send off their children off to pre-school at age three. I have a vivid recollection of my mother dropping me off at a pre-school downstairs of one of the planning buildings on Nelson Street at about age three, before heading to her stall in the George Street market. It was 1950-51. When my uncle who lived in Marabella adopted me at four, he continued the practice. I went to Miss Cross\u2019 private school across the street. Along with her fighting spirit, that is all my mother who died in 1980 bequeathed to me. I thank her immensely for it. I thank my uncle, who died in 2002, for making my humble education his duty. My daughter went to the university pre-school at Wisconsin. When we returned home to T&T, she continued at Happy Vale Pre-School in Diamond Vale. My granddaughter Olivia, who is about to turn six, attended two pre-schools in Maryland before starting kindergarten. She cracked the reading code at four and is an avid, fluent reader. She attends a kindergarten run by the African Methodist Episcopal Church in Maryland. The teachers praise the children there at every turn and believe in their ability. All children can be fluent early readers and that skill is key to their later academic development. The key is that parents and guardians must be made aware of this and strive to enable it. Teachers must be virtuous, ethical and beyond reproach. This nonsense I heard in our pre-schools about not pushing small children too hard really is what they tell black people. Early education is the key for that poor child. Teach him to read early. That must be the primary purpose of our pre-schools. Children can get \u201csocialisation\u201d in the yard, with hop-scotch and bat and ball. That\u2019s the co-curriculum. Teaching small children to read does not hurt or injure them. Get fun books, lots of books, and praise them at every turn. Read to them about the planets, the moon, crabs, iguanas, flamingoes, frogs, fishes, spiders, monkeys, going to the market. I make regular readings on all of these things and email to my daughter, for my granddaughter\u2019s pleasure. The Internet is loaded with images, including cartoons, to support such readings. One hour after a giraffe is born it has to be running, because the lions are coming. Adult Chinese immigrants here are learning English through their very small children. I went to a Chinese restaurant a couple of years ago, and the mother sent her small son of about four to the counter to chat with me. The boy asked me if I had been to university. In clear English. He was the translator in that restaurant. He was attending pre-school. Across the globe there is now a raging new revolution in education focused on pre-school attendance. Countries are frantically placing resources and effort into creating ECCE centres where children can spend the two early years between ages three and five readying themselves for kindergarten. Economist and Nobel Laureate James Heckman has advocated such investment. In 2006 he wrote in an article titled \u201cSkill formation and the economics of investing in disadvantaged children\u201d in the journal Science that \u201cInvesting in disadvantaged young children is a rare public policy initiative that promotes fairness and social justice and at the same time promotes productivity in the economy and in society at large.\u201d He continued: \u201cEarly interventions targeted toward disadvantaged children have much higher returns than interventions \u2026such as ... convict rehabilitation programmes, or expenditure on police.\u201d In other words, pre-school is a sounder economic and social intervention than Life Sport. This is because Early Childhood Development ...strongly influences basic learning, school success, economic participation, social citizenry, and health.\u201d What should be taught in the pre-school? Professor Theodore Lewis MANY aspects of this society proceed on the momentum of the past. Memory is stored in the civil service, or the teaching service. These do not change when governments change so past practices endure. But any society that has continuity as a default will find that it becomes intellectually atrophied. I went back to the campus at University of Minnesota late last year, the second time I had gone back since leaving there in 2008. I stayed in the campus hotel, and I found that when I went for breakfast no one was paying with cash. The students were just walking up to the cashier and producing their cell phones. Even my credit card felt like a relic. Washington Avenue on the fringes of the campus now accommodated not just vehicular traffic but light rail. These developed societies are premised on constant change. But we are a static society here, clinging to colonial memory, and because we are thus, we are a retrogressive society that invents nothing. My target here is education. And what do we have to show for our guiding logic here? We go to our oracle Sat Maharaj, our most influential educator, and he brings out The Concordat of 1960. But wasn\u2019t that before independence? The current Minister on assuming his post promised that the Concordat would be left intact. Now Sat is on the radio, and they are complaining. What kind of cars were people driving in 1960 when the Concordat was made? Where I lived, we had a latrine at the back. Of all things in a society, education cannot be moribund. It is education, and the human capital it produces that moves you into the future. Education is responsible for the kinds of dynamism we see in the more recently developed societies, such as South Korea, China, Singapore, Japan. It is education that has pushed Finland into the limelight. Samsung, Kia, and Nokia are products of human ingenuity and progressive education systems. These brands were not around in 1960. When your education system remains parked in 1960, we should not be surprised that the society itself is parked there, and that someone returning here after 40 years abroad would find no trouble getting around. Nothing has changed. Had Patrick Manning not built those towers, our capital city would have remained stuck in the era of Jean and Dinah. There has been some talk recently about the SEA. The problem is that schools are sites of a proxy war. My child versus your child. You do not hear wholesome progressive talk about what schooling is about. The doors of the prized schools are closed to many. There is a famous image from the United Sates in the 1960s of some black children being escorted by federal marshals as they entered a school yard, with a menacing crowd surrounding them and jeering. We have that attitude here. In the anthem we say every creed and race finds and equal place. But when it comes to education, we have first choice and second choice. Some secondary schools offer chemistry. Most do not. Some offer A-Levels, most do not. So, we have an uneven school system that it takes no special training to see. Our primary schools hold a competition to determine which secondary schools children will attend. In Finland they say all schools must be good. No need for competition. Just pick one and send your child. In this country we say let\u2019s keep the good schools scarce, and let the children battle on SEA day. So, if a child does not pass for a school that offers additional mathematics or chemistry at A-Level, it\u2019s the child\u2019s fault. But if you look at the SEA, you see that we do not examine science. If a subject is not examinable it will not be taken seriously by teachers. So science is not a high priority in our primary schools. But the private sector does not complain, because they don\u2019t need scientifically literate workers. You do not need scientists for fried chicken and coffee. But science is an extremely high priority in the serious countries of the world. The TIMMS results in science for 2015 for children ages 9-10 show that 47 countries took part. Some 4,000 children from each country took the exam. The top seven countries and the average score of their children were as follows: 1. Singapore \u2014 590; 2. South Korea \u2014 589; 3. Japan \u2014 569; 4. Russian Federation \u2014 567; 5 Hong Kong \u2014 557; 6. Taiwan \u2014 555; 7. Finland \u2014 554. Other countries of interest here were United States \u2014 546; England \u2014 536; and Canada \u2014 525. This is academic Olympics. And you see Finland at number 7 in the world. We are not there, because science is not offered at competitive level here. We can\u2019t even be in the competition. But having science in the elementary school is a reason why Koreans could make Samsung phones, and the Finnish could make Nokia. We are known for the volume of fried chicken they buy on the Lara promenade. In England they have long abandoned the eleven-plus selection examination. They had up to 1300 grammar schools in the mid-1960\u2019s now there are 163. They have multiple ways in which a child can do A-Levels. We must do more to strengthen this partnership; to create conditions/places of high quality teaching and learning that will allow each child to realise his/her potential. Pope Francis stated: \u201cEducation cannot be neutral. It is either positive or negative; either it enriches or it impoverishes; either it enables a person to grow or it lessens, even corrupts him/her\u201d. Catholic social teaching speaks about the principle of \u201cintegral human development\u201d, that is, the development of every dimension of a person (intellectual, physical, spiritual, emotional, social) and of every person. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/rights-to-education-health-and-work-squandered-healthand-work-squandered/article_c10a6928-15f9-54f3-86dc-048ca41e47a7.html", "TITLE": " Rights to education, health and work squandered healthand work squandered ", "DATE": "Nov 27, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "I listened and watched with growing alarm and a curious mix of anger and distress, the several parents, flanked by primary school students, bewailing their despair at the lack of school facilities, which translated into the fact that these children are being denied the opportunity, nay the right, to attend school. Some parents were on their knees crying, hands outstretched, imploring, begging the relevant minister to have pity on them, give them a chance, bestow on them, it seems, a great gift\u2014the opportunity to go to school. No, this was not in some impoverished part of Africa, or India. It was not our neighbour Haiti, often dismiss as voodoo cursed. This was our own dear wannabe first world status country of Trinidad and Tobago. Is it only me that is embarrassed and enraged at scenes like these in sweet T&T These scenes are little different to those which show us, weekly, daily, the trials and tribulations of sick people who do not have adequate access to our publicly funded hospitals, who, when they are lucky enough to get a bed, cannot get drugs, or effective drugs, or see the doctor and any one of the myriad of problems that plague our health sector. From all of the various reports, I have heard very little or nothing that we are in fact, speaking about rights. Yes, indeed, rights, not privileges, or handouts from some benevolent state. Such rights invoke legal obligations on the part of the state. Note, I said, the state and not the Government, or any partisan political arrangement. The State is a neutralised concept which goes beyond particular administrations and political timeframes. Human Rights thought has long gone past the limitation that the subject of rights only involves what we call civil and political rights, that is, the right to life, to expression, movement etc. Rather, the more recent understanding of rights is that they also involve what we call economic, social and cultural rights, namely, the rights to education, to health, to work, the environment and to culture. Significantly, we have moved away from the self-imposed limitation that economic, social and cultural rights are merely unenforceable ideals. Rather, the international community now accepts that these kinds of bread and butter rights are just as vital, and in some ways more directly important, to the central dignity and equality of mankind. Accordingly, international conventions and protocols have been signed and developed to ensure that they have tangible and concrete meaning. Ultimately, what this means, is that states now have direct legal obligations to promote and protect such rights. The OAS, for example, has promulgated the San Salvador Protocol, which focusses specifically on making such rights enforceable and specific indicators, on education, health, work etc. have been developed to measure how states perform in this regard. We are part of the OAS community. This complements already existing obligations under the UN and the American Convention. The bottom line is that we can no longer turn a blind eye to the state's duties to promote, provide and protect rights to education, to health, to work, to culture and to the environment. Notably, this jurisprudence calls on states to \u201cprogressively realise\u201d these rights. What this also means is that a state cannot regress or go backward in their provision. What does this say therefore, about our long-standing commitments to universal education, including tertiary education, universal health care when we see these dire situations of the marginalised Rights in the work sphere\u2014to work, to adequate wages, to earned benefits, to decent working conditions, continue to be problematic. Under the rubric of \u201cwork'', we include rights to social security. The arrangements that we make, or do not make for our citizens when they are laid off, or cannot obtain employment, or are unable to work, , are therefore pertinent here, whether it be unemployment insurance, which I have long advocated, or a simple food card to an unemployed person or the elderly. Similarly, our casual disregard of 'ratty' workplaces and termination benefits that escape all legal obligations, or denying GATE funding to persons above 50. We have become so insensitised to suffering, so unaware of and cynical about our place in the world that on the night that the story of the kneeling parents was aired, the people meter question was whether it was \u201cpolitically motivated\u201d, as if ethnicity, when thrown into the mix, should make any difference to our entitlements and rights as citizens of this nation that we say that we want to build. The release added the results of the comprehensive investigation into corruption in education sheds light on the many shapes and forms of corrupt practices in education, from the embezzle- ment of national education funds, hidden school costs, to the buying and selling of fake degrees. The results demonstrate that if we ramp up the fight against corruption in education, more children will stay in school and meet literacy and development goals. It will prepare the next generation to say no to corruption. The report also details numerous practical steps to prevent the abuse of power, bribery and secret dealings from corroding the education-al experience. For schools to educate the corruption-fighters of tomorrow, they need to be free from corruption themselves.
