{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/bring-back-trade-schools/article_16665762-b674-55a6-a8eb-72d6bf0e08a0.html", "TITLE": " Bring back trade schools ", "DATE": "Jul 6, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Knowledge and education have been recognised as precious aspects of humanity for centuries. From the musings of the ancient Greek philosophers, to the enlightenment to the current information age, education is both invaluable and some might now say a right. From being the domain of a few sons of privilege in the Middle Ages, education is now seen as being as basic as shelter and sustenance in the modern world. The very nature of education has been altered through the years but the basic premise of education has remained constant, that is preparing students for life. The idea or concept of education is not to simply learn and regurgitate facts and figures. Rather, it is to apply and interpret existing knowledge to both exist in and add to the world, whilst securing one's own interests. Education is, then, an individualistic experience though it is taught to the collective. It is on this issue that I take umbrage with the current Secondary Education Assessment (SEA) system and the transition from primary to secondary school. The simple fact is that in the name of having good statistics and the illusion of \"all passes\" or \"no child left behind\" our children are being sacrificed. Many may take offence to this but the proof is there for all and sundry to see. The placing into secondary school of students who have performed below average in the SEA is a mistake of epic proportions that will haunt our nation for decades to come. The nature of education is to prepare students for the world. Not all students are academically inclined and this again is another cold, hard fact that many may find most upsetting. Once again the proof of this is quite glaringly obvious from the performance statistics of SEA. These students may, for a myriad of reasons including nerves, fright, poor nutrition, dyslexia etc, perform below expectation and instead of ascertaining the causes of their issues they are thrown from one rigorous academic environment into another. Some of these students can be put back on track with remedial help and special attention, but many others will flourish and perform admirably if they are allowed to study a trade or vocational skill. Whilst some people may be good with numbers or theory others are wizards with computers, labs and practical work. The pursuit of vocational training including electrical installation, mechanics, sewing, tailoring, woodwork, glassmaking, plumbing etc, may also appeal to students who have performed well at SEA but are not interested in pursuing academics. These are skills that students can use to build a life and a future. They are career skills that contribute to the economy and are always in demand. They are skills that form the basis of many entrepreneurs and small businesses which are the backbone of many developed nations. However, instead of recognising that some students need our help and need support to do what they enjoy, they are placed in classrooms where they are shamed and made to feel inferior. Students who can be phenomenal mechanics are made to sit through lessons in literature or history and very often are the point of ridicule from classmates and even worse, from frustrated and uncaring teachers. Being ostracised in secondary school is a soul-crushing experience and many students, instead of facing the daily teasing and abuse, will elect to drop out of school or fall into the wrong company. Either way they will end up out of school without any skills whatsoever, without qualifications and with grim employment prospects. Some may find work in the manual labour sector but those without hope will turn to crime and the very society that abandoned them will be made to pay the price for its callousness. This is a very grave picture and many may say it leans too heavily on the side of pessimism but the simple fact is that there seems to be a disconnect between reality and ideas in the ministries in Trinidad and Tobago. Most of them are operating counter to reality and thus instead of helping are hindering our development. Children and students need help; they need to be empowered to make use of those skills and assets they possess. No one is advocating to send out students who are unable to read or write. Yes, basic numerical, written and communication skills need to be learned but they can be incorporated into the syllabus of trade schools. Vocational and technical college education should be available free of charge to interested SEA students and along with their chosen technical course they can be schooled in basic mathematics, language arts, communication, accounting etc. The opportunity to study at university level through UTT or other programmes should also exist for interested students. The courses offered at these schools should be in demand and partnerships with industry firms can help to provide real world expertise with the possibility of placement thereafter. These schools should be given the same priority, support and respect as academic institutions as both sets of skills are intertwined. The software technician cannot do any programming without a working computer, neither can the doctor get to work without a properly functioning car. There is no shame if one's daughter wants to be a mechanic or if one's son wants to be a cake artist. Whilst many, if not most, parents have dreams of PhDs and ties and stockings for their children, at the end of the day it is crucial to remember that it is their life. If they are able to pursue a skill and make an honest and often profitable living, then as parents and a society it is up to us to support them. It is high time serious thought be given to the current SEA system, as it has proven to be a broken system in need of massive overhaul. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/report-one-in-five-children-in-south-trinidad-overweight-or/article_062c7130-c685-5f9c-8c50-315840726167.html", "TITLE": " REPORT: ONE IN FIVE CHILDREN IN SOUTH TRINIDAD OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE ", "DATE": "Mar 30, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "One in five school-age children in southern Trinidad are overweight or obese, a condition that sets them on a lifelong path for a range of chronic health problems, including heart disease, stroke and diabetes. These are the findings of a newly published report by a team of experts from the Trinidad and Tobago Health Sciences Initiative, a collaboration among Johns Hopkins Medicine, The University of Trinidad and Tobago and the Trinidad and Tobago Ministry of Health, among other institutions, which aims to improve population health in that country through education and research. The study was conducted on behalf of the Trinidad and Tobago Olympic Committee, the ministry of education and the ministry of health. The results, the research team says, underscore the urgent need to make childhood obesity a top national priority. The experts recommend a swift analysis that quantifies the prevalence of childhood overweight and obesity on a national scale, followed by the development of relevant strategies to prevent and reverse the condition in youngsters affected by it. These are decidedly sobering findings that highlight a critical need to reverse a trend that, if uncorrected, can have far-reaching consequences for the health of this nation, says Felicia Hill-Briggs, Ph.D., senior author on the report, an associate professor at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and the director of diabetes research for the Trinidad and Tobago Health Sciences Initiative. A growing body of evidence shows that many chronic conditions typically deemed adult are, in fact, rooted in childhood, the experts say. Obesity is believed to fuel a range of cardiovascular and metabolic disorders and even some cancers. In addition, early weight problems can speed up the onset of disease at a younger age. For example, type 2 diabetes, which was virtually unseen in children 20 years ago, is now increasingly diagnosed in teens and younger children, a trend fueled by growing childhood obesity, scientists believe. In addition to immeasurable human suffering, the experts note, obesity-fueled disease can cause a serious financial drain on a nations health care system to the tune of billions of dollars. Fortunately, the researchers say, there are a variety of lifestyle and behavior-modification programs that have proven successful in the treatment of childhood overweight and obesity. We have a wide range of interventions, and the time to act is now, before the trend reaches a tipping point, says report co-author Larry Romany, M.S., former president of the Trinidad and Tobago Olympic Committee. The analysis, based on data collected in 2012, involved more than 3,300 children, ages 5 through 12, from 14 primary schools in the Point Fortin and Mayaro regions of the country. Less than two-thirds of children had normal body mass index. More than one-fifth were overweight or obese, while 13 percent of youngsters were underweight, the study showed. The relatively high proportion of underweight children is another alarming finding, the experts say, highlighting the range of pathologies stemming from poor nutrition. Children in standard 5, or 12 to 13-year-olds, on average, had the highest body-mass index, a finding suggesting that weight troubles that start in early childhood are generally progressive and difficult to reverse, the research team says. The researchers say that even though the results come from data collected from two southern regions of the country, the findings may very well reflect a national trend. Nearly three-quarters of deaths among Trinidadian men stem from chronic diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, cancer and respiratory ailments, according to estimates from the World Health Organization published in 2004. Such conditions claim the lives of more than 80 percent of women in Trinidad and Tobago, according to the World Health Organization. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-rubik-s-cube-of-the-caribbean-public-education-system/article_c42a7c30-507e-5b23-ba44-e99bb0ba5c6a.html", "TITLE": " The Rubik's cube of the Caribbean public education system ", "DATE": "May 23, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "GEORGETOWN, Guyana, May 21, CMC \u2013 The very good news for Caribbean education is that the Caribbean Community (CARICOM) Council for Human and Social Development (COHSOD) has agreed that 2016 is the time to craft a Regional Strategic Action Plan that presents a harmonised approach to educational reform in CARICOM. The Human Resource Development Commission was launched recently with the main purpose of developing an Education Human Resource Development 2030 Strategy. The intent of the Plan is to ensure that the systems operating at all levels \u2013 national, sub-regional and regional \u2013 are developing the skills graduates need to function effectively in a 21st Century economy and society. While this statement seems an obvious approach to refining and strengthening the education systems in the region, developing an agreed approach and time-bound action plan meeting the needs and priorities of the education systems in CARICOM will not be as simple as making an announcement that it intends to do so. The CARICOM States' education systems are a Rubik's cube of elements that all have to interact in harmony to produce change. Just as solving a Rubik's cube requires the alignment of all cubes of the same colour on a single side of the larger cube so that each side of the cube displays a different colour, so alignment of all of the elements of all of the education systems will be necessary to formulate a Strategic Plan for Caribbean education that will actually effect change in the system. First, before listing the challenges, one needs to acknowledge that this new Plan will be constructed on the foundation of existing collaborative successes across the Caribbean. There are achievements of which member and Associate States can be justly proud: achieving almost universal primary education and boasting an average schooling level of 10.3 in most States; collaborating on regional examination and certification systems of CXC, CAPE and CANTA, and increasing tertiary educational opportunities in the region through improved college programmes and an expanded University of the West Indies. By establishing the CARICOM Single Market and Economy (CSME), opportunities for the best and brightest of graduates appear to be increasing, and the necessity to travel out of the region for a good education and a good job after graduation should be diminishing. However, when one looks closer to home \u2013 at the individual cubes that comprise the whole Rubik's cube \u2013 the education picture seems less positive. The cubes align, but they aren't the same colour. And just as originally there was a belief that the Rubik's cube was unsolvable, there are now competitions to see how fast competitors can solve it. Just as Rubik's cube can be solved, so can the puzzle of component parts that form the Caribbean public education system. This article, which is the first in a series addressing the challenges confronting the Caribbean education system that the Regional Strategic Action Plan must address, identifies the challenges presented by a phenomenon that is uppermost in many parents' and students' minds at this time of the year: how to successfully survive the stress of the regional examination systems. The education of its citizenry is the bedrock of national development in any country. There is no question that the existing education systems in the region have identified, nurtured and graduated a wealth of bright and capable minds that have served both the region and many developed countries well. However, these successes constitute a small percentage of the Caribbean citizenry \u2013 people of considerable talent and achievement who, by emigrating, denied their talents to their own countries. Admittedly, some of the best and brightest returned or remained at home and continued to serve the development needs of their countries, but they still are a small percentage of their age cohorts. For many, school was something at which they couldn't or weren't allowed to succeed because of the very nature and structure of the test-based system. And those school experiences, of success or its absence, have affected the rate of development in the region, as well of the lives of those who passed through the system. Of particular note are those who weren't deemed to be successful, who the system labelled as failures as early as age 10. A few years ago, the valedictorian at a well-respected Ontario university began her address by saying, \u201cWhen you go home, I want all of the people in the audience who are here from [the name of the country where she was born and raised until she was 10] to tell the Ministry of Education that it is possible to be a success even if one fails the Common Entrance.\u201d It is worth noting that even a decade later, this young woman's first concern was to show that she had succeeded even though she \u201cfailed\u201d the Common Entrance examination At this time in the school year here in Jamaica, parents and students are suffering under the exigencies of the19th Century Industrial Age exam-driven education system that the British bequeathed to the countries of the region as part of their colonial legacy. In the 19th Century, the point of the education system was to inculcate obedience in students, so that they could assume industrial jobs on a factory floor. These jobs are very few in the 21st Century and their numbers continue to shrink. Ironically, in Britain, on which many of the Caribbean countries have modelled their educational systems, the importance of high stakes academic testing like the Common Entrance and the \u201cO\u201d and \u201cA\u201d Level examinations has diminished significantly, and routine articulation between technical and academic education streams has been established, especially with the increasing popularity of adult education and the need for further education building on acquired skills. It seems to be much more difficult to bridge the divide between academic and TVET education in CARICOM countries. Parents anguish over the exams their children have to write to \u201csucceed\u201d at almost all levels of schooling \u2013 in Grade 1 when they enter school, at Grade 3 to see their progress in Math and English, in Grade 4 to see whether they are literate enough to proceed to Grade 5, and the exit exam in Grade 6. Because school placements at secondary level in Jamaica are based on achievement at the end of primary school, their children's ability to be accepted in a \u201cgood\u201d high or secondary school depends on scores on the Grade Six Achievement Test (rather than where the students live), the successor to the British-designed Common Entrance Examination that was long the hallmark of school achievement in primary school; \u201csuccess\u201d at the end of high or secondary school depends on scores achieved in CXC and CAPE examinations, the successors of the British \u201cO\u201d and \u201cA\u201d Level examinations. Admission to tertiary institutions, whether colleges or universities, depends on the quality of passes at CXC and CAPE. Parents are investing in extra lessons (if they can afford them) to try to ensure their children's success in these examinations, and teachers are augmenting their incomes with extra lesson monies. Indeed, the more entrepreneurial among their numbers are setting up private businesses in extra lessons (especially Mathematics) to feed the angst of parents who worry about their children's futures if they don't get high scores on the national and regional examinations. And, indeed, their worries are justified: even after years of struggle to improve Mathematics and English Language scores in CXC examinations \u2013 the two required subjects for tertiary level entry \u2013 the percentage of passes is still abysmally low. While the extra lessons syndrome might not seem to extend to technical schools, those students enrolled in TVET programmes also are infected by the testing bug, since graduates must be certified through Jamaica National Vocational Qualifications (J-NVQs) or Caribbean Vocational Qualifications (CVQs) to gain employment beyond their own borders under the Caribbean Single Market and Economy (CSME). Since many students were advised to enrol in technical programmes because they were not successful in the high stakes academic tests at the end of primary school or early in secondary school, the entire TVET system suffers from the perception that its students are not as \u201csmart\u201d as academic students. Although this perception, constructed as it is on the outdated idea that academic students are \u201cbrighter\u201d than TVET students, is wrong, it is still widely held among parents and the general public. It is interesting to note that in Ontario, where community colleges were established 40 years ago to allow those who were considered less academically gifted the opportunity to get a tertiary degree, more than 30 percent of university graduates are now re-enrolling in a community college programme to acquire a skill that will make them employable. The Caribbean is far behind the curve. Educationists and employers alike have asserted that what students need to learn in school is broader than the memorisation of facts and their accurate regurgitation on an examination: employers in particular have said that they want graduates and employees who can solve problems, think critically, listen analytically, act independently, and express themselves accurately in speech and writing. However, the test-driven education system is unlikely to create students who demonstrate these skills, since it places high value on those teachers who can produce large numbers of students who can respond accurately to content-driven examination questions, and the means of getting students to pass examinations is to teach them how to write those kinds of exams. The CXC has been struggling with the contradiction between the demands of an Industrial Age education system and the employers' demands for a graduate from CSEC and CAPE with other skills by increasing the value of school-based assessments at the secondary levels, but the exams still feature heavily in calculating a student's grades. Region-wide adoption of the new CXC Grade 6 examination that encourages problem solving and student involvement in their own learning has been slow. Instead of adopting this Grade 6 examination, Jamaica is developing a news standards-based curriculum for Grades 1 to 9 and revising the approaches in its Grade 6 examination. Changing testing and measuring student success also has implications for establishing international assessment strategies not dependent upon examinations alone, changing the curriculum for pre-service teacher training, changing teacher certification and professional development, strengthening the training of teacher educators and educational administrators, and conducting dialogues with parents and employers. Planning change of such deep-rooted systems poses a considerable challenge. Thus, while Caribbean countries may have gained political independence, they have not yet managed educational independence. The areas of curriculum design, classroom instruction and testing are just a few of the areas the CARICOM Education and Human Resource 2030 Strategy and Action Plan will have to address, and constitute but one cube on one face of the Rubik's cube of the Caribbean education system. *Nancy A. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/workshop-on-dealing-with-indiscipline-in-schools/article_6626ca3d-d145-5d68-8788-50ab979fbe09.html", "TITLE": " Workshop on dealing with indiscipline in schools ", "DATE": "Aug 9, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Aug 10, CMC \u2013 Caribbean teachers have started a three-day workshop here aimed at equipping them with the appropriate skills in tackling the problem of indiscipline in schools. \u201cBoth inside and outside of the classroom, disciplinary problems are multiplying and they are most evident at the secondary level where across the region 44 per cent of our teachers remain untrained,\u201d said co-ordinator Dr. Verna Knight. The director of the UWI School of Education, Dr. Babalola Ogunkola, said poor performances are largely attributed to the environment in whciuh learning takes place. \u201cIn most countries, it is generally by means of an entrance examination or tests at the age 11 to 12 years which focuses principally on mathematics, language arts and social studies, despite the fact that approximately 30 per cent of the students taking these tests have not acquired the basic competences to perform at secondary level, they are still all assigned to secondary schools,\u201d the Senior Lecturer in Science Education and Evaluation added. UNICEF education specialist, Elaine King, said the agency is committed to promoting positive behaviour management in schools and this is reflected in the training of teachers across the Caribbean. \u201cOver the past four years UNICEF has in fact supported the training of over 3,000 teachers in positive behaviour management and a follow up survey among these teachers show that between 65 to 92 per cent of the teachers, who are trained reported using these strategies with positive student outcome. \u201cIn other words, the students responded well to the various strategies and teachers were generally happy with the results,\u201d she added. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/that-education-deficit/article_bf3b3764-a2b2-5f78-a26a-449626b8dfbb.html", "TITLE": " That education deficit ", "DATE": "May 21, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Recently I spoke with a young professional in his mid-30s, a decent chap with three university degrees with whom I am able to converse whenever we meet. I asked him what drives his peers, the young educated class in this country. His thoughtful response was they were concerned mainly with their own material progress and pursuit of pleasure, with no passion for country and society, confirming the view that, among our new educated elite, is an alarming deficit in social conscience, an inner vacancy. They look on at the society from a distance as something unreal, theatre, unrelated to their narrow preoccupations. They are not to be blamed. It is their education for which we have paid with great billions over the years. My young friend agrees if you spend 17 years passing through our primary and secondary schools and there is no stimulation of the soul, you should not expect anything more than limited, superficial engagement of the society by the new professional class in the country. We are therefore paying to place our nation in danger, for if our future leaders and elders don't care, what does the future hold for Trinidad and Tobago but more leaderlessness and rapaciousness This is a serious national challenge that we have not even begun to think about. We must understand how this developed, because it was not so with the pre- and post-Independence generations who were characterised by passion, if not clarity. But around 40 years ago, somewhere in the '70s, there was a global shift in education from the heroic to the pragmatic. Greater emphasis was placed on brain power than on developing the mind; on achieving earning capability than on nurturing sensitivity, social conscience and humanity. English literature and history were pushed to the periphery, for example, and math and sciences gained pre-eminence. How else could you prepare youth for the marketplace was the thinking then and now. So the brightest have continued to choose law, medicine, finance, engineering, accountancy; the pragmatic and practical. Fine, but generations of these have entered the professions with little of the shaping influence of the humanities. We ought to have maintained the critical balance in our schools. We failed and the world has seen the dehumanisation of hundreds of millions of young, bright people, among whom were those, greedy self-seeking financial wizards of Wall Street who, in pursuit for their enormous, ill-gotten gains, brought the world to the brink of economic ruin in 2008. The shift in education either coincided with or was the result of the market fundamentalism that drove the globalisation of production and the liberalisation of trade, reducing the role of the state, emphasising private sector-led growth, creating an environment where, more than ever, the attainment of wealth and status was the principal driving force for young people graduating from colleges and universities. If the world is today more materialistic than ever, then that shift has made the most significant contribution. The shift in education also produced a marked decline in the quality of leadership everywhere. Reagan, Thatcher, Pope John Paul, Lech Walesa and Gorbachev lingered into the modern era but were the products of a different education, a different time, as were Eric Williams, Cheddi Jagan, Errol Barrow and Michael Manley. All these were the last of the devoted breed, the larger than life characters, driven by more than hunger for power and prestige and grappling with their societies in very profound ways. After them came the ordinary, epitomised by the likes of Tony Blair, George W Bush and those in the region today who lack the conviction to lift Caricom from its stagnation. No leader now on the world stage can stir the heart of humanity as Winston Churchill, John F Kennedy or Lyndon Johnson whose landmark speech is 50 years old this week in which he said the \"Great Society\" must be built in the classrooms where \"every young mind is set free to scan the farthest reaches of thought and imagination... where every child can enrich his mind and enlarge his talents\". The barrenness of modern education is a major reason for a prevailing amorality among the upper echelons in Trinidad and Tobago. When wealth acquisition is the main preoccupation of those at the top, scruples are thrown out the window in every sector and predators prowl in offices and boardrooms everywhere, creating a jungle of lawlessness at the top which is already breeding violence of the kind that downed Dana. We must take action. I suppose we must count as largely lost those already too steeped in self and we must hope to eventually develop strength of law and institutions to protect the nation from disembowelment by those it spent billions to educate. But we must focus on the children and youth, those now moving through the education system which is more like an assembly line when it should be an open field for exploration of a variety of offerings, from arts and humanities to science and mathematics. Our education system has been producing academically successful youth who score low in caring and commitment to country. This is threat to the nation's future. Leaders, parents and teachers, take note. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/t-t-born-head-of-howard-university-lauds-dr-williamss/article_3ce27d64-00a8-5779-b5e2-e746ef7e2728.html", "TITLE": " T&T-born head of Howard University lauds Dr Williamss vision ", "DATE": "Jun 17, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Trinidad-born Dr Wayne AI Frederick, newly appointed 17th president of Howard University in the United States, yesterday lauded the late prime minister/historian Dr Eric Williams for his vision in creating a system of free public education. He was speaking at a function hosted by President Anthony Carmona and his wife, Reema Carmona, at Queens Hall, St Anns. Frederick was joined by his wife, Simone; children, Kirie, eight, and Wayne, 11; 91-year-old grandmother Christine Roach; mother, Frances Tyson-Hill; and specially invited guest/former national footballer Shaka Hislop, whom he described as a best friend.Frederick was also celebrating his 44th birthday and Reema Carmo- na had a cake done for the occasion. Frederick is also renowned as a scholar, researcher, administrator, humanitarian and surgical oncologist. Frederick was born in Diamond Vale, Diego Martin, and studied at Diego Martin Government Primary School and St Marys College. He studied medicine at Howard University. Credit to mom, grandmom Frederick said: My grandmother (Roach) was the first person in my life who instilled confidence. My mother (Tyson-Hill) did give me books and surgical masks. She emphasised education. She fell in love with Dr Williams. She was a big fan of his. My children are in middle school. Dr Williams created a public education system. She wanted me to get that type of education so I could have the type of life she envisioned for me. I have to give much credit to her. I was afforded a public education. My two childrens tuition is costing me ten times what I would have paid for my three degrees. Let us not forget Dr Williams and the intervention in education and the public health sector. It is free. The quality is excellent.He added: Dr Williams was a professor at Howard University. It was another reason why my mother and I became enamoured with Howard University as well. Frederick also invited citizens to be obsessed about Trinidad and Tobago. He said: Love is most important. This is a beautiful country. I vow to return the debt by my deeds and the quality of my deeds. Although we may be going through difficult times, let us take a moment to reflect. We are a melting pot of the worlds peoples. Let us never allow the differences to divide us but to bring us together.He also said his children had developed a certain measure of compassion for the homeless and the less fortunate.Humble and outstanding The gifts we have can only be worthwhile if we share them with the less fortunate. Carmona, who has just returned from South Africa, described Frederick as humble and outstanding. He reminisced on the days of Intercol when he was a pupil at Presentation College, San Fernando. Carmona also expressed his pride in Hislops accomplishments by saying whenever he looks at ESPN, he often remarked, I know him. Commenting on Fredericks appointment, Carmona said: It was about selfless service. We have to celebrate it. A young man who, never mind the condition of his heart, decided he was going to make a difference in the world and the lives of others. He was not only a medical doctor, but a good medical doctor. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/school-still-in-limbo/article_8dcea240-88c1-58d8-b42c-c6df6aad1e11.html", "TITLE": " School still in limbo ", "DATE": "Dec 21, 2008 ", "CONTENT": "IN the interest of the children, the board at the Trinidad Muslim League (TML) board will be looking at private sector investment to keep the Rafeek Memorial TML School open, president, Azid Ali has said. \"For now we have to keep the school open until the end of the school year in 2009, but we will have to seek out private sector investment,\" he said. The school, which is on the Eastern Main Road, St Joseph, is a privately-owned institution and has about 210 pupils. Ali said the school has been absorbing losses after the board was unable to earn enough to match its $65,000-a-month expenditure bill and it had reached a point where they could no longer sustain the institution. So after two years of doing this, Ali said they were forced to meet Education Minister Esther Le Gendre to discuss a solution. At the meeting they were told that their contract between the ministry and themselves did not allow them to shut down the school and if they wanted to close it down they would need to submit the necessary documents one year in advance. \"Right now, we basically have until the end of the school year and we intend to do a number of reviews in light of the circumstances,\" he said. Asked if that meant letting go some of the teachers, Ali said they already had a high turnover even though they were always able to keep teachers with an A'Levels certificate. \"The cost of paying university graduate teachers is really high...it's easier for the government run schools to pay the high wages, but we can't,\" he said. In the interim, Ali said they will be open for school on January 5, but as for continuing in the 2009 to 2010 school year, they are still undecided. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/prestige-school-bashing/article_790e990f-d326-5c52-9eaf-70e9e1836617.html", "TITLE": " Prestige school bashing ", "DATE": "Apr 6, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "I read a few articles this week on the statement by Education Minister Dr Tim Gopeesingh on his proposed changes to the primary school curriculum and I would have to say I do indeed believe that in standards four and five SEA is emphasised to the detriment of other important areas such as physical education and social studies. I actually agree with most of the proposed changes and I think it is high time primary school pupils are relieved of the tremendous pressure placed on them. That being said I was most distressed that the honourable minister also took a swipe at the so-called \"prestige\" or denominational schools. The minister was quoted as saying that these schools need to stop taking the best students. Now I do not know if I am the only one who is a bit confused here but what exactly does the minister mean Before I proceed further I must state that I attended one of the so-called \"prestige\" schools: Presentation College, Chaguanas. Some will say that I am biased. But I came from a family and area where the vast majority of my relatives, friends and neighbours went to comprehensive and other non-denominational schools. It would then not be presumptuous of me to say that I can speak on this matter without bias. I will never understand the vitriol that is directed at denominational schools and by extension their pupils. I do not know if these people are aware that when they demonise these schools they are also demonising their pupils and alumni. The denominational schools have made a tremendous contribution to our country. Some of them were created to educate those whom the state forgot or ignored in the early years of our country. The \"cow shed\" schools educated the children of the indentured labourers. Church schools were set up to educate, at first, the children of the elite classes but then grew to encompass the community. Most of our nation's illustrious sons and daughters went to prestige schools. The list includes prime ministers and presidents, sporting heroes and ministers of government. How then can anyone find it in their hearts to bash and ridicule these institutions Claims that only rich children go to prestige schools could not be further from the truth. In my old school and in many others the pupil population was composed of children from middle class and poor backgrounds. There was no elitism, no group of spoiled rich children looking down on other schools. The prestige schools are populated by the children of Joe and Jane Public: farmers, police officers, sales clerks, public servants and many other average working citizens. Of course there are wealthy children, but there are also wealthy children in comprehensive and composite schools. I fail once again to see the problem. Entry into so-called prestige schools is based on merit. These schools set standards for entry. Their ethos is education, their doctrine is knowledge, their dogma is wisdom. They are academic institutions, that is what they are! It is only obvious that they will want the best of the best. Complaining that they only \"take bright children\" is the equivalent of complaining that graduate schools only take people who have an undergraduate degree. It makes no sense at all! Furthermore these schools do not force anyone to apply to them. Children put down their preferences. They are free and their parents are free to choose any school they wish to attend. It is being made to sound as though everyone who scores 95 per cent and over at SEA has to go to a prestige school. This is not true. They can choose to and many have gone to other schools due to various factors and have performed exceptionally. Instead of complaining that prestige schools do well, maybe critics ought to be examining why other schools do not do well and try to rectify this. The prestige schools can provide a possible answer and they need to be examined closely instead of being ridiculed. Students alone do not equal good results. If this were the case there would be no bad results in prestige schools (weak graduates come from them too) and no good results in non-denominational schools (many strong graduates come from them). Systems of respect, tolerance, discipline and well-thought-out procedures are ubiquitous in all of the denominational schools. Though they may be \"religious\" schools, religion is not forced down the throats of the pupils. Instead there is multiculturalism and tolerance. What these schools have are good disciplinary procedures and strong support systems. The Government and the Education Ministry need to provide these to their schools. In many ways those who ridicule prestige schools are also degrading the achievements of other schools in sport, academics and arts. They are in effect saying that the only reason people do well is that they go to a prestige school. This is an insult to all of the students of the nation. There is no such thing as a bad school, there is no such thing as a bad student, there is no such thing as a \"prestige\" school. There are schools that enforce the rules and discipline their students, and push academics and there are those that are abandoned by the state. There are schools where teachers are not given support and help to deal with violent and rowdy students. There are schools where the state shows total disregard and instead of restructuring and trying to change they sweep the problems under the carpet. The next time anyone has the audacity to bash and ridicule a prestige school just remember, a school is not just a building, it is the hearts of students you are stomping on and the feelings of children just like you were, just like your own children. * Rajiv Gopie won the President's Medal for business studies/modern studies in 2006. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/tears-at-tabaquite-composite-school/article_0fee8263-dc17-5a58-85db-5c82d5dec83a.html", "TITLE": " Tears at Tabaquite Composite school ", "DATE": "Aug 20, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "TEARS flowed at the Tabaquite Composite School yesterday, after more than 100 Form Five students found out they would have to put their studies on hold for the next month because they were graded for only three of the seven Caribbean Secondary Education Certificate (CSEC) subjects they sat two months ago. Most of the subject areas where a School-Based Assessment (SBA) determined the final result were ungraded, it was learnt. The Ministry of Education yesterday confirmed that the school will have to query the ungraded subjects and resubmit the marks manually, so that the students can be graded by September. There was turmoil yesterday when students and their parents realised that they had not received grades for five of the seven subjects they wrote. \"None of the children got grades for the subjects with SBAs (School Based Assessments). In fact, the only results they got were for Mathematics, English A because they have no SBAs and Biology because the SBA was submitted late,\" one parent said. The parent was told by school officials that the SBA marks had been sent to the ministry. \"I want to know what will be done because somebody has to be held accountable. My daughter did seven subjects and only got grades for two,\" said the parent. Principles of Business, General Science, Chemistry, Woodwork, Agricultural Science and Spanish were among the ungraded subjects. Valene Joshua, one of the students affected, said, \"I don't know what to do because I applied to the University of the Southern Caribbean but they won't take me with an ungraded transcript. Then there are people who wanted to do A's outside of Tabaquite. What will be their position\" Director of communications at the Education Ministry, Elton Wickham, confirmed that the SBAs had been sent by the school, but said the ministry was not responsible for the ungraded slips because it acts only as the middle man. \"Firstly, when the schools send the scripts to the ministry they are encrypted, the ministry cannot open it for security reasons. If we open it, that is a breach,\" he said. \"CXC called to say they did not get the scripts but it was difficult to get in touch with school officials because school was already on vacation.\" Wickham said CXC will entertain the late marks as when the school makes an official query they are resubmitted, but will have to find a way to ensure that there is oversight in Trinidad. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/single-sex-schools-project/article_5a4ee7bb-8ec7-523c-867f-9d2c5290c824.html", "TITLE": " Single-sex schools project ", "DATE": "Mar 31, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Roland Fisher Roland Fisher It was not my intention to write on the subject of single sex vs co-educational schools again this week, but due to the number of articles and letters appearing in the press, and to statements from the Ministry of Education that have clarified the way in which the Ministry intends to implement the project, I am prompted to return to the subject, even though it may entail repeating some of the statements I have made previously. The Ministry intends to convert 20 co-educational schools to single sex by September this year. These schools have been selected in pairs whereby the two schools are adjacent to or in close proximity to each other; one of the pair will be all-girls and the other all-boys. There has been criticism of this initiative, particularly from the Trinidad and Tobago Unified Teachers Association (TTUTA). It has been put forward that there was not prior consultation and there is insufficient time for proper preparation for what will be a major change in this large number of schools. As I have indicated in my last two articles I support this initiative although I am convinced that it should be introduced in a somewhat different way. It is my hope that changes may be made which will produce more meaningful results and will also win the support of TTUTA for the project. There is now quite extensive literature on this subject of single-sex vs. co-educational education but three points stand out: the results are mostly indicative but not definitive of better results in single-sex settings; most of the positive results for single-sex education are applicable to single-sex classes as well as to single sex-schools (so there is no need for the Ministry to embark on the difficult task of converting schools from co-educational to single-sex at this stage); the measurement of better performance is invariably in terms of academic performance and not necessarily of the production of better citizens which should be a major objective of education (for example, arguments in favour of co-educational systems suggest that socialisation between boys and girls can be better achieved in co-educational settings). In my last article I argued that the objectives of the project could be achieved more successfully and with considerably less disruption by a different approach. I shall repeat these proposals with some elaboration. If schools are converted into separate all-boys and all-girls schools then the difficulty arises in assessing the results and of accounting for the differences between the schools as opposed to the effect of single-sex or coeducation. There are so many other factors that may differ between schools that may affect performance of boys or girls: leadership, standard of the student intake, experience of the teachers and so on. To overcome this problem my proposal is that the trials be conducted by streaming the first-year intake into boys, girls and mixed-sex classes in each of the 20 selected schools in September. This change can be effected with a minimum of disruption of the administration of the schools. It will place less stress on parents having to select different schools at the last minute. The project would have to be set up by persons knowledgeable in educational research. Does the Ministry of Education have the in-house capability to design and monitor such research or sufficient personnel to capture the data produced from 20 schools It is for this reason that I have suggested that the universities should be involved. The Government must allocate a sufficiently large sum of money to contract the universities to conduct the research in collaboration with the Ministry. A number of post-graduate scholarships should be offered for work on this research project (there will be a number of Bachelor of Education students graduating this year from the three universities). I want to again emphasise the importance of providing all of these schools with lunch rooms as an important aspect of socialising between the boys and girls. The opportunity should be taken to expand the school nutrition programme to all students in the schools with the parents paying for a (subsidised) meal at rates based on ability to pay, to zero payment where necessary. I would urge the Minister of Health to join the effort to attack obesity, which he has recognised as a looming problem, by ensuring that our school children are nurtured to follow proper nutrition. This effort should also be supported by the Minister of Agriculture so that food produced locally can replace the unhealthy \"fast foods\" that many children consume at school. The approach that I have suggested would allow for a smooth return to co-education if the results of the project suggest this as the best course of action but could also lead to the model of Trinity (East) and Bishops (East) with a boys school and a girls school on the same compound (not just in close proximity to each other). This is the system that I believe would give the best of both worlds; developing socialisation while giving the benefits of single-sex classes if our research shows this to be the better method of instruction. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/keep-religion-out-of-school/article_148f9b3b-ab1c-5adb-b9e3-89c7435c4a57.html", "TITLE": " Keep religion out of school ", "DATE": "Apr 20, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Part 2 I would like to begin by thanking everyone who commented and emailed me about last week's story. In your disagreement with last week's piece, you were able to help me prove a very salient point: there is no link between religion and crime. You have helped me to toss one of the foundational arguments of this religious education thrust out of the window. A few of those touting this project were advocating that teaching religion in school would somehow come to affect crime through the reformation of social values. As was seen from last week's piece, religion and religiosity and the existence of religion in a school have nothing to do with crime. Rather, it is social and external factors such as poverty and inequality and the drug trade that cause crime in a country. This week I will tackle some of the other arguments used by the advocates of this programme and address some other concerns and questions. Firstly the method being proposed for this programme is not like theology which is taught in universities. If am to understand the Ministry of Education and others it will resemble the United Kingdom version of the course and/or the CXC version. To make things clear those syllabi are not in any way like theology. Theology is learning about religion, deconstructing religion, fighting with religion, arguing with it, reconciling it with fact and science and trying to get a deep understanding of religion in its cultural and historical context. This is how theology is taught at university; this is not how the planned programme is going to be run. Rather, if I am again to infer from the UK and CXC syllabi, it will be cursory approaches to the different religions, a comparative approach; there will be no questioning of whether it is right or wrong or makes any sense at all. Next, on to the UK itself, which many proponents of the programme are using as a model. A March 2011 report in the Daily Telegraph, a reputable daily newspaper, says the UK government has plans to cut funding to teacher training in religious instruction. The subject has also been removed from the English Baccalaureate certificate that bears proof of a student's performance in secondary school. It seems, then, that the touting of the UK as the model we should follow is another argument down the drain, since the UK is realising that this is a failed experiment. Staying in the UK, their programme allows parents to pull their children out of the classes based on school approval. I do hope that if, against all good sense, this \"atrocity'' is implemented in T&T parents will have the right to pull their children out of class. Nothing will be gained from having these courses in school. Rather, there is the need to rebuild and implement a civics programme in school. As a columnist who does not only like to criticise I am offering this counter solution. Instead of playing with a subject that is as inflammatory and controversial as race, the better idea would be to build a sense of citizenship and social responsibility in students. If children are made to feel that they are part of a country, a community and a national family from an early age, this will go a long way in reducing crime. Children need to feel as they are part of society. Whatever their economic and social backgrounds, if they feel accepted and part of a community there is a less likelihood of them turning on this community. Furthermore, there is a pressing need to spark a spirit of nationhood and pride in our country. This can start in school, where nation-building can take place, in the form of national education, learning the history of Trinidad and Tobago, our leaders, our struggles, the horrors of slavery, the brutality of indentureship, the sweetness of independence and fight to define ourselves as a multiracial, multi-ethnic people. A people of many colours and descended from many places but all one under our sun in our beautiful twin-island state. This will have a better impact on crime, this will increase pride, this will encourage social cohesion and nation-building, not religion, but nation. I caution that nothing good will come of this religion programme. It has the potential to disrupt the true purpose of schools: to educate and advance our nation. It can reopen wounds of the past when only one religion dominated our islands. It has the ability to make many children feel vulnerable and unaccepted. I will once again state that I am an agnostic and I have the utmost respect for religion and the right to worship. I strongly believe in religious tolerance and advocate that religions should remain a personal matter never to be interfered with by the state. I am however also a proponent of the secular state, of keeping religion out of all state institutions and that includes schools. Religion should either be taught in the form of theology that allows for debate and disagreement or not at all. If this programme is introduced into schools I suggest that pupils and parents be allowed to opt out. I also suggest that the facilitators be extremely well trained and unbiased. Specific courses run by the Education Ministry or UWI must be compulsory for teachers of religion. Furthermore a hotline should be set up for complaints to be dealt with if the facilitators or schools are trying to indoctrinate children. A specific powerful task force that does not have the usual T&T lackadaisical attitude needs to be set up to oversee this programme. I am wholly against this religion in the schools programme, but if it is going to be done, it needs to be done properly, or else I foresee trouble. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/world/brazil-education-overhaul-aims-at-ousting-marxist-ideology/article_af847d34-2a28-11e9-b75f-cf990a355112.html", "TITLE": " Brazil education overhaul aims at ousting 'Marxist ideology' ", "DATE": "Feb 6, 2019 ", "CONTENT": "FILE - In this Oct. 26, 2018 file photo, university students hold signs with messages that read in Portuguese: \"Not Him\" and \"My faith and torture don't mix\" during a protest against an electoral court order for universities to remove banners containing 'negative propaganda' against then presidential frontrunner Jair Bolsonaro, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. On the campaign trail, Bolsonaro said he wanted to \"enter the Education Ministry with a flamethrower to remove Paulo Freire.\" Bolsonaro and other conservatives say Freire, one of the founders of critical pedagogy, turns students into \"political militants.\" (AP Photo/Silvia Izquierdo, File) FILE - In this Oct. 26, 2018 file photo, university students hold signs with messages that read in Portuguese: \"Not Him\" and \"My faith and torture don't mix\" during a protest against an electoral court order for universities to remove banners containing 'negative propaganda' against then presidential frontrunner Jair Bolsonaro, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. On the campaign trail, Bolsonaro said he wanted to \"enter the Education Ministry with a flamethrower to remove Paulo Freire.\" Bolsonaro and other conservatives say Freire, one of the founders of critical pedagogy, turns students into \"political militants.\" (AP Photo/Silvia Izquierdo, File) President Jair Bolsonaro is taking his anti-leftist ideological war to Brazil's classrooms and universities, causing angst among teachers and education officials who say the government wants to fight an enemy that doesn't exist. Bolsonaro and top officials have announced plans to revise textbooks to excise references to feminism, homosexuality and violence against women, say the military will take over some public schools and frequently bash Paulo Freire, one of Brazil's most famous educators, whose ideas had worldwide influence. \"One of the goals to get Brazil out of the worst positions in international education rankings is to combat the Marxist rubbish that has spread in educational institutions,\" Bolsonaro tweeted on the eve of his inauguration. While students may not yet find many differences as they return to school this month, changes are afoot. \"We are still waiting to see how, in practice, all this is going to turn out,\" said Nilton Brandao, president of one of Brazil's largest teachers' unions, PROIFES Federacao. \"Right now, it does not make any sense.\" For the government, the ideological battle begins with the removal of Freire's legacy in schools, which Bolsonaro and other conservatives say turns students into \"political militants.\" Freire, who died in 1997, was one of the founders of critical pedagogy. Conservatives contend Freire's method encourages students to challenge traditional values such as family and the church. A socialist, Freire was briefly imprisoned during the 1964-1985 military dictatorship that Bolsonaro has repeatedly praised. On the campaign trail, Bolsonaro said he wanted to \"enter the Education Ministry with a flamethrower to remove Paulo Freire.\" Bolsonaro and his education minster appear to be looking for inspiration in philosophers like Olavo de Carvalho, a Brazilian who lives in the U.S. and is known for his anti-globalism and anti-socialist views. While Freire believed in the state's mission to educate the Brazilian people, including poor rural farmers and the illiterate, de Carvalho advocates reducing the state's role in education, favoring private or religious schools. \"The government does not have to educate anyone; it is the society that has to educate itself,\" de Carvalho said last year during a talk about education on his YouTube channel. He added that proposals \"based on the idea that the federal government is the great educator I am going to fight to the death.\" After Bolsonaro took office Jan. 1, the Education Ministry dismantled its diversity department and published a new set of guidelines for textbook publishers that eliminated references to topics such as violence against women and sexism. Receiving an outpouring of criticism, officials backtracked on the revised texts, saying the new guidelines had been written by the previous administration and published by mistake. Even so, Education Minister Ricardo Velez Rodriguez vowed in his inaugural speech to end the \"aggressive promotion of the gender ideology.\" Velez instead defended what he called traditional values, such as family, church, school and the nation, which he said were threatened by a \"crazy globalist wave.\" \"The Brazilian who travels is a cannibal. He steals things from the hotel, steals the life jacket from the plane,\" said Velez in an interview with Veja magazine this week. \"Our kids and teenagers must receive citizenship education, which teaches how to act according to the law and morality.\" Bolsonaro has said he would review the content of Brazil's national high school exam to rid it of any questions on gender or LGBT movements. He made the announcement in a YouTube video after seeing a question from last year's exam on a \"secret dialect used by gays and transvestites,\" called Pajuba. The Pajuba dialect mixes Portuguese and West African languages and is mostly used in Afro-Brazilian religions but has also been adopted by the Brazilian LGBT community. \"Don't worry, there won't be any more questions like this,\" Bolsonaro said. After his inauguration, Velez told the newspaper Folha de S. Paulo that his office will encourage municipalities interested in letting their schools be run by the military or the police. Brazil has 13 military-run schools, which are aimed at educating children of soldiers but also accept some students based on merit. The military is the most respected institution in the country and its schools have a better reputation than many public schools. The military is also sometimes called in to co-run public schools and bring back order. Last year, 39.5 million students attended a public school, while private institutions, which can cost several thousand dollars a month, served 9 million. Opponents say the selective admission process of military schools would end up being discriminatory in impoverished areas. In general, critics say the administration is focused on the wrong things. Claudia Costin, director of Brazil's Center for Excellence and Innovation in Education Policies, a think tank based in Rio de Janeiro, said efforts should focus on improving training and salaries for teachers, making the entrance exam for teachers tougher and building a common syllabus for schools across the country. The government \"complains about indoctrination at school,\" Costin said. \"But it is not with laws that you solve these things.\" Brazil ranked 63rd out of the 72 countries and regions in the 2015 Program for International Student Assessment, conducted by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. According to the group, Brazil has as one of the largest shares of adults without secondary education. Schools are overcrowded, teacher salaries and low and school buildings are often crumbling. More than 5.800 schools had no water supply in 2017, nearly 5.000 had no electricity and 8.400 had no sewage, according to government figures. Many Brazilians don't appear convinced by Bolsonaro's plans. In a poll published Jan. 8, 71 percent of those surveyed said politics should be discussed at school and 54 percent thought it was fine to discuss sexual education inside the classroom. The poll, however, indicated that the new administration's conservative views played well with evangelicals, a powerful voter base for Bolsonaro during the campaign. Fifty-nine percent of evangelicals said they did not approve of sexual education being discussed at school. The Datafolha poll was based on 2,077 interviews carried out Dec. 18 and Dec. 19, with a margin of error of two percentage points. Caua dos Santos Borges, a 15-year-old public school student in Rio de Janeiro, said that in her experience teachers rarely spoke about politics in the classroom and gender had never felt like a core area of the curriculum. \"Once, a student asked the teacher if he supported Bolsonaro, but the teacher didn't respond and changed the subject,\" dos Santos Borges said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/education-and-the-budget/article_271ebfbb-fb4e-5eff-81dc-a216c97b632b.html", "TITLE": " Education and the budget ", "DATE": "Oct 25, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " Part 2 I continue to discuss the Minister of Education's budget presentation. Universal Secondary Education The Minister of Education reminded the House that Universal Secondary Education was introduced when the present Prime Minister was Minister of Education. The Minister did not remind the House of the chaos that ensued when this was done without preparation. I am of the view that some of the ills from which the education system still suffers, and present social ills in the wider society, can be traced back to the way in which that decision was implemented. Universal Secondary Education is essential not only to ensure equity in the society but also for the good of national development, and its success or failure is determined by the way in which the expansion is carried out. As long as there are deficiencies in primary education, there will be a number of pupils who are not properly prepared for secondary school. In the past these pupils were catered for in post-primary classes. When all pupils were moved into secondary schools these post-primary classes should have been replaced by special remedial classes in the secondary schools. In most cases this was not done and such pupils moved through secondary schooling with the deficiencies not corrected and so their benefit from such schooling is minimal. They left secondary school with low self-esteem and in many instances became susceptible to recruitment to \"gangs''. Has any research been done at the University of the West Indies to examine the effects of passage through secondary school and subsequent fate of such pupils This is the second time that the introduction of a system to improve the educational level of our populationand to move toward greater social equityhas been implemented in a way that has had unintended, unfavourable effects. The first was in the introduction of Junior and Senior Secondary schools. This was in itself a good step toward Universal Secondary Education but in order to accommodate the maximum number of pupils, a shift system was introduced which led to students being unsupervised by parents or teachers for long periods each day. Also extra-curricula activities were limited as the school facilities were needed from early morning to late afternoon to accommodate the two shifts. The Minister referred to the Strategy Report of his Ministry which, as he has pointed out, is available on the Ministry's website. In fact it is all about organisation and management and little on education. I have tried unsuccessfully to get from it \"a model for educational development of our children'' that the Minister stated it contains. The 1993-2003 paper on education, which became Government's policy document, was written by a team of experts with wide experience in education. The present strategy document was written by a sole author whose credentials in education are not given. From my experience in the Public Service the proposals in the Strategy Report would make a difficult fit into the systems of that service. The Minister was very open about the underperformance of the pupils in the education system and for this we must give him full marks. What was missing in the Minister's presentation was a proposal for diagnosing the causes of this underperformance, school by school and for monitoring progress in remedying this situation. As the Minister is a medical doctor he will appreciate the need for a proper diagnosis before treatment is applied. In the case of the school system misdiagnosis may lead to adverse effects on many lives for many years. I do not advocate the uncritical adoption of systems from abroad but the system of inspection of schools by an independent external team of inspectors as is in place in the United Kingdom where it is a legal requirement and has great merit. This system should be adopted, with any necessary modifications to meet local conditions. I was informed that a previous Minister of Education carried a team to the UK to examine this system but nothing was done to implement it. The present system of school supervisors is inadequate to the task of diagnosing the problems in schools. In the UK every school is examined at least once in every five years (more frequently if the school is underperforming; it has been proposed recently that inspection will be less frequent if the school is performing well) by a team of inspectors, specially trained and registered by the Office for Standards in Education (Ofsted). Inspectors spend about a week in each school. They sit in classrooms to hear lessons being delivered, look at school work books to assess how much feedback teachers are giving to students, assess the quality of management of the school; report of the physical condition of the school, the relations with the community, discipline and the behaviour of the pupils, examination results and progress (or otherwise) of the school since the last inspection. In January of this year changes were made to this inspection system (see Ofsted website): \"Key changes: In judging the quality of the school, inspectors will make four key judgments:- Achievement; the quality of teaching; behaviour and safety; leadership and management''. ... \"inspectors will take account of the four key judgments and how well the school promotes pupils' spiritual, moral, social and cultural development.'' Each school will now have to submit a self-evaluation report on a yearly basis which will be examined by the inspection team. The Education Discussion Group has in the past recommended this system to previous Ministers of Education. Ms Leela Ramdeen, a member of the Group, has personal experience of the system having worked in an education department in the UK. The system is transparent and the report on each school is posted on the Ofsted website; for any school in the UK one can download the last Ofsted report. John Spence is professor emeritus, UWI. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/back-to-school-for-children-educators/article_04f81f9f-edba-5c62-9634-e940105b92d0.html", "TITLE": " Back to school for 266,000 children, educators ", "DATE": "Sep 1, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "BIG SCHOOL - Four-year -old Nathan Mohammed takes his seat on his first day at the Grant Memorial Presbyterian Primary School in San Fernando. PHOTO by INNIS FRANCIS BIG SCHOOL - Four-year -old Nathan Mohammed takes his seat on his first day at the Grant Memorial Presbyterian Primary School in San Fernando. PHOTO by INNIS FRANCIS Education Minister Dr Tim Gopeesingh issued a statement on Sunday, ahead of today's opening of the 2013 academic year. The following is his statement - I wish to extend sincere best wishes to all the near 250,000 students in the Early Childhood, Primary and Secondary Schools of our nation, as well as the approximately 16,000 Principals, Vice Principals, Senior Teachers, Heads of Departments, Deans and Teachers for a very successful, enjoyable, healthy and safe year. In the past three years we have pursued an aggressive, reengineering, transformation and paradigm shift in our Education System. This to ensure our education sector is second-to-none globally. Upon completion of laptop distribution in September, nearly 70,000 laptops would have been provided to Forms I-IV students, all Principals of Primary and Secondary Schools and School Supervisors. Near to 4,000 Teachers have been trained with the infusion of the curriculum with ICT. All 134 Secondary Schools have functioning Computer Labs, ranging from 1 to 6 labs; three hundred of the 476 Primary Schools have Computer Labs, all serviced by more than 150 IT Technicians. We are now moving closer to achieving Universal Early Childhood Education by 2015. We have 200 ECCE Centres functioning - 71 run by Servol and 80 Private Sector ECCE Centres are now partnering with the MoE. More than 800 teachers have been trained in ECCE, now bringing close to 15,000 students ages 3 and 4 under the formal ECCE education programmes. Stakeholder consultations commenced on the situation of Special Needs Students with more teachers being trained in the 24 MoE and Private Special Needs Schools. Wider and deeper consultations are continuing to effect a comprehensive policy of mainstreaming of special needs students inclusivity in Education. Primary and ECCE School Curriculum review and reform have been completed while Secondary School Curriculum Reform is being initiated. There has been significant improvement in Literacy and Numeracy in all Primary Schools and very much improved academic performances in SEA and CAPE. Fewer students are scoring less than 30 percent in SEA, moving down from 13 percent to 8 percent. 72 percent of SEA students scored above 50 percent, up from about 58 percent three years ago. Over 100 Primary Schools have moved up from underperforming (Academic Watch) to well-performing (Mostly Effective), while another 100 have moved to the Excelling category.There has been a 10 percent improvement in Creative writing and Language Arts. At CAPE, from about 86 percent three years ago to 93 percent achieving Grades I to V. Students from over 80 Primary Schools have placed within the first 200 SEA places and National Scholarships have moved from approximately 250 to 372 in the past three years. The introduction of the Continuous Assessment Component (CAC) has led to significant improvements in performance in the Secondary Entrance Assessment (SEA). Thousands of Teachers have been exposed to various Teacher Training and Development Workshops over the last three years in several areas, while School Supervisors are undergoing training in Leadership and Management. In infrastructure, from July 2010 to October 2012, Repairs and Maintenance had been carried out in over 650 schools at a cost of 340 Million, using more than 450 small, medium and long-term contractors, creating thousands of jobs. In 18 months, there were 939 emergency jobs dealt with in our schools, while daily, there are about 6 schools experiencing emergencies with toilets, sewer and water systems, major and minor electrical problems and pest infestations. This is as a result of inherited widespread school dilapidation from the past. Approximately 100 schools are over 100 years of age; 200 are more than 50 years of age. During the repair programme in July/August 2013, 212 schools underwent Repairs and Maintenance about 30 of these requiring major electrical works. There have been 32 Early Childhood Care and Education (ECCE) schools constructed, with 20 more to be completed by December and 26 commencing within one month. Another 50 ECCE schools are to be constructed in the upcoming fiscal year. There were 11 Primary Schools constructed, another 14 are in progress and 50 more are scheduled to commence soon. With respect to Secondary Schools, seven have been constructed, nine are in progress and 17 Science and Administrative blocks will commence. All of this has been done throughout Trinidad and Tobago within the last three years. Curriculum vocational qualification subjects are being undertaken from 42 schools in 2010 to 102 schools in 2013. Cadets, Boys Scouts, Girl Guides are being strongly introduced in our schools. A strong focus is now being placed on Physical Education and Sports in schools - Total Gyms are now being procured for 50 Secondary Schools. Improved Schools Based Management is being actively pursued for prevention and reduction of indiscipline and dysfunctional behaviour in schools with a zero-tolerance approach to bullying. Schools are now provided with over 700 Student Support Services personnel including Guidance Counsellors, School Social Workers, Behavioural, Clinical and Educational Psychologists. Over 42,000 students from Forms 3, 5 and 6 were exposed to a two-day symposium to Career Guidance from six Tertiary Learning Institutions, fifty Business Corporations for over one hundred professions. The MoE has undergone serious organisational restructuring incorporating Human Resource Management Information Systems in accordance with its Strategic Plan 2011 to 2015 and its prioritization. In this Academic year, students will continue to benefit from them and many more new policies which serve to reinforce this Governments commitment to Education since this sector remains one of our mainstays in our nations continued path to progress and prosperity. But we cannot succeed without the cooperation of all of our parents, teachers and students. Parents please remember that without your commitment to your childrens education and personal development, our society is in danger of losing even more of our young people to crime and violence. We suffer a crisis in parenting at this time and the time has come for you to recommit to your duties and responsibilities to your children. Build stronger bonds with your children. Talk to them about their lives, their problems, their interests and their emotions. Ensure they are well supervised at all times. Let them know they are subject to strong boundaries and discipline and above all. Let them know that you love and care for them. To the Principals and teachers, I applaud you for your dedicated work but I must implore you to recommit to the very noble task with which you are entrusted as educators. We seek a reduction in teacher absenteeism and better academic performance among our students, especially in their literacy and numeracy skills. Teach our children with inspiration, love, caring and dedication. And to our students, I urge every single one of you to be mindful that you are now benefiting from opportunities that no other generation in this country ever had. You therefore have a duty to your parents, your teachers, your fellow citizens, whose tax dollars fund you, your country and especially yourselves, to excel at your school work. Be respectful, disciplined and diligent with the aim of one day serving our nation as dedicated hard-working citizens. I urge all Principals and Teachers to join the students in reciting and singing the words of our National Pledge and our National Anthem respectively, in honour of our countrys 51st Anniversary of Independence and commit to its ideas. As stakeholders in the Education System, we are the ones who have a special duty to demonstrate patriotism and we must be the best example of the decent, law-abiding citizens at this time and beyond, to preserve our beautiful country for our future generations. Im sure that we will all work together towards these goals and I wish you a very safe, productive school year ahead, filled with achievement and joy, rich in Gods blessings.
