{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/kamla-our-responsibility-to-protect-children-everywhere/article_b24266fb-3fd1-503c-a16b-28a5cfc76d0c.html", "TITLE": " Kamla: Our responsibility to protect children everywhere ", "DATE": "Nov 18, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Children today are at risk, vulnerable, suffering and in need of protection, says Opposition Leader Kamla Persad-Bissessar. As the world marks Universal Children's Day today, Persad-Bissessar pleaded for everyone\u2014citizens, community activists, lawmakers and leaders at home and abroad\u2014to make a firm resolution to protect children everywhere from every form of violence so they can sleep in comfort and grow into the adults God intended them to be. \u201cIf the society we build depends on the way we treat our children, then it is our responsibility to ensure that no child suffers, and every child has the opportunity to learn, grow and live happily,\u201d she stated. The former prime minister said in Trinidad and Tobago many children have suffered tragic and painful violence as their lives were taken, as she noted the horrific experiences this week of little Artie Ramkhelawan, who survived an attack, and two-year-old Keyra Singh, who died of a gunshot wound. She stated some of the worst abuse takes place at home from parents and family, in our schools, in other institutions and in the community. \u201cToo often society shuts its eyes to child trafficking, physical and humiliating treatment and other forms of violence that seriously affect a child's dignity, development and physical and psychological integrity,\u201d said Persad-Bissessar. She said as adults and as leaders, we all share a solemn responsibility to do all we must to ensure all children are protected and saved from abusive situations. Outside of this country, Persad-Bissessar pointed out that in Syria, which has been ravaged by war for nearly five years, more than two million children have been negatively affected. \u201cWar deprived them of their families, their homes, and the comforts we often take for granted. These children remain vulnerable, while some countries that pledged to protect them are closing their doors, leaving these children homeless, stateless, hungry and abandoned. \u201cThe Syrian children of war are not unique. Children in every culture and at every stratum of society face various forms of abuse, neglect, exploitation and violence,\u201d she added. Persad-Bissessar reminded that as prime minister she worked toward the protection of the nation's children. \u201cI ensured that the Children's Authority became functional. My first act as the country's leader was to pursue a Children's Life Fund, which to date has saved the lives of more than 200 of our children. We built and equipped a children's hospital that is still unopened. My government also focused on education, guaranteeing the right of children to a good education from nursery to tertiary,\u201d she stated, adding the work to protect the children must continue. Persad-Bissessar further noted that 61 years ago, the General Assembly of the United Nations urged its member states to institute a Universal Children's Day to create worldwide fraternity and understanding among children, which was followed with the declaration of Universal Children's Day, to be celebrated on November 20 each year, and in 1989 it adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child. All these steps, she stated, were intended to formalise a promise that world leaders would do everything to protect and promote the rights of children. She said today the world is far from fulfilling that pledge to take every possible measure to protect the rights of children \u201cto survive and thrive, to learn and grow, to make their voices heard and to reach their full potential\u201d. \u201cWith multi-lateral arrangements, strong public policy and legislation already in place, we have no excuse for failing to protect children, and we must do more, starting now. \u201cWe must ensure that children not only survive but also thrive, become educated and are protected from violence so they can grow with love and affection and become respected and responsible members of society,\u201d stated Persad-Bissessar. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/survey-more-healthcare-needed-for-t-t-children/article_56f268ee-d0ec-5211-9c49-a1c359f9ee87.html", "TITLE": " Survey: More healthcare needed for T&T children ", "DATE": "Dec 30, 2008 ", "CONTENT": "spelling it out: Social Development Minister Dr Amery Browne addresses the audience at yesterday's presentation of the the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey for T&T at Crowne Plaza Hotel.\u0097Photo: JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK spelling it out: Social Development Minister Dr Amery Browne addresses the audience at yesterday's presentation of the the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey for T&T at Crowne Plaza Hotel.\u0097Photo: JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK CHILDREN are dying before the age of five in this country and the health sector needs to pay attention to this issue, the results of a local household survey have shown. Originally developed for the World Summit for Children by the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey three (MICS 3) was the first comprehensive study of the living situation of children and women to be done in nearly 20 years. Delivering the feature address at the formal launch of MICS 3 at the Crowne Plaza Hotel in Port of Spain yesterday, Social Development Minister Amery Browne indicated that the survey showed that more children were going to school, but the majority of this country still had no access to clean water. Mortality rates also remain high. \"In the area of health, the MICS data indicated that infant mortality was, at the time of this survey, 29 deaths per 1000 live births and the under five mortality was 35 per 1000 live births in this country,\" Browne said. However, Browne added that even though the MICS 3 was customised to meet the needs of this country and successfully carried out on 5,557 households in the North West, North Central, South West and Eastern regions as well as Tobago back in 2005 by the Central Statistical Office with support from UNICEF, it should only be used as a guideline for policy makers on the situation of children and women. He indicated that the MICS 3 had produced statistically sound and internationally comparable estimates of a range of indicators in the areas health, education, child protection and HIV/AIDS which would allow them to address their shortcomings. \"And this is indeed very well timed because in this period of economic crisis around the world it is so essential that we continue to invest in the welfare of our citizens, particularly in our nation's women and children,\" he said. MICS Data Analysis and senior lecturer at the University of the West Indies, Dr Godfrey St Bernard, added that the data collected from MICS 3 was relatively better as it pertained to child health and would help the government as it moves toward developing a caring nation and vision 20/20. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/taking-physical-education-to-a-whole-new-level/article_c3645d44-39b6-5dd6-b3c4-956f7bdd561d.html", "TITLE": " Taking physical education to a whole new level ", "DATE": "Jul 4, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Minister of Education Dr Tim Gopeesingh Minister of Education Dr Tim Gopeesingh Opening new doors in the study of physical education, the University of the West Indies (UWI), St Augustine campus launched an innovative programme that will give physical education teachers in Trinidad and Tobago an opportunity to obtain a degree in their chosen profession. Some 74 students of UWI's Bachelor of Education (B Ed) Physical Education Secondary programme, as part of their field study module, made poster/oral presentations of their final research report which was held at the UWI Sport and Physical Education Centre (SPEC) auditorium recently. Director of the centre, Dr Iva Camille Gloudon, said, \"This programme represents the first time that local physical education teachers will receive a degree in Physical Education from a local tertiary level institution.\" Looking for creative ways to incorporate physical education into children's everyday lives, students selected from the following themes to make their presentations: Social learning through Physical Education; Health and Fitness; Staff Development; Self-Esteem/ Perceptions of Competence; Integration with other subjects, Motivation and choice, Values, Social and Personal Responsibility/ Behaviour. The conference consisted of two poster sessions and three parallel oral presentation sessions. Hayes Jones, a physical education teacher from Belmont Secondary School looked at \"Boys' preferences for and values of Physical Education\". Looking at attendance, participation, preference and frequency of physical education, Jones noted that these things were not regularised at his school. Highlighting some of the changes he felt would take physical education to another level, Jones said, \"We need Physical Education to be properly integrated into the syllabus. We need staff to start looking at physical education more seriously as well as allotting more time in the form of double periods so students can benefit from actually learning a sport and doing some physical activity.\" Through his study, Jones learned that boys at his school preferred more traditional sports such as cricket and football while girls preferred netball as opposed to the non-traditional sports such as swimming, volleyball and tennis. Other students also sought to bring the subject to the forefront. Reynold Phillip looked atStaff Development in Primary School Physical Education, Elsa Porter-Lee addressed Teaching Approach, General School Behaviour Change while Nadia-Alicia Ali spoke on Adventure Education. Poster presentations were displayed in three areas around the hall. For more information about the programme call 662-2002. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/t-t-will-be-first-in-world-to-offer-free/article_2f4bd560-9d16-5ae4-974a-ad5ec3f1d0d5.html", "TITLE": " T&T will be 'first in world' to offer free education ", "DATE": "Dec 20, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Flashback: Barry Padarath, centre, adviser to Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar, carries a box containing two computers belonging to the PM outside the Police Administration Building on Sackville Street, Port of Spain, in June. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE Flashback: Barry Padarath, centre, adviser to Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar, carries a box containing two computers belonging to the PM outside the Police Administration Building on Sackville Street, Port of Spain, in June. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE Cabinet has approved some $163 million aimed at expanding the education system in a mission to make Trinidad and Tobago the first country in the world to offer free universal education from early childhood to tertiary education. Education Minister Dr Tim Gopeesingh disclosed this at the post-Cabinet news conference on Thursday at the Coco Reef Hotel, Tobago, where the Cabinet held its meeting. Gopeesingh said that it was the vision of the Prime Minister to make early childhood care education universal as she did with the secondary school system. He noted that there were some 34,000 children between the ages of three and four in the country, 80 per cent of whom are enrolled in early childhood care systems in the private sector. Government, he said, will partner with the private sector to ensure there is universal early childhood care by 2015. He said in June and July this year, the Ministry conducted a series of consultations to introduce the concept of a public/private partnership arrangement where private stakeholders expressed their willingness to partner with the Ministry. A memorandum of understanding, he said, will be signed between the Government and private early childhood care providers in accordance with selected governance models. This initiative, he said, is estimated to cost some $100 million annually. Gopeesingh noted that some 20 per cent of the 34,000 are enrolled in Government ECCE centres, 70 of these 200 centres are run by Servol. Cabinet, he said, further approved a number of employment positions on contract to ensure these ECCE centres are well staffed. He added that Cabinet agreed to increase the subvention to Servol to meet payments of salaries and other expenses. Gopeesingh noted that there are some persons employed in ECCE centres for some 30 years and who do not have \"tremendous qualifications\" nor qualify for pension. As a result, Cabinet has approved an ex gratia payment of some $39 million for these persons for their service. Gopeesingh also noted that there were a number of positions in the teaching service that cannot be filled as teachers do not want to be posted to schools in remote areas. He said Cabinet agreed to the employment on contract of 200 assistant instructors at levels one, two and three to be placed in secondary schools for three years at a cost of $24 million. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/keep-schools-free-of-racial-ugliness/article_26f7eed4-f41b-565c-8bd8-533f59a8124b.html", "TITLE": " Keep schools free of racial ugliness ", "DATE": "Nov 13, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "An important principle that we should uphold at all cost in this country is that any child should be able to attend any school. One of the most beautiful sights in any T&T schoolyard is children of different races playing together. Recently I was at a Roman Catholic girls' secondary school in central, and in the schoolyard I saw children of Indian descent, children of African descent, children of mixed race, children in hijabs, children with dreadlocks and corn rows. When the bell sounded for change of class, the girls all stood and a prayer was said over the microphone, in which they all seemed to participate. During this time, one teacher was preparing a choir to sing Indian songs for a function that was imminent at the school. Remember, this is a Roman Catholic school; you could not tell that from observation. This is who we are. For my own part I went to Harmony Hall Presbyterian school in Union, Marabella. The school was about 90 per cent Indian, as were my friends. The teachers were mainly Indian, and all nurturing, as I recall. Mr Nagessar\"Nags\" to all of his pupils, still alive and an icon on Union Road, even asked my uncle about me, decades after I left. At morning assemblies, we all sang both traditional and Hindu spiritual songs. I have been a teacher for my entire adult life, and I refuse to see race when I teach. I learned that from Indian teachers at Harmony Hall Presbyterian. If what the now-besieged principal of the Tunapuna Hindu School says is true, then I fear we are retrogressing. And what about this very important principle that schools are secular spaces fundamentally, and that any child, whatever her/his race or religion, should be able to attend any convent, St Mary's, Presentation, Naps, SAGHS, or any comprehensive in this country When the SEA results appear in the papers, we see children across races and religions going to schools of their choice, with no reference to race or creed. Children from Sea Lots go to Fatima. Children from Felicity go to Presentation, Chaguanas. There are very few Hindu secondary schools in the country, so it is very important that all secondary schools open their doors to Hindu children. In the same way, Hindu primary schools must open their doors to children of every race. We can't have edicts that keep children out of school on the basis of race or religion. This will bring the ugliness of children being denied school places on the basis of race, as if we here are living in the American south, in the 1950s. This is a beautiful country run by a multiracial party that won seats in the East-West corridor, and in Tobago, on the basis of multi-racial support for an Indian Prime Minister. At all cost, the party has to show that it means what it says. We can't rise if black children on the East-West corridor are denied school places on account of race. The lesson from the NAR and now from the People's Partnership, is that the black community in the country wants to move on. And I think we need a Minister of Education who stands for something, and who would not hide behind the technicality of an Equal Opportunity body, when what is needed is for him to say that all children must be free to enter any of the nation's schools, whether Hindu, Catholic, or government. And we can't have a Minister going to the police with his \"friend\" when the issue is an allegation that his friend is preventing black children from attending a school he over-sees. I find this issue to be particularly distressing. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/educating-the-educator/article_8c37645c-2b35-5439-83c4-7555fc51b9e6.html", "TITLE": " Educating the educator ", "DATE": "Aug 20, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "These days the PNM is heavily engaged in political education through its newly established \"colleges'' in all parts of the country. How much is political and how much educational, I leave it to others to assess. Listening to the political leader at the public forum in Point Fortin, I found it commendable that an important part of his lecture was focused on the questions of \"separation of powers\" and \"human rights\", two concepts which rightly deserve explanation and elucidation in today's T&T. However, the fiery speech by the leader failed to give a full picture on the reality of both concepts. Mr Manning was digging deep into the letter and spirit of Baron de Montesquieu, a French philosopher and statesman, believing in reason and human progress and questioning tradition and authority. His classic, On the Spirit of Laws remains the main source of reference when it comes to the question of separation of powers. Montesquieu's book could usefully be a part of the curriculum at our law schools today. Mr. Manning is certainly at the right source and has the merit of bringing Montesquieu into T&T's present day constitutional reality. He elaborates quite extensively on the requirement of strict independence of the judiciary vis--vis the executive and the legislature, but has very little to say about the separation of powers between the executive and legislature. Here is what Montesquieu has to say: \"When the law making and the law enforcement powers are united, there can be no liberty.\" In the scenario that obtains currently in T&T, where out of the 26 elected lawmakers, 22 are at the same time, part of the executive, the lines of separation of powers between the executive and the legislature are blurred if not removed. Moving to the question of human rights, Mr Manning has the merit of making this important question a central part of his lecture at Point Fortin. However, what is missing is the absence of any reference to the international dimension of human rights. No mention is made of the basic source, namely the Universal System of Human Rights, starting with the Universal Declaration, and the two major international human rights conventions, one on civil and political rights, and the other on economic, social and cultural rights. T&T is a part of this international human rights system, commonly called the Bill of Rights, and it has ratified both conventions. On both laws and policy measures, implementing and reporting, T&T is seriously lagging behind. By way of example, reference is made to the shelving of a comprehensive gender policy or the tardy children's protection legislation, and in terms of reporting, no reports on economic, social and cultural rights have been submitted to the UN supervisory body since the early 90s. Mr Manning elaborated at some length on the question of economic and social rights, using the right to housing as an example. There is no such thing as a right to housing, the argument goes, because such a right, and by extension other economic and social rights, cannot be invoked and enforced before a local court. This argument does not hold, certainly not in doctrine and practice of the international human rights community. While it is true that economic, social and cultural rights as enshrined in the International Covenant are not immediately applicable and enforceable before a national court, except in the rare case of \"public interest litigation\", these rights constitute nevertheless a legal basis for empowering people to claim implementation as an entitlement and not simply as a gesture of goodwill by the Government. Nobody argues that housing, education, health, food, water and sanitation, safety, and other essentials, must be made available overnight to all citizens, by a simple stroke of legislation. But within the human rights community, there is common agreement that every effort must be made, within a certain timeframe, towards progressive realisation of these rights. This means that the Government must strive towards gradual implementation, by allocating the necessary resources and setting the right policy priorities, as compared with other, less essential projects. Incidentally, the UN has recently introduced what is called a rights-based approach to development planning and programming in its country operations. To its credit, the Government has recently endorsed this approach in a new development assistance framework agreement with the UN system. So much, then, for public information and education on two key issues omnipresent in today's T&T. It would point to the fact that there is always room for gaining new, correct and relevant information through education and learning, even when delivered in the halls of PNM \"colleges'' and by a most prominent teacher. After all, learning and education is a life-long process and is everybody's business! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/let-s-help-educate-and-uplift-our-children/article_dd264158-7dc1-5943-b822-0424794db4ba.html", "TITLE": " Let\u2019s help educate and uplift our children ", "DATE": "Feb 15, 2017 ", "CONTENT": " More than 400 years ago, Shakespeare wrote, \u201cThe evil that men do live after them; the good is oft interred with their bones\u201d. This adage still holds good in so many instan\u00adces, but I would like to contradict him on behalf of one person, our inimitable and tireless Minister of Educa\u00adtion, Anthony Garcia. I wish to salute him for the several initiatives he has put in place to raise the standard of education as it obtains today. From day one, he has hit the road running, and like Usain Bolt, he has not stopped. His latest endea\u00advour, to deal with the inadequacies of mathema\u00adtics, and language arts, inclusive of creative writing, could not have been more providential and opportune. I would like however to humbly suggest, in addition to the extensive teachers/principals/supervisors/district teams workshops already conducted, several retirees who are willing to come onboard be invited to share their skills, knowledge and expertise with deficient pupils in their communities. Thus, these young people could access additional help to bring them to an acceptable standard. I had been offering free lessons in English language, creative writing and \u201cbroughtupsy\u201d to several pupils from my community, from both secondary and primary schools, since 2009. I even wrote two books, Caribbean Sunshine For Mammie's Children and Mammie's Folklore Stories, using the children themselves as the protagonists in the stories to encourage them to enjoy reading, build their vocabulary, and improve their sentence structure and writing skills. Unfortunately, I had to stop because of medical treatment for some time. Today, some of these young people have pro\u00adgressed to university, and those from the primary schools are now at Hillview College, Holy Cross College and North Eastern College, to name a few. I marvel at the way in which these \u201cunmanage\u00adable\u201d teenagers were able to come to terms with the realisation that they are indeed important and that there are indeed people who really care about them and want to see them become good citizens, no matter what obstacles they may encounter. A bit of \u201ctough love\u201d helped tremendously. They were pleasantly surprised at their success in their exams, especially in English and creative writing. As such, I would like to exhort other retirees like myself who are willing to offer themselves in this nation-building venture for our young people, and posterity. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/education-and-the-budget/article_dcda0fcc-1348-537d-83c8-2ad7afed98c4.html", "TITLE": " Education and the budget ", "DATE": "Oct 18, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "A SONG FOR PM: Sherice Lutchman sings \u0093Greatest Love of All\u0094 for Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar during the People\u0092s Partnership rally yesterday at Mid Centre Mall, Chaguanas. \u2013Photo: DEXER PHILIP A SONG FOR PM: Sherice Lutchman sings \u0093Greatest Love of All\u0094 for Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar during the People\u0092s Partnership rally yesterday at Mid Centre Mall, Chaguanas. \u2013Photo: DEXER PHILIP Part I In the budget presentation by the Minister of Finance there was reference to two aspects of the education system the GATE programme and the Seamless Education System. I shall quote directly from the budget presentation for I find it difficult to interpret exactly what is intended. Education and GATE \"A further review will be informed by the findings of studies undertaken by the Centre for Workforce Research and Development funded by the European Development Fund under the aegis of the University of the West Indies. The study will identify the skills gaps within the local economy, thereby guiding education and training needs that are aligned with labour market information.\" \"The GATE programme will now be subject to more rigorous pay-for-performance rules with respect to students to ensure value for money spent and greater accountability will be required from the institutions that are registered in this programme\". I am in agreement with the intention to monitor the GATE programme more closely. I suggest that the GATE programme entitlement should be subject to a \"means test\". The Prime Minister recently pointed out that equality is not the same as equity; it is equity that we should pursue. Is there equity when \"the people's money\" is used to pay the university fees of the sons and daughters of millionaires Do the proposals by the Minister of Finance imply that GATE will be given only for particular areas of study This would be a big departure from present policy and from many of the reasons which are usually given for the existence of GATE. The Seamless Education System \"The Seamless Education System is a multi-phase project. The first phase of this project will improve equity, quality and relevance of educational services provided to all children in Early Childhood Care and Education, and in primary education.\" For some time now I have been struggling to understand the concept, as espoused by the Ministry of Education, of \"Seamless Education\". Does it mean passage from one level to the next (primary to secondary) without a barrier Can we expect that the SEA will be removed (a development which I would support if only to save our children from the trauma of this examination) The only reason we keep this examination is because we have a system of so-called prestige schools. If the SEA were to be removed and replaced (as is the case in many developed countries) by assignment to secondary schools by geography, influential parents whose children are assigned to non-prestige schools would soon force Government, and the various religious denominations who manage schools, to make all schools prestige schools! The Minister of Education spent a great deal of his valuable time discussing general financial issues and replying to Opposition comments. Why don't Government and Opposition organise their affairs in such a way that certain speakers deal with the economy in general, others are assigned to criticise the opposite side and let the various Ministers tell us about their areas of responsibility Instead, Ministers having spent most of their time outside of their ministerial responsibilities then have to rush the last part (and most important part from the point of view of their direct responsibilities) of their presentation and have to ask anxiously: \"how much time have I got left\" He recorded the achievements of the Government in education. He discussed the laptop (computer) programme, primary school curriculum, Early Childhood Education, the strategy document of his Ministry, the introduction of universal secondary education and \"Universal\" tertiary education with GATE. Laptop programme I do not believe the laptop programme was a good idea. The laptops should have been provided to the schools. In any event there should have been a \"means test\" to promote equity in Government expenditure. Primary school curriculum I agree with the proposals to introduce \"non-academic\" subjects. He stated: \"we are now moving to continuous base-assessment programmes so that students would be able to do things like physical education, visual and performing arts, music, dance theatre, drama, health and family life, moral, values, ethics; all of these will be taught up to Standard 5, compulsory up to Standard 5, so we are beginning to get a more all-rounded child rather than just academic performance\". His way of getting away from the present situation whereby students are only taught the subjects which are examined in the SEA is to have the other subjects assessed continuously and the marks obtained thereby to be included in the SEA marks. This is a bold step and no doubt fraught with many problems, not least of which will be to achieve parity in marking among teachers and schools. With respect to the \"academic curriculum\" the introduction of Geography should be considered. Modern Geography places mankind in his/her environment and so includes social studies as well as environmental studies. Early Childhood Education I have some concern for the use of de-populated primary schools as Early Childhood Centres. Many of these primary schools are not even suitable for primary education today. Also the idea of placing very young children with primary school children, some of whom will be 11 or 12 years old, is fraught with danger. John Spence is professor Emeritus, UWI. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/features/aquaponics-takes-centre-stage-at-uwi-children-s-workshop/article_2f2e1ae7-1d28-5bc2-8ca0-919be5c2bc77.html", "TITLE": " Aquaponics takes centre stage at UWI children's workshop ", "DATE": "Aug 23, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "What do plastic bottles, goldfish, glass marbles and filtered water have in common They are all parts of a basic aquaponics system \u2013 so simple, a child can do it and they did at The University of the West Indies (The UWI) After-School Care Centre's (ASCC) Children's Discovery Workshop as part of the project Science Education as a Climate Change Resilience Strategy (SECCRS). The workshop featured an aquaponics-themed presentation and graduation ceremony for 67 participants ages 3 to 13. Aquaponics \u2013 the symbiotic system combining aquaculture (raising aquatic animals such as fish in tanks) with hydroponics (cultivating plants in water) wherein, the fish waste produced provides an organic food source for the growing plants, and the plants, in turn, provide a natural filter for the water the fish live in \u2013 was just one of the topics covered during the two-week workshop. The children also learned about climate change and green technologies through outdoor activities, games, arts and crafts, and a visit to the NIHERST National Science Centre. The workshop was a result of The UWI St Augustine's Department of Chemistry's ongoing SECCRS initiative, an 18-month project funded by the United Nations Development Programme's (UNDP) Global Environment Facility Small Grants Programme (GEF-SGP). The project's overall goal is to empower communities to apply practical knowledge of green technologies to best meet the need of local circumstances. Members of the Heights of Guanapo community were trained to use aquaponics to avoid soil and water contamination from the landfill. Nine of these adults were then mentored to work directly with the children of the ASCC and Guanapo to pass on what they had learned. The UWI Department of Chemistry and Department of Clinical Veterinary Sciences Aquatic Health Unit, the Guanapo Community Environmental Development Organisation (GCEDO) and the National Institute of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (NIHERST) have a unique partnership with the ASCC to accomplish the project goals.
